If applicable. molybdate (0.5 mM), tungstate (0.5 mM), DMSO (14 mM), or @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ (1 mM) were added at the time of inoculation.

@gm$ E. limosum @/gm$ was detected at high levels in F1 and F2 (8.9 +- 0.2 and 7.8 +- 0.4 log copies ml-1, respectively) in reactors 22 h after spiking (Table 2 and Fig. 6c). When pooling data from the two fermentations, @gm$ E. limosum @/gm$ and @sm$ lactate @/sm$ supplementation led to significant increases in @sm$ lactate @/sm$ (P < 0.01), formate (P < 0.05), propionate (P < 0.001), and total SCFAs (P < 0.001) (Fig. 5c). The impact of daily addition of @gm$ E. limosum @/gm$ at 108 CFU ml-1 together with 60 mM dl-lactate differed between fermentations (Fig. S7c and d). @gm$ E. limosum @/gm$ and @sm$ lactate @/sm$ supplementation significantly increased butyrate (30.3 +- 1.3 mM versus 18.7 +- 1.2 mM, P < 0.01) in F1 and propionate (20.6 +- 2.5 mM versus 11.2 +- 2.9, P < 0.05) in F2 compared to respective stabilization. This treatment also decreased Enterobacteriaceae detected by qPCR in F1 (P < 0.05) (Table 2), which was confirmed by MiSeq data in both fermentations. A lower abundance of Enterococcus was also observed in both fermentations, with a higher relative abundance of Bifidobacterium, Peptostreptococcaceae, and Ruminococcus during F1 and of Collinsella and @sm$ lactate @/sm$-utilizing Veillonella during F2 and a lower Bacteroides abundance during F2 (Fig.

@gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$ strains were isolated at prefectural livestock hygiene centers or meat inspection centers in 10 prefectures located either in Tohoku, Kanto, Hokuriku, Tokai, Chubu, Chugoku, Shikoku or Kyushu region of Japan during 2014 and 2016 from pigs affected with erysipelas. They were sent to the National Institute of Animal Health for serological and genetic analyses. In this study, only the @gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$ isolates from pigs affected with chronic erysipelas, namely, endocarditis and polyarthritis, in farms where the Koganei vaccine were used were analyzed for their serovars and @sm$ acriflavine @/sm$-resistance, and tested by the SNP-based PCR.

@gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$ and related strains were grown in BBL Brain Heart Infusion (BHI) media (BD, Franklin Lakes, NJ) supplemented with L-arginine (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) under an atmosphere of 2-5% @sm$ H2 @/sm$, 2-5% CO2, and balance N2.

@gm$ Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae @/gm$ can cause erysipelas in animals and erysipeloid in humans. Since its recurrence in 2012, swine erysipelas has caused serious losses within the pig industry in China. The aim of this study was to perform multilocus sequence typing and understand the virulence and antimicrobial susceptibility of @gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$ isolates in China. Multilocus sequence typing (MLST) of a total of 120 strains was performed, and as a result, three different sequence types were identified, of which ST48 was the main one. Five isolates of each MLST type were randomly selected to be used to challenge mice. ST48 was associated with a higher virulence. Antimicrobial susceptibility was tested using a microdilution technique and, to analyze the resistance mechanism, six strains were selected for genome sequencing. A comparison of the six genomes indicated the presence of a suspected macrolide resistance gene, namely, Erm(A)-like, in erythromycin-resistant strains, which increased the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of erythromycin against E. coli C600 at least four-fold. In addition, three mutations (gyrA86T-I, gyrA90D-N, and parC81S-I) were observed in the @sm$ quinolone @/sm$ resistance-determining regions (QRDRs) of gyrA and parC in @sm$ quinolone @/sm$-resistant strains. After the gyrA gene with the 86T-I mutation or the parC gene with the 81S-I mutation was transfected into E. coli C600, the MIC of enrofloxacin against this strain increased at least two-fold. Our findings provide a theoretical basis for developing antibacterial drugs and may contribute to the clinical prevention and control of @gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$.

@gm$ Escherichia coli O157:H7 @/gm$ is an important pathogen of humans, capable of causing severe diarrhea and more serious sequelae. In this study, the transcriptome response of @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ to bile was determined. Bile exposure induced significant changes in mRNA levels of genes related to virulence potential, including a reduction of mRNA for the 41 genes making up the locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island. Bile treatment had an unusual effect on mRNA levels for the entire flagella-chemotaxis regulon, resulting in two- to four-fold increases in mRNA levels for genes associated with the flagella hook-basal body structure, but a two-fold decrease for "late" flagella genes associated with the flagella filament, stator motor, and chemotaxis. Bile salts also caused increased mRNA levels for seventeen genes associated with iron scavenging and metabolism, and counteracted the inhibitory effect of the iron chelating agent @sm$ 2,2'-dipyridyl @/sm$ on growth of @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$. These findings suggest that @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ may use bile as an environmental signal to adapt to changing conditions associated with the small intestine, including adaptation to an iron-scarce environment.

@gm$ Eubacterium limosum @/gm$ can use the Wood-Ljungdahl (WL) pathway for demethylation of phenolic compounds (Genthner et al.; Drake; Liu and Suflita). This pathway was thus suggested as the most likely metabolism for IX conversion (Fig. 1b) (Drake; Studenik et al.; Jeong et al.). For methylotrophic reactions in @gm$ Eubacterium limosum @/gm$, inducible enzymes and complex patterns of diauxic growth and (co-) metabolic regulations have been described (Pacaud et al.; Lindley et al.; Cocaign et al.; Loubiere and Lindley; Loubiere et al.; Lebloas et al.). Whereas during growth on sugars, the WL pathway can be used to maintain the redox balance but there is no need that the pathway is coupled to energy conservation (Fig. 1c), in absence of sugars, the pathway must be coupled to net @sm$ ATP @/sm$ synthesis such as via ion gradient-driven phosphorylation by ATP synthases (Muller).
@gm$ Eubacterium ramulus @/gm$ is one of the key colonic bacteria implicated in the biotransformation of the polyphewnolic compounds @sm$ quercetin @/sm$, apigenin and naringenin.

@gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ (ATCC 25,586) was purchased from Guangdong Microbial Culture Collection Center (GDMCC), and grown in Brain Heart Infusion Broth (hopebio, China) supplemented with hemin, K2HPO4, Vitamin K1, and @sm$ L-Cysteine @/sm$ in a round bottom vertical anaerobic culture bag (hopebio, China) at 37 C.

@gm$ Faecalibacterium @/gm$ was the paramount short chain fatty acid-producing bacterium in the human hindgut, also beneficial in improving diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer, which further explained the improvement of intestinal barriers and the increased concentration of volatile fatty acids (propionic acid and @sm$ butyric acid @/sm$) in the cecum.

@gm$ Faecalibacterium prausnitzii @/gm$ is abundant in the healthy human intestinal microbiota, and the absence or scarcity of this bacterium has been linked with inflammatory diseases and metabolic disorders. @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ thus shows promise as a next-generation probiotic for use in restoring the balance of the gut microbial flora and, due to its strong anti-inflammatory properties, for the treatment of certain pathological conditions. However, very little information is available about gene function and regulation in this species. Here, we utilized a systems biology approach-weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WGCNA)-to analyze gene expression in three publicly available RNAseq datasets from F. prausnitzii strain A2-165, all obtained in different laboratory conditions. The co-expression network was then subdivided into 24 co-expression gene modules. A subsequent enrichment analysis revealed that these modules are associated with different kinds of biological processes, such as arginine, histidine, cobalamin, or @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ metabolism as well as bacteriophage function, molecular chaperones, stress response, or SOS response. Some genes appeared to be associated with mechanisms of protection against oxidative stress and could be essential for @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$'s adaptation and survival under anaerobic laboratory conditions. Hub and bottleneck genes were identified by analyses of intramodular connectivity and betweenness, respectively; this highlighted the high connectivity of genes located on mobile genetic elements, which could promote the genetic evolution of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ within its ecological niche. This study provides the first exploration of the complex regulatory networks in @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$, and all of the "omics" data are available online for exploration through a graphical interface at https://shiny.migale.inrae.fr/app/faeprau.

@gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ is recognized as a diverse taxon, both phenotypically and genotypically. Eight biotypes of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ have been identified by Piot et al. based on the presence of beta-galactosidase, lipase and hippurate hydrolysis activities, whereas Benito et al. identified seventeen biotypes based on these characteristics in addition to fermentation of xylose, @sm$ arabinose @/sm$ and galactose. Phenotypic diversity within @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ has also been described in terms of virulence factors, particularly production of sialidase and formation of biofilms. Genetic heterogeneity within @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ has been demonstrated using amplified ribosomal DNA restriction analysis (ARDRA). Santiago et al., identified three ARDRA genotypes of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$, of which only two genotypes (genotypes 1 and 3) produced sialidase.

@gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ is susceptible to various antibiotics: penicillin, amoxicillin, vancomycin, metronidazole and clindamycin. @sm$ Quinolones @/sm$ and co-trimoxazole are less effective. Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for vaginosis. No consensus exists on the treatment of systemic infections. Among the five patients treated for bone-and-joint infections, three received amoxicillin or ampicillin, one patient each was prescribed clindamycin or co-trimoxazole, and rifampin or @sm$ quinolones @/sm$ were added to three patients' regimens.

@gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$ KCTC5096 (@gm$ GV @/gm$) and Atopobium vaginae KCTC15240 (AV) were obtained from the Korean Collection for Type Cultures (Daejun, Korea). The bacteria were subcultured in GAM or BHI broth supplemented with yeast extract (1%), @sm$ maltose @/sm$ (0.1%), glucose (0.1%), and horse serum (10%) at 37  C for 48 h under anaerobic conditions (in a sealed anaerobic jar).

@gm$ Haemophilus @/gm$ isolates were resistant to sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim (n = 25, 67.6%), amoxicillin (n = 18, 34%), cefuroxime (n = 5, 25%), amoxicillin/clavulanic acid (n = 4, 22.2%), tetracycline (n = 4, 14.8%), chloramphenicol (n = 6, 10.9%), and ceftriaxone (n = 5, 9.6%). All @gm$ Haemophilus @/gm$ isolates were sensitive to @sm$ penicillin G @/sm$ and ciprofloxacin (Table 5).

@gm$ Haemophilus parainfluenzae @/gm$ and Haemophilus influenzae, upper respiratory tract microbiota representatives, are able to colonize natural and artificial surfaces as biofilm. The aim of the present study was to assay the effect of ten 1,2,4-triazole-ciprofloxacin hybrids on planktonic or biofilm-forming haemophili cells in vitro under stationary conditions on the basis of MICs (minimal inhibitory concentrations) and MBICs (minimal biofilm inhibitory concentrations). In addition, anti-adhesive properties of these compounds were examined. The reference strains of @gm$ H. parainfluenzae @/gm$ and H. influenzae were included. The broth microdilution microtiter plate (MTP) method with twofold dilution of the compounds, or ciprofloxacin (reference agent) in 96-well polystyrene microplates, was used. The optical density (OD) reading was made spectrophotometrically at a wavelength of 570 nm (OD570) both to measure bacterial growth and to detect biofilm-forming cells under the same conditions with 0.1% @sm$ crystal violet @/sm$.

@gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ was 100% resistance to ampicillin, 85.7% in chloramphenicol, sulphamethoxazole trimethoprim and cephalothin, (71%) in ceftriaxone however it indicates low resistance to ciprofloxacin (35.7%) and doxycycline. This was in consistence with the study done in Ethiopia. Proteus species were resistance to ampicillin (91%), cephalothin (87%), @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ (73.9%) and ceftriaxone (65%). The isolates were sensitive to ciprofloxacin (83%) and gentamicin (74%). This was compared to previous studies done in the country and elsewhere. Most of the gram negative bacteria isolated were resistant to ampicillin, cephalothin, @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ and chloramphenicol.

@gm$ Klebsiella aerogenes @/gm$ strain W70 has an inducible pathway for the degradation of d-arabitol which is comparable to the one found in Aerobacter aerogenes strain PRL-R3. The pathway is also similar to the pathway of ribitol catabolism in that it is composed of a pentitol dehydrogenase, d-arabitol dehydrogenase (ADH), and a pentulokinase, d-xylulokinase (DXK). These two enzymes are coordinately controlled and induced in response to d-arabitol, the apparent inducer of synthesis of these enzymes. We obtained mutants which lacked a functional d-xylose pathway and were constitutive for the ribitol catabolic pathway. These mutants were able to grow on the unusual pentitol, xylitol, only if they contained the functional DXK of the d-arabitol pathway. This provided us with a specific selection technique for DXK(+) transductants. As in @gm$ A. aerogenes @/gm$, mutants constitutive for ADH were able to use this enzyme to convert the hexitol @sm$ d-mannitol @/sm$ to d-fructose. With mutants blocked in the normal @sm$ d-mannitol @/sm$ catabolic pathway, growth on @sm$ d-mannitol @/sm$ became a test for ADH constitutivity. Growth of such mutants on xylitol, d-arabitol, and @sm$ d-mannitol @/sm$ was utilized to classify transductants in mapping, by transductional analysis, the loci involved in d-arabitol utilization.

@gm$ Klebsiella michiganensis @/gm$ strains can be isolated from the gastro-intestinal tract, blood and cerebrospinal fluid of infants, and they are affiliated with upper-respiratory diseases in adults. In this study, we isolated K. michiganensis strains predominantly from sewage sludge. Previously, it was shown that sub-group B1 strains have the potential to synthesize protease inhibitor @sm$ leupeptin @/sm$, which might provide a colonization advantage in the lung.

@gm$ Klebsiella pneumoniae @/gm$ is considered a good host strain for the production of 2,3-butanediol, which is a promising platform chemical with various industrial applications. In this study, three genes, including those encoding glucosyltransferase (wabG), lactate dehydrogenase (ldhA), and pyruvate formate-lyase (pflB), were disrupted in @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ to reduce both its pathogenic characteristics and the production of several by-products. In flask cultivation with minimal medium, the yield of 2,3-butanediol from rationally engineered @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ (DeltawabG DeltaldhA DeltapflB) reached 0.461 g/g @sm$ glucose @/sm$, which was 92.2% of the theoretical maximum, with a significant reduction in by-product formation. However, the growth rate of the pflB mutant was slightly reduced compared to that of its parental strain. Comparison with similar mutants of Escherichia coli suggested that the growth defect of pflB-deficient @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ was caused by redox imbalance rather than reduced level of intracellular acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl-CoA). From an analysis of the transcriptome, it was confirmed that the removal of pflB from @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ significantly repressed the expression of genes involved in the formate hydrogen lyase (FHL) system.

@gm$ Klebsiella variicola @/gm$ strain JNQH579 was recovered from a sputum sample of a 64-year male patient in intensive care units (ICUs) at a tertiary hospital in Jinan City, Shandong Province, in March 2021, who had been hospitalized for 17days due to severe pneumoniae and renal failure. The patient had received @sm$ tigecycline @/sm$ treatment for 7days at a dosage of 100mg (IV) q12h before the isolation of the strain. Based on the antibiotic susceptibility testing results, antibiotic therapy was switched to aztreonam 0.5g (IV) q8h in combination with @sm$ tigecycline @/sm$.

@gm$ L. raffinolactis @/gm$ strains are capable of fermenting alpha-galactosides including raffinose and melibiose and the resulting alpha-galactose is further degraded through either the tagatose 6-phosphate or the Leloir pathway (Boucher et al., ). L. hircilactis acidifies milk well and is capable of fermenting @sm$ galactose @/sm$, lactose, melibiose, raffinose, sucrose, mannitol, gentibiose and starch, whereas L. laudensis exhibits limited milk acidification yet is able to ferment lactose, @sm$ galactose @/sm$, sucrose, mannitol and xylose (Meucci et al., ).

@gm$ L. raffinolactis @/gm$ strains are capable of fermenting alpha-galactosides including raffinose and melibiose and the resulting alpha-galactose is further degraded through either the tagatose 6-phosphate or the Leloir pathway (Boucher et al., ). L. hircilactis acidifies milk well and is capable of fermenting galactose, lactose, melibiose, raffinose, sucrose, @sm$ mannitol @/sm$, gentibiose and starch, whereas L. laudensis exhibits limited milk acidification yet is able to ferment lactose, galactose, sucrose, @sm$ mannitol @/sm$ and xylose (Meucci et al., ).

@gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ is able to convert tryptophan into @sm$ indole @/sm$ and its derivatives, which are major aromatic hydrocarbon receptors (AHRs) that play a pivotal role in intestinal immunobarrier function.

@gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ strains grown in MRS media (with or without antibiotics), washed with @sm$ PBS @/sm$ and re-suspended in @sm$ PBS @/sm$ were orally gavaged once/day for 7 consecutive days before starting the DSS treatment. Oral gavage of indicated lactobacilli was continued daily until experiments were terminated (11 days, 16 days). Lactobacilli were administered at varying cell number. Regular dose consisted of 109 CFU/mouse/day (denoted as 1 x ), high dose consisted of 1010 CFU/mouse/day (denoted as 10 x ) and low dose consisted of 108 CFU/mouse/day (denoted as 0.1 x ) (See Fig. S2). Control mice (untreated, DSS only) received daily gavage of @sm$ PBS @/sm$ instead of bacteria.

@gm$ Lactobacillus acidophilus @/gm$ is one of the widespread probiotic bacteria that can overcome acid and bile barrier of stomach and intestine, respectively, and then have beneficial effects on the host improving its intestinal microbial balance. The cell membrane FO F1 -ATPase is an important factor in the response and tolerance to low pH through the action of controlling the H+ concentration between the cell cytoplasm and external medium. In this study, the effects of extremely high-frequency EMI at the frequencies of 51 8 GHz and 53 GHz and cetfazidime ( mumol l-1 ) on survival of L. acidophilus VKM B-1660 in the gastrointestinal model in vitro and on ATPase activity of their membrane vesicles were investigated. Irradiated @gm$ L. acidophilus @/gm$ survived in media with acid pH; the irradiation stimulated N,N'-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide-sensitive FO F1 -ATPase activity under acidic conditions, but enhanced the inhibitory effects of @sm$ ceftazidime @/sm$. Probably irradiated @gm$ L. acidophilus @/gm$ is overcoming the acid barrier even in the presence of @sm$ ceftazidime @/sm$ due to the FO F1 -ATPase. The obtained results can allow the use of @gm$ L. acidophilus @/gm$ in food industry, veterinary and medicine. SIGNIFICANCE AND IMPACT OF THE STUDY: The probiotic property of lactobacilli is defined with survival in different conditions of human digestive tract even in the presence of antibiotics and subjected to electromagnetic irradiation (EMI) at the extremely high frequency. Despite the fact that EMI and antibiotic @sm$ ceftazidime @/sm$ affected @gm$ Lactobacillus acidophilus @/gm$; the viable number of bacterial cells was decreased in in vitro gastrointestinal model, but they could to grow in fresh growth medium. The changes in the FO F1 -ATPase activity were obtained at acidic pH. Thus, these bacteria can overcome acid barrier due to the FO F1 -ATPase: the irradiation stimulates the FO F1 -ATPase activity in the acidic conditions, but enhances the effects of @sm$ ceftazidime @/sm$.

@gm$ Lactobacillus crispatus @/gm$ strains were cultivated on semisynthetic MRS medium without glucose supplemented with a 1% (wt/vol) concentration of a particular sugar, and the optical densities (measured at a wavelength of 600 nm) were recorded using a plate reader (BioTek, Winooski, VT, USA). Tested sugars are arabinose, cellobiose, fructose, fucose, galactose, @sm$ glycogen @/sm$, glucose, inulin, maltodextrin, mannitol, N-acetil-D-glucosamine, N-acetil-D-galactosamine, mannose, melibiose, maltose, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose, sorbitol, starch, sucrose, threalose, turanose, and xylose (Figure 3).

@gm$ Lactobacillus gasseri @/gm$ and Lactobacillus paragasseri are human commensal lactobacilli that are candidates for probiotic application. Knowledge of their oligosaccharide metabolic properties is valuable for synbiotic application. The present study characterized oligosaccharide metabolic systems and their impact on @sm$ lipoteichoic acid @/sm$ (@sm$ LTA @/sm$) production in the two organisms, i.e., L. gasseri JCM 1131T and L. paragasseri JCM 11657. The two strains grew well in medium with glucose but poorly in medium with raffinose, and growth rates in medium with kestose differed between the strains. Oligosaccharide metabolism markedly influenced their @sm$ LTA @/sm$ production, and apparent molecular size of @sm$ LTA @/sm$ in electrophoresis recovered from cells cultured with glucose and kestose differed from that from cells cultured with raffinose in the strains. On the other hand, more than 15-fold more @sm$ LTA @/sm$ was observed in the @gm$ L. gasseri @/gm$ cells cultured with raffinose when compared with glucose or kestose after incubation for 15 h. Transcriptome analysis identified glycoside hydrolase family 32 enzyme as a potential kestose hydrolysis enzyme in the two strains. Transcriptomic levels of multiple genes in the dlt operon, involved in D-alanine substitution of @sm$ LTA @/sm$, were lower in cells cultured with raffinose than in those cultured with kestose or glucose. This suggested that the different sizes of @sm$ LTA @/sm$ observed among the carbohydrates tested were partly due to different levels of alanylation of @sm$ LTA @/sm$. The present study indicates that available oligosaccharide has the impact on the @sm$ LTA @/sm$ production of the industrially important lactobacilli, which might influence their probiotic properties.

@gm$ Lactobacillus helveticus @/gm$ produce a glycolipid-type biosurfactant closely resembling xylolipids. The biosurfactants produced by Lactococcus lactis 53 are composed of glycoproteins with @sm$ glucose @/sm$, rhamnose, fucose and mannose.

@gm$ Lactobacillus johnsonii @/gm$ BS15 (CCTCC M2013663) is a probiotic strain that was first isolated from homemade yogurt collected from Hongyuan Prairie, Aba Autonomous Prefecture, China and reported to prevent non-alcoholic fatty liver diseases in obese mice. In our previous study, we found that incorporating BS15 to broiler diet enhanced growth performance and improved meat quality. Moreover, only live BS15 and not disrupted cells may exert health benefits mainly by improving @sm$ lipid @/sm$ metabolism, intestinal development, and gut microflora in the small intestine. We then applied BS15 to prevent SNE and discovered that it may positively control the growth performance, @sm$ lipid @/sm$ deposition, and fatty acid composition of chicken meat during SNE infection by enhancing intestinal development and balancing microflora in the intestines.

@gm$ Lactococcus raffinolactis @/gm$, unlike most lactococci, is able to ferment alpha-galactosides, such as melibiose and @sm$ raffinose @/sm$. More than 12 kb of chromosomal DNA from L. raffinolactis ATCC 43920 was sequenced, including the alpha-galactosidase gene and genes involved in the Leloir pathway of galactose metabolism. These genes are organized into an operon containing aga (alpha-galactosidase), galK (galactokinase), and galT (galactose 1-phosphate uridylyltransferase). Northern blotting experiments revealed that this operon was induced by galactosides, such as lactose, melibiose, @sm$ raffinose @/sm$, and, to a lesser extent, galactose. Similarly, alpha-galactosidase activity was higher in lactose-, melibiose-, and @sm$ raffinose @/sm$-grown cells than in galactose-grown cells. No alpha-galactosidase activity was detected in glucose-grown cells. The expression of the aga-galKT operon was modulated by a regulator encoded by the upstream gene galR. The product of galR belongs to the LacI/GalR family of transcriptional regulators. In L. lactis, @gm$ L. raffinolactis @/gm$ GalR acted as a repressor of aga and lowered the enzyme activity by more than 20-fold.

@gm$ Legionella pneumophila @/gm$ infection of mammalian cells was described previously. To examine @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ containing vacuole (LCV) localization of endogenous plasma membrane t-SNARE molecules in RAW 264.7 macrophages, cells were infected with dsRed-expressing wild-type @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ or dotA mutant at an MOI of one for 1 h. Cells were fixed for 5 min in ice-cold methanol, and blocked with 2% BSA in @sm$ PBS @/sm$. Samples were stained with antibodies to Stx2, Stx3, Stx4 or SNAP23 and Alexa-488-labeled secondary antibody (Invitrogen). To examine LCV localization of endogenous Sec22b and VAMP7 in RAW 264.7 macrophages, cells were infected as described earlier. After infection, cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) in @sm$ PBS @/sm$ for 15 min at room temperature. Samples were stained with rabbit or mouse anti-@gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ antibodies to detect the extracellular bacteria before permeabilization. After staining extracellular bacteria, cells were permeabilized with ice-cold methanol, blocked and stained with antibodies to Sec22b or VAMP7, and Alexa-488 anti-rabbit or mouse IgG secondary Abs to detect Sec22b or VAMP7, and Alexa-350 anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG secondary antibodies to identify the extracellular bacteria. To examine endogenous plasma membrane t-SNARE molecules and Sec22b in HEK293-FcgammaRII cells and 3x-FLAG-Sec22b and 3x-FLAG VAMP7 in HEK293-FcgammaRII stable cell lines, @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ was opsonized with rabbit or mouse anti-@gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ antibodies (1:1000), and cells were infected at an MOI of one for 1 h.

@gm$ Listeria monocytogenes @/gm$ (@gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$) is a Gram-positive bacterium that causes infections in humans. In this study, the effects of @sm$ tea tree oil @/sm$ (@sm$ TTO @/sm$) at subinhibitory concentrations on @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ growth and two important exotoxin proteins secreted by @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ were researched. Treatment with half of minimal inhibitory concentration of @sm$ TTO @/sm$ demonstrated very little or no reduction in numbers of viable ATCC 19115 cells. Listeriolysin O (LLO) and p60, were investigated. A listeriolysin assay was used to investigate the hemolytic activities of @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ exposed to @sm$ TTO @/sm$, and the secretion of LLO and p60 was detected by immunoblot analysis. Additionally, real-time RT-PCR was used to analyse the influence of @sm$ TTO @/sm$ on the transcription of LLO and p60 encoded genes hly and iap respectively. According to our experimental results, we propose that @sm$ TTO @/sm$ could be used as a promising natural compound against @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ and its virulence factors. SIGNIFICANCE AND IMPACT OF THE STUDY: This is the first report on the influence of subinhibitory concentrations of @sm$ tea tree oil @/sm$ (@sm$ TTO @/sm$) on the secretion of listeriolysin O (LLO) and p60, the critical virulence factors involved in Listeria pathogenesis. The results showed that @sm$ TTO @/sm$ at 0 25 mg ml-1 reduced the secretion of LLO and p60 to 10 and 34 9% respectively, in addtion, the transcription of hly and iap was reduced to 10 and 4 3% at 0 5 mg ml-1 respectively. We propose that @sm$ TTO @/sm$ could be used as a promising antimicrobial compound and virulence inhibitor against @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$.

@gm$ Listeria monocytogenes @/gm$ can be carried by and infect poultry, although the clinical disease in birds is rare. Escape from macrophage phagocytosis is a key step in pathogenesis for @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$. Therefore, we investigated the infection of the chicken macrophage-like cell line HD11 with 2 strains of L. monocytogenes EGD-e and Scott A. After infection, @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ was quantified by spread plating and HD11 was quantified with trypan blue exclusion stain before enumeration. The standard macrophage killing protocols require washing the cell monolayers 3 times with @sm$ PBS @/sm$, which was found to negatively influence HD11 monolayers. Maximum bacterial densities within macrophages were not different between the 2 Listeria strains. HD11 required more than 11 h to effectively reduce intracellular @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ Scott A, and Scott A was more susceptible to HD11 killing than EGD-e. It appears that Listeria infection initially causes attenuation of HD11 growth, and infected HD11 cells do not begin to lyse until at least 11 h post infection. These results suggest that there are subtle strain to strain differences in response to HD11 macrophage phagocytosis. The long lead-time required for HD11 to kill @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ cells means that there is sufficient time available for chicken macrophages to circulate in the blood and transfer the intracellular Listeria to multiple tissues.

@gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ strains were grown in Middlebrook 7H9-broth (Difco) supplemented with 0.2% glycerol, 0.05% Tween 80, and 10% albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment, or on 7H10 agar (Difco) supplemented with 0.5% glycerol and 10% @sm$ oleic acid @/sm$-albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment. Cultures were supplemented with antibiotics as appropriate. For fractionation of @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ cultures, they were grown in Sauton's defined medium (Teknova).
@gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ transformed with pSMT3-lipY-mspA was cultured in 7H9 medium supplemented with 10% ADS and 0.05% @sm$ Tween-80 @/sm$.

@gm$ Methanobrevibacter @/gm$ spp. are methane producers, and our Spearman's rank correlation data shows positive associations between @gm$ Methanobrevibacter @/gm$ and methane metabolism (rho = 0.88, p < 0.01) (Fig. 4b). Other significant positive correlations (rho >= 0.5, p < 0.01) include pathways involved in transcription and translation, secondary metabolite synthesis, and @sm$ lipid @/sm$ metabolism.

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" based on annotation of the genomes we recently sequenced is shown in Figure 2; a similar pathway is inferred from the M. luminyensis genome. As for other methanogenic archaea, it includes a methyltransferase MttB with a predicted pyrrolysine residue, which is associated with its synthetic machinery. The fact that these strains were isolated from humans might facilitate regulatory compliance. M. luminyensis like M. smithii is susceptible to @sm$ bacitracin @/sm$, metronidazole, ordinazole and squalamine, providing the reassurance of contingency eradication.

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" has a circular genome of 1,931,561 bp, with a G+C content of 41.3%. Despite its close phylogenetic relationship with M. luminyensis, the genome of "Ca. @gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" is 27% smaller and its G+C content is 20% lower than that of M. luminyensis. This suggests a fast genomic reshuffle in one of the two genomes, which may be due to differential adaptation to the gut environment. The "Ca. @gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" genome contains 46 tRNA genes, a single copy of the 16S and 23S rRNA genes, and 2 noncontiguous copies of 5S rRNA genes that were distant from the 23S and 16S rRNA genes. A total of 1,820 protein-coding sequences were predicted. A clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR) region containing 110 spacers was identified using CRISPRfinder, in close association with cas genes. The genome of "Ca. @gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" contains one mcr operon (mcrBDGA) and a mcrC gene distantly located from it. Genes involved in methylotrophic methanogenesis from methanol (mtaABC) and @sm$ methylamine @/sm$ compounds (mtmBC, mtbBC, and mttBC) are also present. The latter are on an 18.7-kb region also containing the genes involved in pyrrolysine biosynthesis. The sequence of "Ca. @gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$" offers a great opportunity to determine the metabolic properties and phenotypic features of this poorly characterized order of methanogens related to Thermoplasmatales, and it will further help to identify the genomic adaptations of methanogens to gut environments.

@gm$ Mycobacterium chelonae @/gm$, one type of NTM, grew in the cultures of this tissue. She was initially treated with kanamycin and ethionamide but eventually underwent subtotal thyroidectomy. The postoperative course was marked by transient hypoparathyroidism. Two years after her surgery, her serum thyroxine, calcium, and @sm$ phosphorus @/sm$ levels normalized.

@gm$ Mycobacterium kansasii @/gm$ is one of the most pathogenic and frequent nontuberculous mycobacteria isolated from humans. Patients with adverse drug reactions, resistant isolates, or suboptimal response require alternative treatment regimens. One hundred forty-eight consecutive clinical isolates of @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ were tested for antimicrobial susceptibilities by the BACTEC 460 system (NCCLS) with two different inoculation protocols, one conventional and one alternative. In the alternative protocol, the inoculum 12B vial was incubated until the growth index was between 250 and 500. Four conventional antimycobacterial drugs (isoniazid, rifampin, streptomycin, and ethambutol) were studied with standard critical concentrations. The in vitro activities of linezolid, telithromycin, clarithromycin, @sm$ levofloxacin @/sm$, and moxifloxacin were determined by measuring radiometric MICs. All isolates tested were identified as @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ genotype I and were resistant to isoniazid at a concentration of 0.4 mug/ml. One hundred twenty isolates (81.1%) were inhibited by 1 microg of isoniazid per ml. A high level of resistance to isoniazid (>10 microg/ml) was observed in six isolates (4.1%). Only five strains (3.4%) were resistant to rifampin (>1 microg/ml). All isolates studied were susceptible to streptomycin and ethambutol. The MICs at which 90% of the isolates were inhibited (in micrograms per milliliter) were as follows: linezolid, 1 (range, < or =0.25 to 2); telithromycin, >16 (range, 4 to >16); clarithromycin, 0.5 (range, < or =0.03 to 1); @sm$ levofloxacin @/sm$, 0.12 (range, 0.12 to 0.25); and moxifloxacin, 0.06 (range, < or =0.06 to 0.12). The susceptibility testing results with both inoculation protocols showed perfect correlation. In conclusion, all @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ isolates showed decreased susceptibility to isoniazid, but resistance to rifampin was infrequent.

@gm$ Mycobacterium marinum @/gm$, a close genetic relative of M. tuberculosis, possesses several advantages as a suitable model for tuberculosis drug screening. However, despite the high genetic similarity, there are some obvious differences in susceptibility to some tuberculosis drugs between these two species, especially for the prodrugs ethionamide and @sm$ isoniazid @/sm$. In this study, we aimed to improve @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ as a model for antituberculosis drug identification by heterologous expression of two common drug activators, EthA and KatG. These two activators were overexpressed in @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$, and the strains were tested against ethionamide, @sm$ isoniazid @/sm$, and a library of established antimycobacterial compounds from TB Alliance to compare drug susceptibility. Both in vitro and in vivo using zebrafish larvae, these genetically modified @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ strains showed significantly higher susceptibility against ethionamide and @sm$ isoniazid @/sm$, which require activation by EthA and KatG. More importantly, a strain overexpressing both ethA and katG was potentially more susceptible to approximately 20% of the antituberculosis hit compounds from the TB Alliance library. Most of these compounds were activated by EthA in @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ Four of these compounds were selected for further analysis, and three of them showed obvious EthA-dependent activity against M. tuberculosis Overall, our developed @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ strains are valuable tools for high-throughput discovery of potential novel antituberculosis prodrugs.

@gm$ Odoribacter @/gm$, on the other hand, has been shown to be crucial for maintaining a healthy gut, and decreased abundance is associated with conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and cystic fibrosis. Specific species of @gm$ Odoribacter @/gm$, such as @gm$ O. splanchnicus @/gm$ and O. laneus, have been found to improve @sm$ glucose @/sm$ tolerance and reduce inflammation by producing outer membrane vesicles and reducing intestinal succinate.

@gm$ Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale @/gm$ (ORT) is an emerging respiratory pathogen of poultry in North America that is causing millions of dollars in economic losses to the poultry industry. @gm$ Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale @/gm$ is associated with airsacculitis, pleuritis, pneumonia, and consolidation of lungs. Little is known about the molecular mechanisms of infection. In this study, the mechanism of iron acquisition by @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ was explored. @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ strains grown under iron deprivation in media containing 200 microM @sm$ 2,2'-dipyridyl @/sm$ did not secrete siderophores as measured by the chrome azurol S (CAS) agar and CAS solution assays. Filter disks impregnated with various protein-bound iron compounds and inorganic iron salts of Fe(III) and Fe(II) placed on iron-restricted agar inoculated with a lawn of @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ supported growth from sheep and porcine hemoglobins, ovotransferrin, Fe(III), and Fe(II), but they did not support growth from bovine transferrin, bovine apo-transferrin, bovine lactoferrin, and hemin. However, both bovine hemoglobin and transferrin supported growth of O. rhinotracheale serotype C. Four immunoreactive proteins involved in iron acquisition were identified in an @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ membrane extract by using mass spectrometry. Furthermore, @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ field strains showed differential sensitivity to @sm$ 2,2'-dipyridyl @/sm$. Of the 72 field strains tested, 22 strains were resistant to the iron chelator at concentrations of 50 microM and 100 microM, suggesting this attribute may be related to disease-producing potential of these strains. This is the first report on the identification of the iron acquisition mechanism of @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$.

@gm$ Oscillibacter @/gm$ (ASVs 003 and 018), Colidextribacter (ASV 009), and Sporanaerobacter (ASV 025) are genera often found to be abundant in communities producing MCCs (Joshi et al., ; Liu et al., ; Zagrodnik et al., ). Only few isolates of these genera have been characterized. @gm$ Oscillibacter valericigenes @/gm$, Colidextribacter massiliensis, and Sporanaerobacter acetigenes are heterotrophs that produce short-chain carboxylates via sugar fermentation (Hernandez-Eugenio, ; Katano et al., ; Ricaboni et al., ), with @gm$ O. valericigenes @/gm$ being described additionally as an n-valerate producer. @gm$ Oscillibacter @/gm$ isolates growing autotrophically on H2/@sm$ CO2 @/sm$ or CO and producing i-valerate have been reported (Park, Yasin, Kim, Park, et al., ; Park, Yasin, Kim, Roh, et al., ). Here, @gm$ Oscillibacter @/gm$ and Colidextribacter correlated to n-caproate formation and not to gas consumption (Figure 4B), suggesting a heterotrophic chain elongation metabolism.

@gm$ Oxalobacter formigenes @/gm$ is a Gram-negative, obligate anaerobic bacterium that commonly inhabits the human gut and degrades oxalate as its major energy and carbon source. A review of colonization frequencies conducted worldwide indicated that 38-77% of a normal population is colonized with @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$. Recent evidence suggests a lack of colonization with @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ may increase the risk for recurrent idiopathic calcium oxalate kidney stone disease. Protection against calcium oxalate stone disease appears to be due to the oxalate degradation that occurs in the gut on low @sm$ calcium @/sm$ diets with a possible further contribution from intestinal oxalate secretion. Despite the role this organism may play in reducing oxalate levels in the host and reducing the risk of calcium oxalate stone disease, there is scant information on how this organism colonizes the host and adapts to new environments. The release of the genome sequence of a Group 1 (OxCC13) and a Group 2 strain (HOxBLS) as part of the Human Microbiome Project has provided a genetic framework for investigating important biological properties of the organism. In this study, we performed mass spectrometry (MS)-based shotgun proteomics of both log and stationary growth phase cultures of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$. These proteomic analyses of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ cultures provide insight into the physiological response associated with nutrient shifts and entry into stationary phase growth.

@gm$ P. acnes @/gm$ was adjusted to a concentration to 2 x 107 CFU/ml using the plate count method, mixed with 5% LY-shelled MBs (8.4 x 106 bubbles/ml, containing 0.75 mg/ml LY) in an Eppendorf tube, and sonicated by the 1-MHz US transducer of the sonoporation system successively at the following acoustic power densities: 1 W/cm2 for 1 min, 2 W/cm2 for 1 min, and 3 W/cm2 for 1 min. The duty cycle was set at 50% and a 0.6-cm-diameter US transducer was used. The change in temperature during US sonication at power densities of 2 and 3 W/cm2 for 1 min at 37  C did not exceed 0.3  C, as measured by a thermometer (Optris LS, Optris, Berlin, Germany). The solution was rested for 30 min, and then samples were diluted 1:104 in @sm$ PBS @/sm$, and 10 muL of each sample was spotted on RCM agar plates. The samples were incubated at 37  C under anaerobic conditions for 3 days, and then the CFU of @gm$ P. acnes @/gm$ were quantified with the aid of image-analysis software (ImageJ, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA).

@gm$ P. fluorescens @/gm$ has been found to have high affinity for the GABA system and binding characteristics that are similar to those of brain receptors. Escherichia coli O157:H7 has a receptor for host-derived @sm$ epinephrine @/sm$/norepinephrine that can be selectively inhibited by adrenergic antagonists.
@gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ O17 @sm$ LPS @/sm$ was hydrolyzed with 2% acetic acid and the core oligosaccharide 1 was isolated by gel chromatography.

@gm$ Parabacteroides @/gm$ species are obligately anaerobic bacteria that degrade @sm$ saccharides @/sm$, forming acetate and succinate as major end products. These observations imply that bacteria assigned to vadinCA02 and Blvii28 decompose peptone and @sm$ saccharides @/sm$ into acetate, respectively, and the acetate thus produced may serve as a fuel for the generation of current for exoelectrogens.

@gm$ Parabacteroides distasonis @/gm$ was obtained from American Type Culture Collection (@gm$ ATCC8503 @/gm$), which was cultured in brain-heart infusion medium (Huankai, China) at 37  C in an anaerobic chamber for 24 h. Bacterial pellets were collected by centrifuging at 8000xg for 10 min at 4  C. After resuspended in sterilized oxygen-free PBS, cultured bacterial cells were administrated orally to mouse at 0.2 mL containing 2 x 108 CFU. The experimental groups were set as follows (n = 6): (1) control; (2) A+TP; (3) antibiotics+TP+@gm$ Parabacteroides distasonis @/gm$ (A + TP + @sm$ Pd @/sm$.); (4) antibitoics + TP + heat-killed @gm$ Parabacteroides distasonis @/gm$ (A + TP + @sm$ Pd @/sm$.-H). After antibiotics treatment for 7 days, A + TP, A + TP + @sm$ Pd @/sm$., and A + TP + @sm$ Pd @/sm$.-H groups were given @gm$ Parabacteroides distasonis @/gm$ transplantation and TP treatment (0.1 mg/kg) daily for 14 days starting from the 8th day. Heat-killed @gm$ Parabacteroides distasonis @/gm$ was treated parallelly.

@gm$ Pediococcus @/gm$ and Weissella in fermented dough were positively correlated with short-chain aldehydes, while Lactobacillus was negatively correlated with them, suggesting that dough fermented by @gm$ Pediococcus @/gm$ or Weissella had more lipid-oxidation products than the dough fermented by Lactobacillus. Similar results were found by Xu et al., who showed that P. pentosaceus participated in the lipid oxidation of broccoli juice fermentation, affected the content of lipid degradation products including volatile aldehydes and alcohols, and enhanced the sensory properties of broccoli juice. Lipid oxidation in wheat flour and microbial metabolism are the main pathways for the formation of alcohols in fermented dough. In the lipid oxidation pathway, the alcohols are generated by lipoxidase-catalyzed oxidation of @sm$ fatty acids @/sm$ and conversion of lipid-oxidizing compounds such as aldehydes to the corresponding alcohols. @gm$ Pediococcus @/gm$ and Weissella in fermented dough were positively correlated with 1-hexanol (green), 1-nonanol (citrus), and 1-heptanol (green), but Lactobacillus was negatively correlated with them. It was indicated that the fermented doughs containing @gm$ Pediococcus @/gm$ and Weissella showed stronger lipid oxidation reactions, which provided more precursors for alcohol conversion and formed more alcohol flavor compounds than Lactobacillus in dough.

@gm$ Peptostreptococcus prevotii @/gm$, Corynebacterium species, and Eubacterium species were recovered only from dentoalveolar infections, while Gemella morbillorum was found more frequently in periodontitis than in the other infections. beta-Lactamase-positive strains were detected only in staphylococci. Ampicillin, ampicillin/sulbactam, cefazolin, cefotaxime, imipenem, erythromycin, clindamycin and @sm$ levofloxacin @/sm$ showed high susceptibility rates (> or = 77%) against viridans streptococci, Peptostreptococcus and Gemella.

@gm$ Phascolarctobacterium succinatutens @/gm$ can grow only on @sm$ succinates @/sm$, whereas Viellonela parvula uses lactate as the main substrate; however, they can get additional energy from @sm$ succinates @/sm$.

@gm$ Phascolarctobacterium succinatutens @/gm$ consumes succinate to produce propionate. This may be the same as Phascolarctobacterium faecium, which lacks fumarate reductase required for succinate production, so it cannot produce succinate and needs to utilize succinate produced by other bacteria to complete its own metabolism. In addition, Clostridia spp. colonization can be promoted by treating drinking water with succinate in mice. This is probably because succinate can consume @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ to promote the colonization of strict anaerobes.

@gm$ Plesiomonas shigelloides @/gm$ is a gram-negative pathogen which can utilize @sm$ heme @/sm$ as an iron source. In previous work, @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ genes which permitted @sm$ heme iron @/sm$ utilization in a laboratory strain of Escherichia coli were isolated. In the present study, the cloned @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ sequences were found to encode ten potential @sm$ heme @/sm$ utilization proteins: HugA, the putative heme receptor; TonB and ExbBD; HugB, the putative periplasmic binding protein; HugCD, the putative inner membrane permease; and the proteins HugW, HugX, and HugZ. Three of the genes, hugA, hugZ, and tonB, contain a Fur box in their putative promoters, indicating that the genes may be iron regulated. When the @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ genes were tested in E. coli K-12 or in a @sm$ heme iron @/sm$ utilization mutant of @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$, hugA, the TonB system genes, and hugW, hugX, or hugZ were required for @sm$ heme iron @/sm$ utilization. When the genes were tested in a hemA entB mutant of E. coli, hugWXZ were not required for utilization of @sm$ heme @/sm$ as a porphyrin source, but their absence resulted in heme toxicity when the strains were grown in media containing @sm$ heme @/sm$ as an iron source. hugA could replace the Vibrio cholerae hutA in a @sm$ heme iron @/sm$ utilization assay, and V. cholerae hutA could complement a @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ @sm$ heme @/sm$ utilization mutant, suggesting that HugA is the heme receptor. Our analyses of the TonB system of @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ indicated that it could function in tonB mutants of both E.

@gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ is a genus of Gram-negative bacteria. They are non-motile, singular cells that thrive in anaerobic growth conditions. They thrive on tissues with decreased oxidation-reduction potentials, such as those with limited blood supply or tissue necrosis. @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ spp. are found in the oral cavity, the gastrointestinal tract and the vagina. They can act as an opportunistic pathogen, often penetrating tissues and establishing an infection at mucosal surfaces causing periodontal and tooth problems such as gingivitis and periodontitis. They predominate in periodontal disease and periodontal abscesses. Some @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ spp. are resistant to Beta-lactam antibiotics. Effective antibiotic treatments are metronidazole, amoxicillin/clavulanate, ureidopenicilins, carbapenems, cephalosporins, clindamycin and chloramphenicol. This patient had extensive spread of the infection due to a late diagnosis of an abscess in the visceral space with a @sm$ penicillin @/sm$ resistant @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ treated with amoxicillin.

@gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ is often associated with the degradation and utilization of starch, proteins, and @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ in the rumen; however, according to, @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ may be involved in fiber degradation in the rumens of sheep. Furthermore, confirmed that @gm$ P. ruminicola @/gm$ contributes to the degradation of the plant cell wall by acting synergistically with cellulolytic bacteria.

@gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ species originate mostly from the oral cavity, are pigmented anaerobic Gram-negative rods and important pathogens in endodontic infections. Anaerobic bacteria are generally considered to be of relatively low virulence and are especially prevalent in infections associated with underlying conditions such as trauma or dental extraction, thus affording an opportunity to penetrate deeper tissues or blood stream and inaugurate infection. The @gm$ P. denticola @/gm$ strain cultured from the patient's blood was sensitive to ampicillin/sulbactam, chloramphenicol, clindamycin, metronidazole, cefmetazole and cefoxitin, but resistant to @sm$ penicillin @/sm$. The @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ species are disseminated by hematogenous route and harbor the brain tissue to form abscess gradually although his blood was sterilized after antibiotic treatment with meropenem. If the diagnosis of @gm$ P. denticola @/gm$ can be obtained before dental extraction, antibiotic treatment may lead to complete resolution.

@gm$ Prevotella copri @/gm$ was cultured in BHI+S liquid media, minimal media plus a carbon source, on BHI agar supplemented with 5% defibrinated horse blood or on YT agar supplemented with 5% defibrinated horse blood and 5% sucrose unless otherwise specified. Cultures were routinely grown and manipulated in an anaerobic chamber (Coy Laboratory Products) with an atmosphere of 20% CO2, 10% H2, and 70% N2 at 37 C. When necessary, antibiotics were added to the medium as follows: 7 microg/ml vancomycin, 100 microg/ml @sm$ ampicillin @/sm$, 200 microg/ml gentamicin, 20 microg/ml erythromycin for selecting P. copri DSM 18205 derived plasmid integrants; 5 microg/ml for other @gm$ P. copri @/gm$ strains, and 20 microg/ml tetracycline for RHA03 and HDE06; 2.5 microg/ml for HDD04, HDE04 and HDD05.

@gm$ Prevotella denticola @/gm$ shared 12.7% of the bacterial consortium producing hydrogen (Figure 9). This species is Gram-negative, obligately anaerobic, rod-shaped, and belongs to the phylum Bacteroides. It has previously been isolated during biohydrogen production. However, it was 0.3% of the community with methanogenic activity, similar to the observations of Mariakakis et al.. The end products of @gm$ Prevotella denticola @/gm$ metabolism during sucrose fermentation are mainly succinic and acetic acids, while smaller quantities of @sm$ lactic acid @/sm$ can also be detected.

@gm$ Prevotella ruminicola @/gm$ plays a prominent role in the breakdown of peptides in the rumen, a process which contributes to excessive ammonia production and inefficient nitrogen retention in ruminants. Various metal ions and chelators were examined to assess how the metal ion-dependent dipeptidase activity of P. ruminicola M384 might be inhibited. Using sonicated extracts, Cu2+, Cr2+ and Hg2+ were most inhibitory, decreasing Ala2 breakdown to 15, 15 and 5% of control activity, whereas Co2+, Mn2+ and Zn2+ stimulated activity by 189, 30 and 26%, respectively. The chelators, EDTA, EGTA, TPEN and @sm$ 1,10-phenanthroline @/sm$, were inhibitory, as were several phenanthroline analogues. Among the stereoisomers of @sm$ 1,10-phenanthroline @/sm$ tested, derivatives methylated on C-2 and C-9 were less effective than the parent molecule, but 3,4,7,8-tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (TMP) was more inhibitory. Titration of the most effective inhibitors showed that EDTA, TPEN and TMP had similar potency and were effective at 0.1 mmol l-1 and above. Thus some metal ions and chelators are potent inhibitors of @gm$ P. ruminicola @/gm$ dipeptidase, although they are unlikely to be sufficiently specific to peptide metabolism to be useful in vivo.

@gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$ strain GU was able to utilize guanidine, agmatine, and urea as sole sources of nitrogen for growth, using citrate and @sm$ acetate @/sm$ as carbon sources (see Table S1 in the supplemental material).

@gm$ R. bromii @/gm$ was grown in specialized @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ (Rum) media (per 50 mL of 2x media): yeast extract (0.25 g), @sm$ NaHCO3 @/sm$ (0.4 g), L-cysteine (0.1 g), (NH4)2SO4 (0.09 g), K2HPO4 (0.045 g), KH2PO4 (0.045 g), NaCl (0.09 g), MgSO4 (0.004 g), CaCl2 (0.009 g), biotin (20 mug), cobalamin (20 mug), p-aminobenzoic acid (60 mug), folic acid (100 mug), pyridoxamine (300 mug), thiamine (100 mug), riboflavin (100 mug), D-pantothenoic acid hemicalcium salt (100 mug), nicotinamide (100 mug), and resazurin (50 mug). Rum media also contained (concentrations per 50 mL of 2x media): hematin (30 muM), L-histidine (3 mM), acetic acid (63.7 mM), propionic acid (17.8 mM), isobutyric acid (5.75 mM), isovaleric acid (1.95 mM), and valeric acid (1.95 mM). Rum media was diluted with an equal volume of a carbohydrate source (0.05% w/v maltose or fructose and glycogen) to culture cells. Co-cultures were made by growing @gm$ R. bromii @/gm$ anaerobically at 37  C overnight and adding B.

@gm$ Roseburia @/gm$  species appear to be able to synthesize nearly all of their own amino acids de novo. This result was somewhat surprising given the high organic @sm$ carbon @/sm$ and nitrogen content of colon luminal contents; however, excreted amino acids have long been thought to be largely bound in proteins and faecal metagenomes reveal significant enrichments in amino acid biosynthetic genes relative to all sequenced bacterial genomes in KEGG. This may indicate either low bioavailability of free amino acids in the colon or fierce competition for amino acids among organisms. All of the  @gm$ Roseburia @/gm$  genomes we examined possessed complete proline biosynthesis pathways from glutamate and arginine biosynthesis pathways via citrulline and aspartate. However, all appeared to lack arginases and, therefore, possessed incomplete arginine cycles. All species of the genus  @gm$ Roseburia @/gm$  encode genes for the biosynthesis of aspartate from oxaloacetate and asparagine from aspartate. The entirety of the lysine biosynthesis pathway converting aspartate to lysine via the dehydrogenase branch is present throughout the genus. However, all three strains of  @gm$ R. inulinivorans @/gm$  contain genes suggesting the presence of an additional alternative succinylation-dependent synthesis branch.

@gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$, which has an important role in the degradation of @sm$ cellulose @/sm$ and hemicellulose, was the most dominant bacterium in the intestine of healthy individuals. To a certain extent, @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ is able to promote cellular uptake of sugar and reduce insulin resistance. However, long-term intake of large amounts of sugar may lead to obesity due to the role of @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ in promoting sugar absorption. In the present study, the relative abundance of @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ in the intestinal tract of patients with T2DM was relatively low, which may have been due to the diet of these patients being hyperlipidic and high in protein. The low-fat diets were energy-balanced and required patients to increase their intake of carbohydrates and dietary fibre, including vegetables, fruits and grains, and control fat intake to <25% of the total daily energy intake. After 6 months of low-fat diet treatment, the relative abundance of @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ in the intestine increased slightly.

@gm$ Ruminococcus obeum @/gm$ produces @sm$ acetate @/sm$, formate, and lactate during growth on glucose on pure culture, but additionally produces propionate during growth on fucose, again using the propanediol utilization pathway.

@gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ strain PS80 was previously shown to survive intracellularly within neutrophils isolated from @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ surgical site infections. We have now demonstrated that PS80 establishes its intracellular survival niche within phagocytes through subversion of the autophagic pathway. Following infection of BMDCs, PS80 prevented the constitutive degradation of autophagosomes by lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of LC3-II. In contrast, @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ strain SH1000 did not interfere with the homeostatic turnover of the autophagic machinery. Furthermore, BMDCs that had been treated with @sm$ MDC @/sm$ (which accumulates in the autophagosome) postinfection showed colocalization between the autophagosome and PS80 but not SH1000. In addition, macrophages that were stably transfected with GFP-LC3 also demonstrated colocalization of PS80 with LC3-II punctae, indicating the interaction of the bacterium with autophagosomes. Upon invasion of nonprofessional phagocytes, @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ was shown to subvert autophagy, enabling replication within the autophagosome and subsequent lysis of the host cell. Consistent with this, we have demonstrated that the cytotoxic effects exerted by @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ strain PS80 on BMDCs are associated with the subversion of autophagy.

@gm$ S. carnosus @/gm$ TM300 exhibited the smallest genome (2,566,424 bp), while strain Mu2 possessed the largest (2,927,171 bp). Both of the S. equorum strains possessed genomes that were larger in size than the average of the 10 strains. The CNS strains displayed an average @sm$ G+C @/sm$ content of 33.29% and @gm$ S. carnosus @/gm$ showed the highest @sm$ G+C @/sm$ content.

@gm$ S. flexneri @/gm$ cultures were grown 16 h in conical polypropylene tubes containing 5 ml of M9-Tris (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8, 50 mM KCl, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 10 mM CaCl2, 100 mM MgSO4) salts supplemented with a mix of nutrients (45 mug/ml L-methionine, 20 mug/ml @sm$ L-tryptophan @/sm$, 12.5 mug/ml nicotinic acid, 10 mug/ml vitamin B1, 1% glucose, 0.5% casein hydrolysate, 0.1% fatty acid-free BSA) -M9-Tris-CAA- at 37  C with shaking at 200 rpm. This optimized reaction solution was based on an optimized minimal growth medium for Shigella and a buffer that permits septin assembly into filaments/bundles. The following day, bacterial cultures were diluted in 10 ml of fresh prewarmed M9-Tris-CAA (1:100 v/v) in conical polypropylene tubes and cultured until an OD600 of 0.6. 1.2 ml of bacterial cultures were centrifuged in Low Protein Binding tubes (ThermoFisher Scientific) at 800 x g for 2 min at RT and the supernatant was removed. To measure binding of septins to @gm$ S. flexneri @/gm$, bacterial pellets were resuspended in 100 mul of in vitro reconstitution solution [M9-Tris-CAA supplemented with 240 nM of septin complex SEPT7/msGFP-SEPT6/SEPT2 and 1 mM dithiothreitol (DTT)].

@gm$ S. parasanguinis @/gm$ and A. actinomycetemcomitans infection of Drosophila melanogaster flies was performed as previously described. Briefly, Drosophila flies were maintained on Jazz-Mix Drosophila food (Fisher). To infect flies, @gm$ S. parasanguinis @/gm$ was grown to an A470 of 2.0 and 1.5 ml of the culture was harvested. A. actinomycetemcomitans was grown to an A470 of 0.8 and 4 ml of the culture was harvested. The harvested cell pellets of the two species were re-suspended respectively or mixed together in 100 mul sterile 5% sucrose to desirable cell density (109~1010 CFU/mL). The re-suspended cells were spotted onto a sterile 21-mm filter paper disc (Whatman) that was placed on the surface of 5 ml of solidified 5% sucrose agar in a plastic vial (FlyBase). Male Drosophila flies (1 to 3 days old) were treated with antibiotics (erythromycin, @sm$ vancomycin @/sm$, and ampicillin at 50 mug/ml) for 3 days and transferred to fresh medium for 3 days to remove residual antibiotics. All the flies were starved for 4 h before being added to vials (10 flies per vial). To determine the number of viable bacterial cells inside the flies, the surface of the flies were sterilized by treating with 70% ethanol for 30s and washed 3 times with sterile PBS. Flies were crushed with tips in an Eppendorf tube with 100 mul of saline. Serial dilutions of the homogenate were spread on TSBYE agar plates. Colonies of @gm$ S. parasanguinis @/gm$ appeared after overnight incubation at 37 C. Colonies of A. actinomycetemcomitans were visible after 2 days incubation at 37 C. @sm$ Vancomycin @/sm$ (5mug/ml) was added to TSBYE agar plate to selectively grow A.
@gm$ S. pasteurianus @/gm$ was injected intraperitoneally into mice (10 per group) at a dose of 1.5 x 108 cfu per mouse. As a negative control, 5 mice were infected with @sm$ PBS @/sm$.
@gm$ S. pneumoniae @/gm$ strains were grown as static cultures at 37  C in a casein hydrolysate-based liquid medium (AGCH) containing 0.2% yeast extract and 0.3% sucrose (@sm$ C @/sm$ + Y).

@gm$ S. suis @/gm$ infection is of major economic and veterinary importance in the farming world, and should now be on the list of differential diagnoses when clinicians encounter patients with unexplained sepsis who have a history of exposure to pigs. Eradication of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ from the pig population is not currently feasible, even though @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ appears fully sensitive to @sm$ penicillin @/sm$. Antibiotic treatment in pigs is rarely successful, probably because of poor antibiotic penetration of the porcine tonsillar tissues, which act as a source of infection . Resistance to macrolides, lincosamides, and tetracycline is common, limiting efforts to clear tonsillar carriage. Development of a vaccine targeted against the most virulent or prevalent strains might be one possible way to prevent colonisation of female pigs and to protect those working with pigs . Better characterisation of activities that increase risk of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ acquisition and faster diagnostic tests to identify outbreaks in pigs will lead to adaptation of practices that incur unnecessary exposure to infected carcasses.

@gm$ S. variabile @/gm$, A. muciniphila, Escherichia sp., and I. bartlettii respectively had 4, 2, 1 and 1 double lethal pairs involving 2 exchange reactions. Simultaneous inhibition of NMN exchange and @sm$ nicotinate @/sm$, or L-tyrosine coupled with glycyl-L-tyrosine, or phosphate paired with glycerol 3-phosphate and uracil paired with succinate became lethal in @gm$ S. variabile @/gm$. In A. muciniphila inhibiting the exchange of L-asparagine together with glycyl-L-asparagine or thiamin led to lethality. Notably, simultaneous blocking of exchange of oxygen with ferric iron (Fe3+) or @sm$ nicotinate @/sm$, respectively prevented growth in Escherichia sp.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ (S. Choleraesuis) is a swine-adapted serovar associated to invasive infections in humans. In Brazil, data of strains of this serovar are scarce. In the present study, six S. Choleraesuis strains of animal (n = 5) and human (n = 1) origin from Brazil were screened for phenotypic antimicrobial resistance using disk-diffusion assay and using whole-genome sequencing data to search for antimicrobial resistance genes, plasmids, prophages, and @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ pathogenicity islands (SPIs). Its genetic relatedness was evaluated by MLST and SNP analysis. A single isolate from swine gallbladder harbored the colistin resistance gene mcr-1.1 into a IncX4 plasmid. In the six strains analyzed, resistance was found to tetracycline, @sm$ nalidixic acid @/sm$, ciprofloxacin, ampicillin, piperacillin, streptomycin, cefazoline, gentamycin, sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, and choloramphenicol, along with resistance genes aac(6')-Iaa, aac(3)-IV, aph(3'')-Ib, aph(6)-Id, aph(4)-Ia, aadA1, aph(3')-IIa, blaTEM-1A, floR, sul1, sul2, tet(B), drfA1, erm(B), mph(B), lnu(G), qacE, and gyrA point mutation Serine83   Tyrosine and parC Threonine57   Serine.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$, a host-adapted pathogen of swine, usually causes septicemia. Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) strains have been widely studied in recent years for their probiotic properties. In this study, a mouse infection model first screened for potential agents against infection, then a pig infection model evaluated effects of LAB strains and herbal plants against infection. Scutellariae radix (SR) and Gardeniae fructus (GF) showed abilities to reduce bacteria shedding and suppressing serum level of TNF- alpha induced by infection in swine. Bioactivities of SR and GF were enhanced by combining with LAB strains, which alone could speed up the bacteria elimination time in feces and boost immunity of infected pigs. Baicalein and @sm$ genipin @/sm$ exhibited stronger cytotoxicity than baicalin and geniposide did, as well as prevent @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ from invading macrophages.

@gm$ Salmonella paratyphi-B @/gm$ CMCC 50094, Salmonella paratyphi-A CMCC 50093, Salmonella enterica subsp. arizonae CMCC(@sm$ B) @/sm$47001, Salmonella typhimurium CMCC 50015 and Escherichia coli DH5alpha were purchased from the National Center for Medical Culture Collections (CMCC).

@gm$ Shigella @/gm$ does not make flagella and is nonmotile. The plaque assay measures cell-to-cell spread of intracellular @gm$ Shigella @/gm$, and so it suggested that @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ must express some other means of motility while in the mammalian cytoplasm. More than 20 years earlier, Hidemasa Ogawa at the National Institute of Health in Tokyo, Japan, used phase-contrast video microscopy to show that intracellular @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ do, in fact, display rapid random movements in the host cell cytoplasm. Ogawa noted, "When virulent bacilli entered into the tissue cells, they exhibited an unexpected vigorous movement. This movement was apparently random, not directional, and independent of the movement of intracellular organelle...". This movement frequently led to formation of protrusions of the host cytoplasm. The observation that @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ inhibited intracellular bacterial movement also suggested the role of a @gm$ Shigella @/gm$-specific factor.

@gm$ Streptococcus @/gm$ spp. were the only bacteria in these microbial communities that encoded all of the enzymes in the 2,3-butanedione pathway. budA was not present in P. aeruginosa (in these CF metagenomes from San Diego nor in publically available fully sequenced genomes, and budC was not present in the highly abundant R. mucilaginosa. However, R. mucilaginosa and/or P. aeruginosa have the ability to consume 2,3-butanedione, as they encode acoA and acoB, the genes whose products catabolize @sm$ acetoin @/sm$ for use in central metabolism.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is an important swine pathogen and an emergent zoonotic pathogen. Excessive inflammation caused by @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ is responsible for early high mortality in septic shock-like syndrome cases. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) may contribute to regulating inflammatory processes. This study shows that mouse infection by @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ is accompanied by an increase of arachidonic acid, a proinflammatory omega-6 (omega-6) PUFA, and by a decrease of docosahexaenoic acid, an anti-inflammatory omega-3 PUFA. Macrophages infected with @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ showed activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways and cyclooxygenase-2 upregulation. Fenretinide, a synthetic @sm$ vitamin A @/sm$ analog, reduced in vitro expression of inflammatory mediators. Pretreatment of mice with fenretinide significantly improved their survival by reducing systemic proinflammatory cytokines during the acute phase of an S. suis infection. These findings indicate a beneficial effect of fenretinide in diminishing the expression of inflammation and improving survival during an acute infection by a virulent @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ strain.

@gm$ Streptococcus thermophilus @/gm$ is stimulated by the contribution of amino acids and small peptides coming from the proteolytic activity of Lactobacillus bulgaricus. The stimulation of Lactobacillus bulgaricus is allotted to formic acid, pyruvic acid, and carbon dioxide produced by @gm$ Streptococcus thermophilus @/gm$. Both microbial species are homofermentative bacteria, which produce lactic acid starting from @sm$ lactose @/sm$ milk.

@gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$ species produce butyrate and @sm$ lactate @/sm$ as major products of glucose and some other carbohydrates. @gm$ Subdoligranulum variabile @/gm$ is a known butyrate producer living in human intestine and represents 1% of total @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$ population. @gm$ Subdoligranulum variabile @/gm$ also produces small amounts of acetate and succinate in addition to its main products.
@gm$ Subdoligranulum variabile @/gm$, the only specie of this genus, which is more abundant in patients with MetS, was shown to produce mainly butyrate and lactate from @sm$ glucose @/sm$.

@gm$ T. denticola @/gm$ cells, wild type or mutant (Tdm101, Tdm109, Tdm111), were grown in TYGVS broth overnight at 37 C in a Coy anaerobic chamber (5% CO2, 10% H2, 85% N2). Cell concentrations in the cultures were measured by their optical density at 620nm and equivalent numbers of cells (equal to the number of cells in 1 mL of a culture at OD620nm) were removed from each sample into centrifuge tubes. The cells were pelleted by centrifugation, resuspended in 1 mL PBS, centrifuged again and the final cell pellet was resuspended in 1 mL PBS. A 0.5 mL aliquot was removed from each sample into a new tube, 10 muL of freshly prepared L-cysteine HCl (100 mM) was added and the samples were covered with parafilm and incubated aerobically for 2 hr in a water bath at 37 C. Then the @sm$ H2S @/sm$ produced by the various @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$ strains was assayed as described by Siegel with some modifications. Briefly, 50 muL of 0.02 M N,N-dimethyl-p-phenylenediamine sulfate in 7.2 N HCl and 50 muL of 0.3 M FeCl3 in 1.2 N HCl were added sequentially to each tube. After color development for 30 min at room temperature, the samples were centrifuged briefly and the absorbance of each supernatant was measured at 620 nm. The sulfide concentration was determined from a standard curve with Na2S as the substrate. The three @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$ mutants and wild type spirochetes were grown together and assessed for @sm$ H2S @/sm$ production on four different days. The data @sm$ H2S @/sm$ concentrations are expressed as means +- standard deviations.
