@gm$ T. forsythia @/gm$ was cultured by adding 10 mug/mL N-acetylmuraminic acid (Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) to the above medium. T. denticola was added to the heart infusion broth with 1.0% trypticase peptone, 0.25% yeast extract, 0.05% sodium thioglycollate, 0.1% l-cysteine HCl-H2O, 0.025% l-asparagine, 0.2% d-glucose, 0.0001% resazurin, 0.20025% @sm$ sodium bicarbonate @/sm$, 2% rabbit serum, and 2% thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)/volatile fatty acid solution (0.03% TPP, 0.05% isobutyric acid, 0.05% 2-methylbutyric acid, 0.05% isovaleric acid, 0.05% valeric acid, and 0.098 N sodium hydroxide).

@gm$ Tannerella @/gm$ and Streptococcus in the subgingival plaque. The anaerobic @gm$ Tannerella @/gm$ requires a much lower pO2 than Streptococcus and is proteolytic, while Streptococcus is a saccharolytic colonizer of the tooth surface that uses sugars as its primary source of carbon and is @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ tolerant. This continuous nutritional, metabolite (e.g. hydrogen peroxide), and @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ gradient between the supragingval and the subgingival biofilms, along with differential exposure to host factors in saliva, is reflected through the gradual drop of the abundance of @gm$ Tannerella @/gm$ as the streptococci increase (Figure S4).

@gm$ Treponema pallidum @/gm$, although sensitive to atmospheric concentrations of O2, requires low levels of O2 for optimal survival and metabolic activity. The addition of 0.0125-0.2 mg/ml of sodium metabisulfite to a basal medium consisting of Eagle's minimal essential medium and 50% fresh, heat-inactivated normal rabbit serum was found to have an effect similar to that of @sm$ dithiothreitol @/sm$ in extending the survival of @gm$ T. pallidum @/gm$ (Nichols strain) under 3% O2. Detailed analysis of the effect of O2 tension revealed that 50% motility was retained longest at atmospheric O2 concentrations of 1-5%, whether or not @sm$ dithiothreitol @/sm$ or sodium metabisulfite were present. Concentrations of O2 of 3-10% were optimal for nucleic acid synthesis, as determined by [3H]adenine incorporation during the first 24 hr of incubation. Sodium metabisulfite was less effective than @sm$ dithiothreitol @/sm$ in stimulating nucleic acid synthesis. Neither sodium metabisulfite nor @sm$ dithiothreitol @/sm$ at their effective concentrations had any effect on levels of dissolved O2. During incubation under 3% O2, motility was maintained at > 50% for 15 days and virulence for at least 13 days by dilution of the treponemal suspensions every three days with fresh medium containing sodium metabisulfite. The optimal retention of motility and nucleic acid synthesis under microaerobic conditions in the absence of reducing compounds provides further evidence that @gm$ T. pallidum @/gm$ is a microaerophilic organism.

@gm$ Treponema pallidum @/gm$, an obligate parasite of humans and the causative agent of syphilis, has evolved the capacity to exploit host-derived metabolites for its survival. Flavin-containing compounds are essential cofactors that are required for metabolic processes in all living organisms, and riboflavin is a direct precursor of the cofactors FMN and @sm$ FAD @/sm$. Unlike many pathogenic bacteria, @gm$ Treponema pallidum @/gm$ cannot synthesize riboflavin; we recently described a flavin-uptake mechanism composed of an ABC-type transporter. However, there is a paucity of information about flavin utilization in bacterial periplasms. Using a discovery-driven approach, we have identified the TP0796 lipoprotein as a previously uncharacterized Mg(2+)-dependent FAD pyrophosphatase within the ApbE superfamily. TP0796 probably plays a central role in flavin turnover by hydrolyzing exogenously acquired @sm$ FAD @/sm$, yielding AMP and FMN. Biochemical and structural investigations revealed that the enzyme has a unique bimetal Mg(2+) catalytic center. Furthermore, the pyrophosphatase activity is product-inhibited by AMP, indicating a possible role for this molecule in modulating FMN and @sm$ FAD @/sm$ levels in the treponemal periplasm.

@gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is sensitive to most antibiotics in vitro, except for colistin; antibiotics that are effective against @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ in vitro are third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or ceftazidime), piperacillin-tazobactam, carbapenems (imipenem or meropenem), tetracyclines (doxycycline or tetracycline), aminoglycoside (gentamicin or amikacin), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, or @sm$ moxifloxacin @/sm$), and sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprime. In most in vitro or in vivo mouse model experiments on antibiotic susceptibility, tetracyclines are reported to have significantly higher efficacy than penicillin or cephalosporins. This has been attributed to the fact that the tetracycline class of antibiotics achieves better penetration into tissues with poor perfusion when V. vulnificus infection occurs, and has inhibitory effects against the synthesis of proteins, such as various toxins and enzymes produced by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$.

@gm$ Veillonella @/gm$ species, which metabolize lactate, were also less predominant in later plaque (Figure 8), in accordance with several previous studies, indicating that elevated levels of @gm$ Veillonella @/gm$ were associated with higher acid production within plaque. The developing plaque in CF subjects likely had a lower acidogenic potential than that in CE subjects during the later stage of the current study period. Because formation, succession, and removal of dental plaque on the tooth surface occur repeatedly, the differences observed in the assembly process may be involved in the susceptibility to dental caries. Further evaluation of the microbiota shift upon @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ ingestion and pH measurement within dental plaque would be helpful to clarify their contribution to the progression of dental caries.

@gm$ Vibrio parahaemolyticus @/gm$ is a common marine food-borne enteropathogen. In this study, we examined the antioxidative activity, growth, biofilm formation, and cell mobility of an oxyR deletion mutant and its genetically complementary strain of @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$. oxyR is the regulator of catalase and ahpC genes. Protection against extrinsic H2O2 and against the organic peroxides cumene hydroperoxide and tert-butyl hydroperoxide was weaker in the deletion mutant than in its parent strain. Expression of the major functional antioxidative genes, ahpC1 and VPA1418, was markedly decreased in the oxyR mutant. Growth of this mutant on agar medium was significantly inhibited by autoclaved 0.25% @sm$ glucose @/sm$ and by 0.25% dipotassium hydrogen phosphate, 0.5% monosaccharides (@sm$ glucose @/sm$, galactose, xylose, and arabinose), or 114.8 mM phosphates. The inhibition of the growth of this oxyR mutant by extrinsic peroxides, autoclaved sugars, and phosphates was eliminated by the complementary oxyR gene or by the addition of catalase to the autoclaved medium, while no inhibition of growth was observed when filter-sterilized sugars were used. The formation of biofilm and swimming mobility were significantly inhibited in the oxyR mutant relative to that in the wild-type strain. This investigation demonstrates the antioxidative function of oxyR in @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ and its possible roles in biofilm formation, cell mobility, and the protection of growth in heated rich medium.

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ is a rod shape, Gram-negative bacterium and is a member of family Vibrionaceae. Worldwide this lethal pathogen causes seafood-related deaths in humans. @gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ causes sepsis greater than 50% mortality rate, necrotizing fasciitis, gastroenteritis, skin and soft tissue infection, wound infection, peritonitis, meningitis, pneumonia, keratitis, and arthritis. Chronic liver disease, kidney disease, hemochromatosis, immune deficiency and heart diseases are the predominant risk factors for @gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$. Pili, Cytotoxin, hydrolytic enzyme, flagella, and capsule polysaccharide are the feasible virulent determinant for @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$. Based on pathogenicity @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is categorized into three biotypes. Type 1 and type 3 cause diseases in humans, while biotype 2 causes diseases in eel and fishes. The majority of microorganisms that cause infections are resistant to antibiotics. Due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ has developed resistance to many antibiotics so curing is dramatically a challenge. Pan et al. stated that @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ showed resistant to cefazolin, streptomycin, tetracycline, aztreonam, tobramycin, cefepime and gentamycin. The mechanism by which @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ interact with different factors of host defense was investigated by researchers to understand its pathogenicity better. The first host defense encounter by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is the highly acidic environment of the stomach. To neutralize low-pH of the environment Gram-negative bacteria catabolize @sm$ amino acids @/sm$ to amines and carbon dioxide, to encounter acidic environment @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ utilize the same strategy.

@gm$ Y      . enterocolitica @/gm$ biotype 1A isolates were selected from the strain collection of the National Reference Centre for Salmonella and other enteric pathogens, Robert Koch Institute, Wernigerode, Germany. All strains were routinely cultured in Luria-Bertani (LB) broth. To avoid possible stimulation of virulence gene expression, all strains were cultured at 27 C for standard procedures except for infection studies. Where appropriate, antibiotics were supplemented as follows: kanamycin at 30 mug/mL, @sm$ streptomycin @/sm$ at 30 mug/mL.

@gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ and Y. pestis possess two pairs of convergently transcribed luxI/R orthologs (ypsI/R, ytbI/R and ypeI/R and yepI/R, respectively). Both species produce the same four major AHLs, namely N-(3-oxohexanoyl) homoserine lactone (3-oxo-C6-HSL), N-hexanoylhomoserine lactone (C6-HSL), N-octanoylhomoserine lactone (C8-HSL), and N-(3-oxooctananoyl) homoserine lactone (@sm$ 3-oxo-C8-HSL @/sm$)).

@gm$ Yersinia pestis @/gm$, the causative agent of the bubonic plague, is a predominately extracellular pathogen with the ability to survive and replicate intracellularly. A previous study has shown that a novel rip (required for intracellular proliferation) operon (ripA, ripB and ripC) is essential for replication and survival of @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ in postactivated macrophages, by playing a role in lowering macrophage-produced nitric oxide (NO) levels. A bioinformatics analysis indicates that the rip operon is conserved among a distally related subset of macrophage-residing pathogens, including Burkholderia and Salmonella species, and suggests that this previously uncharacterized pathway is also required for intracellular survival of these pathogens. The focus of this study is ripA, which encodes for a protein highly homologous to 4-hydroxybutyrate-CoA transferase; however, biochemical analysis suggests that RipA functions as a butyryl-CoA transferase. The 1.9 A X-ray crystal structure reveals that RipA belongs to the class of Family I CoA transferases and exhibits a unique tetrameric state. Molecular dynamics simulations are consistent with RipA tetramer formation and suggest a possible gating mechanism for @sm$ CoA @/sm$ binding mediated by Val227. Together, our structural characterization and molecular dynamic simulations offer insights into acyl-CoA specificity within the active site binding pocket, and support biochemical results that RipA is a butyryl-CoA transferase. We hypothesize that the end product of the rip operon is butyrate, a known anti-inflammatory, which has been shown to lower NO levels in macrophages. Thus, the results of this molecular study of @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ RipA provide a structural platform for rational inhibitor design, which may lead to a greater understanding of the role of RipA in this unique virulence pathway.

@gm$ Yersinia pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ has a broad host range and is capable of infecting a wide variety of animals, including humans. The disease caused by this bacterium may vary from a mild enteritis to extra-intestinal symptoms and septicemia. The severity of symptoms differs among strains, and @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ has been subdivided into genetic groups designated G1-G6, dependent on the presence of the virulence plasmid (pYV), the high pathogenicity island (HPI), and the subtype of the @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$-derived mitogen (YPM). G4 isolates cannot ferment @sm$ melibiose @/sm$ (@sm$ melibiose @/sm$-negative) and are not pathogenic: they express YPMb and lack the pYV and HPI. G5 isolates are also @sm$ melibiose @/sm$-negative and of low pathogenicity: they express YPMc, and contain the pYV as well as a truncated HPI (R-HPI). G1-G3 and G6 isolates are @sm$ melibiose @/sm$-positive and fully pathogenic: they contain the pYV, and variably harbour the HPI and YPMa. Although human cases of @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ infections are usually sporadic, several outbreaks have recently been reported from Finland and Russia. Humans are not the primary host for @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$. These bacteria can be isolated from a wide variety of domestic and wild animals, as well as from the environment in Japan and occasionally in Europe. @gm$ Yersinia pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ has also been subdivided on the basis of variable lipopolysaccharide O-side chain into 15 O-serotypes (O:1-O:15) and ten subtypes (O:1a-c, O:2a-c, O:4a-b and O:5a-b).

@gm$ canis @/gm$ (serum agglutination test <50 IU/mL) and bacteriologic culture of a urine sample were negative. Despite treatment with @sm$ doxycycline @/sm$ (10 mg/kg 1x/d for 14 days starting 3 days after neuter), the dog did not recuperate and because of the poor prognosis was euthanized.

@gm$ jejuni @/gm$ cannot ferment carbohydrates and depends mainly on amino acids and some SCFAs to proliferate in the avian gut. C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ utilizes @sm$ acetate @/sm$, lactate, fumarate, succinate, and malate as part of its citric acid cycle to satisfy its energy needs. The ability of C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ to use SCFAs might explain the ineffectiveness of organic acid supplementation such as lactic acid, formic acid, and acetic acid in the presented studies. Butyrate supplementation might be the organic acid of choice to control C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$.

@gm$ jejuni @/gm$ was associated with important alteration of gut microbial predicted metabolism and functions. It could partly be explained by the microbiota functional enrichment in pathways involved in the biosynthesis of antimicrobial synthesis and bacteriocin (i.e. bacterial toxins) as previously observed in suckling piglets supplemented with benzoic acid and essential oils (Zhai et al., ). Besides support of gut barrier integrity, immune activation and nutrient competition, secretion of antimicrobial products allow the gut microbiota with colonization resistance (Ducarmon et al., ). Altogether, these mechanisms might explain both the resistance to C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ development, the associated decrease of enteropathogens (Sassone-Corsi et al., ) and the microbiota structure specificity induced by the carvacrol-based product in chickens inoculated with C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$. In inoculated chickens, the carvacrol-based product down-regulated the predicted degradation pathways of lysine, valine, leucine and @sm$ isoleucine @/sm$ while up-regulated biosynthesis of lysine, phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. In accordance, Li et al. observed in piglets group supplemented with a mix of carvacrol and thymol, an increased concentration of several amino acids such as valine, @sm$ isoleucine @/sm$ and alanine (Li et al., ).

@gm$ jejuni @/gm$. Firstly, irrespective of the selective agent, the resistant clones obtained in vitro exhibited dual resistance to both agents (Table 2 ). Similar cross-resistance was previously reported in E. coli and Salmonella , which usually emerged under FFC selection. Combined resistance to CHL and FFC might be conferred by specific resistance genes, such as floR , fexA , fexB , pexA  and cfr . Secondly, both the CHL- (MICCHL>=64 microg/mL) and FFC-selected (MICFFC>=32 microg/mL) resistant strains contained the G2073A mutation in three copies of the 23S rRNA gene (Table 2 ), which is the first reported mutation associated with amphenicol resistance in Campylobacter spp. The G2057A mutation of the E. coli 23S rRNA gene (corresponding to position 2073 in the 23S rRNA gene of Campylobacter spp.) was previously reported to confer resistance to chloramphenicol and intermediate-level resistance to 14-nunbered-ring macrolides. Indeed, the CHL- and FFC-selected C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ mutants carrying the G2073A mutation also showed elevated MICs to @sm$ erythromycin @/sm$ (8 microg/mL), consistent with the finding in E. coli that the G2057A conferred cross resistance to chloramphenicol and @sm$ erythromycin @/sm$. Interestingly in propionibacteria, Mycoplasma hominis , and Francisella tularensis , the same G2057A mutation was associated with @sm$ erythromycin @/sm$ resistance, but not with resistance to 16-membered macrolides or chloramphenicol.
@gm$ pasteurianus @/gm$ se obtuvo sensibilidad a penicilina, clindamicina, eritromicina, levofloxacino y @sm$ vancomicina @/sm$, mientras que a A.

@sm$ Acarbose @/sm$ is a clinically used drug produced by Actinoplanes sp. and is composed of acarviosin bound to maltose. @sm$ Acarbose @/sm$ exerts its anti-diabetic effect by inhibiting alpha-glucosidases and alpha-amylases, which are required for the breakdown of starch into glucose, resulting in reduced uptake of glucose into the bloodstream and prevention of postprandial hyperglycemia. Since @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ hinders the absorption of glucose in the upper gastrointestinal tract, an increased concentration of oligosaccharides transits to the colon where fermentation by gut bacteria can lead to unwanted gastrointestinal side effects. In addition, @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ can directly affect the microbiota through inhibition of bacterial amylases. Santilli et al. showed that @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ can inhibit the growth of B. thetaiotaomicron and Bacteroides fragilis on potato starch. This growth phenotype was postulated to be a result of SusG inhibition, as growth of the two bacteria on glucose was not affected by @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ treatment. In contrast, the growth of R. bromii on starch was not affected by @sm$ acarbose @/sm$. 16S rRNA gene sequencing has been used to identify changes to the gut microbiota structure from @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ treatment, in conjunction with measures of metabolites and physiological markers of type 2 diabetes (T2D) or other metabolic diseases. Restructuring of the gut microbiota in T2D by @sm$ acarbose @/sm$ is often accompanied by a decrease in overall bacterial diversity,- despite an increase in Lactobacillus and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ taxa in a variety of animal models and patient populations.- There is generally also an increase in SCFA production, particularly of butyrate,- which could result from the enrichment of butyrate-producing lactobacilli and bifidobacteria.

@sm$ Acetate @/sm$ can be synthesized through two different pathways. Firstly, acetyl-CoA can be produced by decarboxylation of pyruvate, then, acetyl-CoA is hydrolyzed to @sm$ acetate @/sm$ by an acetyl-CoA hydrolase. Most of the @sm$ acetate @/sm$ is produced by enteric bacteria, including Prevotella spp., Ruminococcus spp., Bifidobacterium spp., Bacteroides spp., Clostridium spp., Streptococcus spp., A. muciniphila, and @gm$ B. hydrogenotrophica @/gm$, using this pathway. Secondly, the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway can be also used by acetogenic bacteria to form @sm$ acetate @/sm$ from acetyl-CoA. Here, the reduction of carbon dioxide generates carbon monoxide, which reacts with a coenzyme A molecule and a methyl group to produce acetyl-CoA. At the same time, acetyl-CoA is the substrate to obtain @sm$ acetate @/sm$.

@sm$ Acetate @/sm$, propionate, and butyrate are the main components in SCFAs, of which @sm$ acetate @/sm$ can be produced through the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway by @gm$ Blautia hydrogenotrophica @/gm$, and propionate is generated by Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes through the succinate and lactate pathway, and the remaining butyrate being produced by several Firmicutes through Acetyl-CoA.

@sm$ Alcohol @/sm$ consumption, particularly chronic and moderate to heavy @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ intake, has been recognized as an important risk factor for CRC, and is closely related to the metastasis and poor prognosis in CRC patients. The metabolism of @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ is actively modulated by the gut microbiota, which regulates ethanol conversion into its metabolites that exert carcinogenic effects in the colon. For example, Enterobacteriaceae Ruminococcus, and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ mediate the production of carcinogenic acetaldehyde from ethanol, which accumulates in the colon and greatly contribute to CRC development as ethanol consumption increases. Furthermore, the gut microbiota in alcoholic people is diminished in dominant obligate anaerobes (such as Bacteroides and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$) and enriched in Streptococcus, which in turn contribute to CRC development according to their cancer-inhibiting or -promoting functions as discussed in Section 3.

@sm$ Amino glycoside @/sm$ resistance genes strA, strB, aadA and aacA4 (83.3-100%), and integron genes IntI and 3'-CS (97.5-100%) were widely observed among the strains harvested from the 0.1 to 50 mg L-1 STM exposures (Table 3; Additional file 1: Table S7), whereas STM resistance genes strA and strB (50.0%) and integron genes IntI (30%) and 3'-CS (70%) were also observed in the exposure without STM. In addition, other @sm$ amino glycoside @/sm$ genes including aac(3)-II, aphA1, aphA2, aadE and aadB, were not notably distributed (0-17.5%) among the various STM exposures. In particular, the aadE gene (confers resistance to STM and spectinomycin) was observed only in Lactococcus chungangensis (1-50 mg L-1), whereas none of the STM resistant strains contained the aac(3)-II gene (confers resistance to gentamycin, tobramycin and kanamycin). In this study, Lactococcus chungangensis and Stenotrophomonas acidaminiphila exhibited the maximum number of @sm$ amino glycoside @/sm$ resistance genes (six), whereas Paracoccus yeei, @gm$ Lactococcus raffinolactis @/gm$, Pseudoxanthomonas mexicana and Chryseobacterium lactis contained five @sm$ amino glycoside @/sm$ resistance genes (Additional file 1: Fig. S4) and Aeromonas veronii and Comamonas testosteroni contained three @sm$ amino glycoside @/sm$ resistance genes.
@sm$ Aminoglycosides @/sm$ treatment in healthy volunteers has been associated with a decrease in Ruminococcaceae, Lachnospiraceae, Faecalibacterium spp. and @gm$ Blautia @/gm$ spp..

@sm$ Amoxycillin @/sm$, oxytetracycline and ceftriaxone are the most commonly used antimicrobials in poultry, followed by ofloxacin and norfloxacin in China. Inclusion in feed is the most common route of administration of antimicrobials in poultry, mainly to prevent necrotic enteritis caused by @gm$ Clostridium perfringens @/gm$ and coccidiosis.

@sm$ Anthocyanins @/sm$, a particular class of flavonoids, are enriched in fruits and vegetables, and could be metabolized by the intestinal microbiota. Moreover, @sm$ anthocyanins @/sm$ and their metabolites could enhance the growth of beneficial bacteria (e.g., Bifidobaterium and Lactobacillus) and reduce a group of potentially harmful bacteria, such as Clostridium histolyticum. Similar results in the Bifidobaterium have also been described in human volunteers after 6-week consumption of a blueberry drink. In addition, a recent study examined the microbial associations of circulating equol, a metabolite of dietary soy isoflavones, and found higher @gm$ Alistipes senegalensis @/gm$ and Coprococcus catus but lower abundances of Ruminococcus gnavus were associated with equols.

@sm$ Azelastine @/sm$, a new generation antihistaminic, possesses certain antibacterial activity and is capable of inducing alteration in the bacterial membrane permeability. Hence, we hypothesized that it could reverse resistance to antibiotics. @sm$ Azelastine @/sm$ significantly increased the antibacterial activity of eight antibiotics belonging to five different classes (beta-lactams, macrolides, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides and tetracyclines) against nine Gram-positive clinical isolates: five Staphylococcus aureus, two Staphylococcus epidermidis and two @gm$ Enterococcus faecium @/gm$, seven of which were multi-drug resistant, reversing their resistance to the tested antibiotics. The synergistic effects of @sm$ azelastine @/sm$ with the studied antibiotics increased with raising the pH from 5 to 8. Antibiotics did not affect the ability of @sm$ azelastine @/sm$ to alter the permeability of a liposomal artificial membrane model, an effect thought to be critical for the interaction with antibiotics. The findings of this study present @sm$ azelastine @/sm$ as a potential 'helper compound' that could reverse the resistance of multi-drug resistant Gram-positive clinical isolates to antibiotics.

Alternativ konnen auch Levofloxacin oder Moxifloxacin zum Einsatz kommen, da diese Substanzen eine Wirksamkeit gegenuber Pneumokokken besitzen. Obwohl Levofloxacin eine gute In-vitro-Wirksamkeit gegen Pneumokokken aufweist, sind Therapieversager beschrieben. Cephalosporine der 3. Generation sind aber zur Therapie von @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ nicht geeignet; Mittel der ersten Wahl zur Behandlung von @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ sind Flucloxacillin, Cephalosporine der 1. Generation (z. B. Cefazolin) oder Cephalosporine der 2. Generation (z. @sm$ B. @/sm$ Cefuroxim).

@sm$ Bazedoxifene @/sm$ (@sm$ BZA @/sm$), which belongs to a new generation of SERMs, shows the ability to inhibit the growth of @gm$ M. tuberculosis @/gm$ in macrophages and is associated with autophagy. Our findings reveal a previously unrecognized antibacterial function of @sm$ BZA @/sm$.

@sm$ Carbapenem @/sm$-resistance among human invasive Escherichia coli strains was still reported to be rare in all EU/EEA countries, with a population weighted mean percentage of 0.1% in 2017 (ECDC,). @sm$ Carbapenem @/sm$-resistance combined with resistance to other important antimicrobial groups was commonly reported in P. aeruginosa in many EU/EEA countries in 2017, with a weighted mean of 17.4% (ECDC,). Unlike other bacteria, carbapenemresistance in P. aeruginosa is multifactorial, due to plasmid or integron-coded carbapenemases, increased expression of efflux systems, reduced porin expression and increased chromosomal cephalosporinase activity (Meletis et al.,). Regarding Acinetobacter baumanni, the epidemiological situation for @sm$ carbapenem @/sm$-resistance strains has been worsening in several European countries. Like K. pneumoniae and E. coli, @sm$ carbapenem @/sm$-resistance in A. baumannii is often mediated by carbapenemases production. In 2017, several European countries reported high percentages of resistance against @sm$ carbapenems @/sm$ in @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ spp., which ranged from 0.0% in some northern countries (Denmark, Norway and Sweden) to 96.2% (Croatia).

@sm$ Carnosol @/sm$ and carnosic acid, together with ursolic acid, which was not highlighted as a bioactive compound, have been reported to be responsible for the antibacterial activity of extracts of sage or S. officinalis toward MRSA when tested using the microdilution method. Salvia officinalis leaves are rich in methyl carnosate, a diterpene compound with good antibacterial activity towards @gm$ B. cereus @/gm$.

@sm$ Cholic acid @/sm$ enhances the abundance of opportunistic gut bacteria such as Prevotella and Desulfovibrio and reduces the abundance of Ruminococcus, Lactobacillus, and @gm$ Roseburia @/gm$, which drive gastrointestinal tumorigenesis through overproduction of the toxic substance, DCA.

@sm$ Cinnamic acid @/sm$ was the most abundant phenolic acid in the fermented C. lanceolata. The HPE-BLF and HPE-LRF samples exhibited the most noticeable antimicrobial activities against Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella Typhimurium, and @gm$ Shigella boydii @/gm$ (MICs<15 mg/mL).

@sm$ Ellagitannins @/sm$ (@sm$ ETs @/sm$) and ellagic acid (EA) are polyphenolic compounds abundantly present in walnuts and fruits, such as strawberries and pomegranate. The metabolization of EA by the specific members of the gut microbiota, such as Gordonibacter urolithinfaciens and @gm$ Gordonibacter pamelaeae @/gm$ (Eggerthellaceae family) generates another class of metabolites known as urolithins, comprising urolithin A-D.

@sm$ Enrofloxacin @/sm$ is a fluoroquinolone group antibacterial drug developed for use in veterinary medicine. It has a broad spectrum of antibacterial activity, including Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, as well as Mycoplasma spp.. @sm$ Enrofloxacin @/sm$ has a bactericidal effect by inhibiting the activity of bacterial DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV enzymes. In both mammalian and nonmammalian species, @sm$ enrofloxacin @/sm$ is dealkylated to ciprofloxacin, which exhibits a potency and spectrum of activity similar to @sm$ enrofloxacin @/sm$. @sm$ Enrofloxacin @/sm$ is widely used in fish due to its properties such as good absorption, large volume of distribution, high bioavailability, and long terminal half-life. Although @sm$ enrofloxacin @/sm$ is included in category B (Restrict) in the classification of antibiotics for veterinary use in terms of the risk of antimicrobial resistance by the EMA, it has been stated that it can be used in fish in cases in which there are few alternative treatment options, such as Aeromonas infection. @sm$ Enrofloxacin @/sm$ is used in diseases such as septicaemia, furunculosis, enteric red mouth, vibriosis or skin diseases in fish due to its effectiveness against bacteria such as @gm$ Aeromonas @/gm$ spp., Vibrio spp., and Yersinia spp..

@sm$ Esomeprazole @/sm$ was dosed to the nearest capsule size to achieve an oral dose of approximately 1 mg/kg once daily. @sm$ Esomeprazole @/sm$ is commercially available as 20 mg delayed-release capsules and was compounded by the UW Veterinary Care (UWVC) pharmacy into 10 and 30 mg capsules as needed. Participants were instructed to give the @sm$ esomeprazole @/sm$ on an empty stomach 30 minutes before feeding. A multi-strain probiotic was dosed to the nearest capsule size to a goal of at least 15 billion CFU/kg based on previously published guidelines for the treatment of canine inflammatory bowel disease as well as manufacturer recommendations. The probiotic capsules contained 4 live strains of Lactobacilli (L. plantarum DSM24730TM, L. paracasei DSM24733TM, L. acidophillus DSM24735TM, and L. delbueckii subp. Bulgaricus DSM24734TM), 3 live strains of Bifidobacteria (B. longum DSM24736TM, B. infantis DSM24747TM, and B. breve DSM24732TM), 1 live strain of @gm$ Streptococcus @/gm$ thermophiles DSM24731TM with microcrystalline cellulose, stearic acid, and magnesium sulfate in a vegetable capsule. This specific probiotic blend is sold under the brand name Visbiome Vet in the USA and Canada. The probiotic was administered simultaneously with @sm$ esomeprazole @/sm$ as the Visbiome label recommends it be given on an empty stomach and a previous study showed that probiotics administered 30 minutes after a meal did not survive in as high of numbers as those administered 30 minutes before a meal.

@sm$ Estradiol @/sm$-treated mice are often used as animal models to establish the colonization of pathogens associated with human reproductive tract infections, such as G. vaginalis, Streptococcus agalactiae, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The pH of @sm$ estradiol @/sm$-treated mouse vagina (pH range 5.8-7.2) is conducive to the colonization of BV-associated bacteria, which can be inoculated to evaluate the in vivo microbicidal activities of TP4 microbicide formulations. In this study, we established a murine model of single- or dual-species vaginal colonization by G. vaginalis and @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$, or lactobacilli. We demonstrated that TP4 microbicide formulation decreases the colonization density of BV-associated bacteria but not lactobacilli. Not surprisingly, metronidazole did not reduce the @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ survival in dual-species infected mice. However, the immunomodulatory effects of TP4 microbicide formulation could not be evaluated in this model because of a non-obvious inflammatory response in vaginal tissue and fluid (data not shown) in inoculated mice (observed after G. vaginalis, @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$, or dual-species).

@sm$ Ethyl acetate @/sm$ crude extract of Streptomyces VITNK9 evaluated for its efficacy as a protective agent against different fish-associated pathogens showed a moderate response against Aeromonas hydrophila, Edwardsiella tarda, Vibrio anguillarum, Vibrio harveyi, and @gm$ Aeromonas caviae @/gm$.

@sm$ Ethylene @/sm$ is a vital plant phytohormone that facilitates plant growth and development under non-stressed conditions. However, under stressed conditions, the level of @sm$ ethylene @/sm$ increases and negatively regulates plant growth. It restricts the elongation of root and transport of auxin, supports aging and extirpation of organs, and assists in the ripening of fruits. @sm$ Ethylene @/sm$ plays a key role in the activation of plant defense against biotic stresses. 1-Aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate (ACC) is the primary precursor in plants for @sm$ ethylene @/sm$ synthesized by ACC synthase by converting S-adenosyl methionine. Under stressed conditions, the activity of ACC synthase increases and produces a high amount of @sm$ ethylene @/sm$. When the ACC is degraded by the ACC deaminase producing bacteria, the level of @sm$ ethylene @/sm$ decreased, which results in the elongation of roots. A diverse group of PGPR having ACC deaminase activity has been reported as Serratia, Pseudomonas, Bacillus, @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$, Rhizobium, etc.. This PGPR with ACC deaminase activity hydrolyses the primary precursor ACC to alpha-ketobutyrate and ammonia and reduces the @sm$ ethylene @/sm$ level and improves plant health under stressed conditions.

@sm$ Fatty acids @/sm$ were the major metabolites perturbed across the liver, portal vein and gut microbiome in HCV, especially in patients with cirrhosis. Decreased @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ degradation by hepatic peroxisomes and mitochondria was coupled with increased free fatty acid (FFA) influx to the liver via the portal vein. Metatranscriptomics indicated that @gm$ Anaerostipes hadrus @/gm$-mediated @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ synthesis influences portal FFAs. Both microbial @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ synthesis and portal FFAs were associated with enhanced hepatic fibrosis.

@sm$ Fluconazole @/sm$'s resistance breakpoint concentrations for Candida spp. were recently investigated for their antibacterial effect against selected Gram-positive and Gram-negative species. While quaternary ammonium derivatives of @sm$ fluconazole @/sm$ had a potent inhibitory effect, none of the bacteria tested were inhibited by @sm$ fluconazole @/sm$ alone. However, the experiments were based on standard methods for MIC determination that examine inhibition only when the bacteria have reached the stationary phase of growth. Another study showed that in plate agar assays, @sm$ fluconazole @/sm$ inhibited S. lividans, although to a lesser extent than imidazoles. Our results indicate that although the effects on @gm$ S. mitis @/gm$ were not observed at the stationary phase, they were present at earlier growth phases. Accordingly, measurements of the density and viability of @gm$ S. mitis @/gm$ revealed a delay in reaching the stationary phase in the presence of @sm$ fluconazole @/sm$.

@sm$ Glutathione @/sm$ (@sm$ GSH @/sm$) is a highly abundant tripeptide thiol that performs diverse protective and biosynthetic functions in cells. While changes in @sm$ GSH @/sm$ availability are associated with inborn errors of metabolism, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders, studying the limiting role of @sm$ GSH @/sm$ in physiology and disease has been challenging due to its tight regulation. To address this, we generated cell and mouse models that express a bifunctional @sm$ glutathione @/sm$-synthesizing enzyme from @gm$ Streptococcus thermophilus @/gm$ (GshF), which possesses both glutamate-cysteine ligase and glutathione synthase activities. GshF expression allows efficient production of @sm$ GSH @/sm$ in the cytosol and mitochondria and prevents cell death in response to @sm$ GSH @/sm$ depletion, but not ferroptosis induction, indicating that @sm$ GSH @/sm$ is not a limiting factor under lipid peroxidation. CRISPR screens using engineered enzymes further revealed genes required for cell proliferation under cellular and mitochondrial @sm$ GSH @/sm$ depletion. Among these, we identified the glutamate-cysteine ligase modifier subunit, GCLM, as a requirement for cellular sensitivity to buthionine sulfoximine, a @sm$ glutathione @/sm$ synthesis inhibitor. Finally, GshF expression in mice is embryonically lethal but sustains postnatal viability when restricted to adulthood. Overall, our work identifies a conditional mouse model to investigate the limiting role of @sm$ GSH @/sm$ in physiology and disease.

@sm$ Indole @/sm$ also has a significant number of reported biological properties beneficial to the human. As a derivative of tryptophan, @sm$ indole @/sm$ is used by bacteria as a signaling molecule. In addition, @sm$ indole @/sm$ helps maintain the integrity of the intestinal barrier. In our study, we detected the @sm$ indole @/sm$ production by the most of the analyzed bacterial species. In @gm$ B. cellulosilyticus @/gm$ 807, B. eggerthii 91, B. intestinalis 181 and B. xylanisolvens EBA 5-17 large amount of @sm$ indole @/sm$ were detected.

@sm$ Indoles @/sm$ are bioactive products of the GM bacterial catabolism of tryptophan. Among these, 3-Indolepropionic acid (IPA), has been the subject of numerous studies due to its anticarcinogenic effects. IPA and other propionic acid species (PAs) derived from phenylalanine and tyrosine are synthesized through aromatic amino-acid transferases and phenyllactate dehydratase found in some species of the bacterial genera @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$, Akkermansia, Clostridium and Peptostreptococci. In general, @sm$ Indoles @/sm$ are also key interbacterial and GM-Host signaling molecules, act through steroid and xenobiotic receptors (AHRs and PXRs).

@sm$ LPS @/sm$ (200 ng/mL) alone or in combination with IFN-gamma (200 ng/mL) or LTA (1 mug/mL) were alternatively used to pre-stimulate THP-1 cells for 20 h before the infection with @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$. To assess the influence of TLR2 signaling, a TLR2 blocking antibody was added to the cells 90 min before OMV stimulation at a final concentration of 20 mug/mL. NF-kappaB inhibition was achieved by incubation with 1 muM IKK XIII inhibitor prior to treatment. The influence of nucleic acids in the OMVs on @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ replication was analyzed by digestion of OMVs with RNase A (0.2 mug/muL) and RNase III (0.02 U/muL) in combination or DNase I (0.004 U/muL).

@sm$ Lactate @/sm$ was even higher and acetate somewhat less suppressed as compared to neomycin. Butyrate production, however, was considerably higher than with untreated slurries. The latter is consistent with @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$'s metabolism, which is known to produce mainly butyrate from hexoses (Schwiertz et al.,; Duncan et al.,).

@sm$ Lactose @/sm$ hydrolysis was identified only in Firmicutes with exception of bin20 representing a member of Coriobacteriaceae. Most @sm$ lactose @/sm$-degrading bacteria (27 out of 31) hydrolyze @sm$ lactose @/sm$ by intracellular GH2 beta-galactosidase (BbgI, LacM, and BbgIV) or GH42 beta-galactosidase LacA, including members of Lactobacillus, @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$, and Ruminococcus. The abundance of Lactobacillus delbrueckii, a species that is specialized for @sm$ lactose @/sm$ conversion, decreased over time (Fig. 2). The other @sm$ lactose @/sm$ decomposers were capable of @sm$ lactose @/sm$ hydrolysis by extracellular BbgIII (GH2).

@sm$ Lactose @/sm$-based prebiotics or their interaction with probiotics reduce osteoporosis and improve bone health via different mechanisms. The mechanisms are (a) transformation of insoluble inorganic salts to soluble by short-chain fatty acids and increase their absorption to the gut wall; (b) maintenance and protection of mineral absorption surface in the gut by promoting the proliferation of enterocytes and colonocytes, integrating gut epithelium cells and improving intestinal barrier defending activity, down-regulating the formation and activity of nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells, reducing oxidative stress, immunomodulation, genetic modulation, and increasing antimutagenic activity; (c) increase the expression of calcium-binding proteins in the gut wall by increasing calbindin-D9k gene expression; (d) remodel the formation of osteoclasts and osteoblasts by increasing calcium uptake by suppressing the activities of parathyroid hormone and synthesis of insulin-like growth factor 1; (e) release of bone modulating factors; and (f) degradation of mineral complexing phytic acid. The involvement of several gut microbiota, including probiotics, such as Butyricicoccus, Dialister, Oscillibacter, @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$, Lactococcus, and Bifidobacteria reduce the risk of osteoporosis. The detailed mechanisms of reduction of osteoporosis offered by @sm$ lactose @/sm$-based prebiotics and interaction with probiotics are presented in Figure 2 and subsequent sections.

@sm$ Lignans @/sm$, for instance, are present in foods such as flaxseeds, vegetables and fruits and its bioconversion by bacteria renders them possible to be digested and absorbed by the human organism, where they were shown to have a protective effect against cancer and other diseases. The conversion of @sm$ lignans @/sm$ into secoisolariciresinol diglucoside (SDG) and the subsequent production of enterodiol (ED) and enterolactone (EL), which are responsible for the beneficial effects of @sm$ lignans @/sm$, involves a very complex series of steps. Eleven bacterial strains were identified to be responsible for these series of processes including several species from the genus Clostridium and Bacteroides and individual species such as Eubacterium limosum, Peptostreptococcus productus and @gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$.

@sm$ Methanol @/sm$ extract of C. asiatica from Soxhlet extraction was able to inhibit Aspergillus niger (14-19 mm), Fusarium oxysporum (13-14 mm), Xanthomonas campestris (10-13 mm), Lactobacillus acidophilus (11-13 mm), Pseudomonas marginalis (10-25 mm), Pseudomonas syringae (18-22 mm), Staphylococcus @gm$ salivarius @/gm$ (13-177 mm), and Staphylococcus aureus (9-12 mm), but exhibited no activity toward Penicillium expansum, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Staphylococcus mutans.

@sm$ Nitrate @/sm$ reduction to ammonia is a critical step of @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ metabolism in the rumen. It is reduced by nitrate reductase in assimilatory or dissimilatory way. Ruminal bacteria with @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ reducing ability are S. ruminantium, @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$, M. succiniciproduces, W. succinogenes, and V. parvula. In this study, @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ increased the @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$, M. succiniciproducens, and S. ruminantium abundance significantly indicating that they were core nitrate-reducing bacteria in @sm$ nitrate @/sm$-adapted steers. However, the relative abundance of S. ruminantium was 0.4469%, much lower than that reported by due to difference in feeding conditions, diet, and animal species. Were there other @sm$ nitrate @/sm$-reducing bacteria present in the rumen? In nature, most @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ reducers are found in Proteobacteria, Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Cyanobacteria. Based on deep analysis of sequencing data, we found that Proteobacteria and Cyanobacteria were linearly/quadratically increased with @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ addition. On genus taxon, Campylobacter of Proteobacteria was linearly increased with @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ supplementation. We proposed that there are undiscovered @sm$ nitrate @/sm$ reducing bacteria in Proteobacteria (especially Campylobacter genus) and Cyanobacteria phyla.

@sm$ Nitric oxide @/sm$ was also shown to kill @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ in vitro. When applied therapeutically, phenytoin powder did not kill @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ but promoted healing through acceleration of fibrogenesis.

@sm$ Octyl beta-D-glucopyranoside @/sm$ prevented the expression of cell-associated fructosyltransferase activity in @gm$ Streptococcus salivarius @/gm$ ATCC 25975 grown in batch culture or incubated in nonproliferating cell suspension medium. This effect was not due to the direct inhibition of enzyme activity nor due to the loss of active enzyme into the external medium. The prevention of enzyme expression did not appear to be due to the inhibition of a general translocation mechanism for protein secretion, since fructosyltransferase activity was not detected within the cytoplasm of lysed cells grown in the presence of @sm$ octyl beta-D-glucopyranoside @/sm$; nor was there any observed inhibition of the secretion of the extracellular enzyme glucosyltransferase.

@sm$ Oleanolic acid @/sm$ (148) often occurs in combination with its isomer, ursolic acid (147), and has been isolated from more than 1,620 plant species, especially in plants belonging to the Oleaceae family. @sm$ Oleanolic acid @/sm$ demonstrated moderate to high growth inhibitory activity against E. faecalis, @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$, B. cereus, and M. tuberculosis. Derivatives of @sm$ oleanolic acid @/sm$ with antibacterial activity have been isolated from a variety of plant species; this is the case of compound 156 (3-O-beta-D-glucuronopyranosyloleanolic acid 28-O-beta-D-glucopyranosyl ester) and compound 154 (3-O-beta-D-glucuronopyranosyl-oleanolic acid), both isolated from Melanthera elliptica O.Hoffm. Compounds 156 and 154 showed moderate activity against multidrug-resistant E. coli, S. flexneri and S. aureus. Compound 155 (3-O-beta-D-glucopyranosyl(1 6)-beta-D-glucopyranosyloleanolic acid) is another derivative of @sm$ oleanolic acid @/sm$ and was isolated from Paullinia pinnata L. (Sapindaceae). Compound 155 showed moderate to high antibacterial activity against E. coli, K. pneumoniae, E. aerogenes, and S. enterica ser. Typhi. A set of oleanolic acid C-28 amide derivatives were synthesized and it was shown that a longer chain length improved antibacterial activity on gram-positive bacteria. Unlike ursolic acid, @sm$ oleanolic acid @/sm$ inhibits peptidoglycan turnover, thus affecting the cell membrane of bacteria. @sm$ Oleanolic acid @/sm$ also showed a synergistic effect in combination with conventional antibiotics against MRSA. Although @sm$ oleanolic acid @/sm$ is one of the most investigated plant-derived compounds and has been approved as an OTC hepatoprotective drug in China, few in vivo studies and clinical trials have been undertaken to evaluate the use of @sm$ oleanolic acid @/sm$ and its derivatives as antibacterial agents.

@sm$ Piperacillin @/sm$ has the broadest activity spectrum of all the penicillins, including Pseudomonas, Enterobacteriaceae, Gram-negative rods, and anaerobes. To demonstrate its efficacy, a study examined the clinical usefulness of @sm$ piperacillin @/sm$ therapy compared to ampicillin-sulbactam for community-acquired pneumonia. The general clinical efficiency of @sm$ piperacillin @/sm$ therapy in these patients was similar to that of ampicillin-sulbactam therapy. The previous study by Seki et al. concluded that @sm$ piperacillin @/sm$ was effective in the treatment of pneumonia and proposed @sm$ piperacillin @/sm$ as a first-line treatment for community-acquired pneumonia. From the results of our study, @sm$ piperacillin @/sm$ cannot be recommended as a first-line treatment for patients with pneumonia caused by @gm$ Haemophilus @/gm$ species because of its relatively high resistance rate and lower sensitivity rate according to our susceptibility testing results.

@sm$ Polyphosphate @/sm$ [poly(P)] has antibacterial activity against various Gram-positive bacteria. In contrast, Gram-negative bacteria are generally resistant to poly(P). Here, we describe the antibacterial characterization of poly(P) against a Gram-negative periodontopathogen, @gm$ Porphyromonas gingivalis @/gm$. The MICs of pyrophosphate (Na(4)P(2)O(7)) and all poly(P) (Na(n + 2)P(n)O(3n + 1); n = 3 to 75) tested for the bacterium by the agar dilution method were 0.24% and 0.06%, respectively. Orthophosphate (Na(2)HPO(4)) failed to inhibit bacterial growth. Poly-P75 was chosen for further study. In liquid medium, 0.03% poly-P75 was bactericidal against @gm$ P. gingivalis @/gm$ irrespective of the growth phase and inoculum size, ranging from 10(5) to 10(9) cells/ml. UV-visible spectra of the pigments from @gm$ P. gingivalis @/gm$ grown on blood agar with or without poly-P75 showed that poly-P75 reduced the formation of mu-oxo bisheme by the bacterium. Poly-P75 increased hemin accumulation on the @gm$ P. gingivalis @/gm$ surface and decreased energy-driven uptake of hemin by the bacterium. The expression of the genes encoding hemagglutinins, gingipains, hemin uptake loci, chromosome replication, and energy production was downregulated, while that of the genes related to iron storage and oxidative stress was upregulated by poly-P75. The transmission electron microscope showed morphologically atypical cells with electron-dense granules and condensed nucleoid in the cytoplasm. Collectively, poly(P) is bactericidal against @gm$ P. gingivalis @/gm$, in which hemin/heme utilization is disturbed and oxidative stress is increased by poly(P).

@sm$ Polysaccharide @/sm$-containing bacteria possess degradation properties, and their associations with fecal sugar derivatives were generally positive, while @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ showed a negative correlation. Dorea strain administration on a high-fat diet mice intensified insulin resistance and obesity compared with @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ administration. The authors of this work reported that the gut microbes' effects on metabolic diseases are mediated through @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$' microbial fermentation and their derivatives. Several studies in mice involving species of Bacteroides have shown that controlling the intake of @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ in the mouse diet allows species selection that are capable of metabolizing the complex @sm$ glycans @/sm$ present, such as human milk oligosaccharides, fructans, fucosylated mucin glycans and mannan, among others.

@sm$ Progesterone @/sm$ displayed the greatest ability in the induction of biofilm formation (65%) but had a smaller effect on @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ ATCC 13884 bacterial population growth (11%). Similarly, hydrochlorothiazide, a diuretic widely used in combination with antihypertensive drugs, had a great effect on the induction of biofilm formation (51%) and a smaller effect on bacterial growth (17%). Acetaminophen caused several changes in @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ ATCC 13884 cultures related to quorum sensing, such as inducing the synthesis of the N-hexanoyl-homoserine lactone (C6-AHL) autoinducer by up 22%, increasing bacterial populations by 27%, inducing biofilm formation by 49%, and forming a more gentamicin-resistant biofilm. Furthermore, it increased the colonization area of the urethral catheter. Non-modified drugs are mainly excreted in the feces and urine at concentrations of approximately 0.09-0.6 microg/mL. Therefore, intact drugs at low concentrations in urine might be enough to activate the virulence and resistance mechanisms of @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ ATCC 13884.

@sm$ ROS @/sm$, RNS, and NO produced by cold plasma play a key role in the inactivation of microorganisms and the formation of nitrite in meat products. As a food additive, nitrite is often used to pickle meat products and prevent the contamination of pathogenic microorganisms, such as @gm$ Clostridium botulinum @/gm$, Staphylococcus aureus, and Clostridium perfringens. Cold plasma technology is used in the research, at present, to pickle pork sausages because cold plasma-producing @sm$ ROS @/sm$ may directly result in microbial death by destroying microbial DNA; on the other hand, nitrite formed by cold plasma treatment can maintain the color, flavor, and lipid oxidation of pork.

@sm$ Reactive oxygen species @/sm$ (@sm$ ROS @/sm$) have been associated with host defense, inflammation, and tissue damage. Antioxidant enzymes participate in inactivation of @sm$ ROS @/sm$ and degradation of superoxide anions and hydrogen peroxide. In the current study, the CBN group significantly increased the inhibition ability of hydroxyl radical and GSH-PX activity and modestly decreased H2O2 serum concentration. This was in agreement with previous studies, which showed that diets with @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ can increase the activity of GSH-PX, SOD, and CAT in intestine of broiler and Rex rabbits. In addition, @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$'s main metabolite butyric acid can modulate oxidative damage by reducing @sm$ ROS @/sm$ and increasing the levels of antioxidative enzymes. Improved immune function might partially contribute to enhance the antioxidant ability and suppress @sm$ ROS @/sm$ production, because @sm$ ROS @/sm$ are considered indispensable for host defense against an inflammatory threat. ALT, AST, ALP, gamma-GT, and CHE play an important role in liver function as main indicators. A previous study revealed that @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ supplementation resulted in a considerable reduction in the serum ALT and AST activities in piglets. In the mice model, @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ also relieved acute liver damage induced by carbon tetrachloride. Our results indicated that diet supplemented with @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ decreased AST, ALP, gamma-GT, and CHE activies, particularly in the CBN group.

@sm$ Rifampin @/sm$ inhibited 20 strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in concentrations of 0.005 to 0.02 mug/ml in 7H-9 broth with Tween 80 and killed all or nearly all of the inoculum in four to eight times greater concentrations. In the same medium without Tween 80, as well as on 7H-10 agar, about 16 to 64 times these amounts were required to produce the same effect. @sm$ Rifampin @/sm$ was also active against @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ and some of the nonchromogenic mycobacteria. The incidence of mycobacterial cells resistant to @sm$ rifampin @/sm$ within the cultures studied was in the range of one to four per 10(8) to 10(9) colony-forming units with concentrations of 4 to 125 mug of @sm$ rifampin @/sm$ per ml. Only one of the Battey cultures and that of M. fortuitum yielded cells resistant to @sm$ rifampin @/sm$ at 125 mug/ml but not at 500 mug/ml. The same strains yielded more than double that number of organisms resistant to streptomycin and up to 100 times more organisms resistant to isoniazid. All three drugs stopped the growth or reduced the mycobacterial population in growing cultures after contact for 24 to 48 hr. Complete inhibition of growth was produced by @sm$ rifampin @/sm$ at 1.0 mug/ml in an average of 6 days and by streptomycin at 5.0 mug/ml in 3 days. After an average contact of 10.7 days with @sm$ rifampin @/sm$, five of seven strains resumed growth and all strains began regrowth after exposure to streptomycin for 9.4 days. The marked susceptibility of M. tuberculosis and of atypical mycobacteria to @sm$ rifampin @/sm$ in vitro and the relatively low incidence of resistant mutants suggests that this agent may have clinical usefulness in the treatment of tuberculosis and some other mycobacterioses.

@sm$ Spermidine @/sm$ was produced by all strains from the genera Bifidobacterium, by two of the three Clostridium isolates (B.1 and B.2), but by only two of the 17 Enterococcus strains (C.1 and C.17). Lactobacillus crispatus and @gm$ Lactobacillus gasseri @/gm$ strains were not able to produce @sm$ spermidine @/sm$, but Lactobacillus fermentum, Lactobacillus salivarius (except D.21) and Lactobacillus vaginalis were capable of producing @sm$ spermidine @/sm$ (Figure 1). The Pediococcus and Streptococcus isolates also secreted @sm$ spermidine @/sm$ (Figure 1). For Gram-negative bacteria, only two E. coli strains (H.7 and H.8), one K. pneumoniae strain (I.2) and Proteus mirabilis (K.1) were capable of secreting @sm$ spermidine @/sm$ under these culture conditions (Figure 1).

@sm$ Tedizolid @/sm$'s anaerobic activity is unappreciated. In this study, it was active against all 332 anaerobic isolates tested at <=2 mug/ml except @gm$ Bilophila wadsworthia @/gm$ and was more active than linezolid against Bacteroides fragilis group species (MIC90, 1 mug/ml versus 2 to 4 mug/ml). @sm$ Tedizolid @/sm$ was active against Gram-positive anaerobes (MIC90 for clostridia, 0.25 to 1 mug/ml; MIC90 for anaerobic cocci, <=0.06 to 0.25 mug/ml).

@sm$ Terpenoids @/sm$ represent the largest group of secondary metabolites with variable structures and functions. @sm$ Terpenoids @/sm$ are well known for their beneficial application in human life, such as pharmaceutical products, vitamins, hormones, anticancer drugs, cosmetics, flavors and fragrances, foods, agriculture, and biofuels. Recently, engineering microbial cells have been provided with a sustainable approach to produce @sm$ terpenoids @/sm$ with high yields. Noticeably, the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-associated (Cas) system has emerged as one of the most efficient genome-editing technologies to engineer microorganisms for improving @sm$ terpenoid @/sm$ production. In this review, we summarize the application of the CRISPR-Cas system for the production of @sm$ terpenoids @/sm$ in microbial hosts such as Escherichia coli, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Corynebacterium glutamicum, and @gm$ Pseudomonas putida @/gm$. CRISPR-Cas9 deactivated Cas9 (dCas9)-based CRISPR (CRISPRi), and the dCas9-based activator (CRISPRa) have been used in either individual or combinatorial systems to control the metabolic flux for enhancing the production of @sm$ terpenoids @/sm$. Finally, the prospects of using the CRISPR-Cas system in @sm$ terpenoid @/sm$ production are also discussed.

@sm$ Tirapazamine @/sm$ (@sm$ 3-amino-1,2,4-benzotriazine 1,4 dioxide @/sm$) is an anticancer agent showing selective cytotoxicity for hypoxic cells in solid tumors. Upon its activation, this aziridinylquinone forms a free radical at position 1, where the oxide group is attached, inducing single- and double-strand breaks in DNA, base damage, and cell death. Previous studies reported its activity against E. coli, Salmonella enterica, S. aureus, @gm$ Clostridium difficile @/gm$, and M. tuberculosis. In the present study, for the first time, we observed the effectiveness of @sm$ tirapazamine @/sm$ against P.

@sm$ Tryptamine @/sm$ was noted in one of the RYGB donors when cultured with tryptophan-supplemented media (Figure S7). Twelve representative bacterial species in healthy individuals (Bacteroides uniformis and Bacteroides vulgatus), obese patients (Streptococcus cristatus, Streptococcus gallolyticus, Ruminococcus torques and @gm$ Dorea longicatena @/gm$) and RYGB patients/animal models (Shigella sonnei, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Escherichia coli, Enterobacter hormaechei, Enterobacter cloacae and Klebsiella oxytoca) were selected for batch culture.

@sm$ Tryptophan @/sm$ catabolism in cancer is recognized as an important microenvironment modulator that alleviates antitumor immune responses. It has been reported that cancer cells create an immunosuppressive milieu in tumors and tumor-draining lymph nodes by inducing T cell anergy and apoptosis through depletion of @sm$ tryptophan @/sm$ and accumulation of immunosuppressive @sm$ tryptophan @/sm$ catabolites. In our study, fecal @sm$ tryptophan @/sm$ was significantly increased in CRC patients. It has been reported that the fecal tryptophan indole pathway is impaired in colorectal cancer and that indole-related bacteria may lead to downregulation of the tryptophan indole metabolic pathway. We noticed a linkage of increased levels of fecal @sm$ tryptophan @/sm$ associated with @gm$ Ruminococcus bicirculans @/gm$ and Fusobacterium in our study for decreased production of indole.

@sm$ Tyramine @/sm$ is a health-adverse biogenic amine, which can accumulate in fermented foods like cheese by decarboxylation of the free amino acid tyrosine by either starter cultures or resident microbes such as lactic acid bacteria including Enterococcus spp., respectively. Our study aimed to show the effect of sodium chloride concentrations on @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ production as well as to characterise bacterial strains as anti-@sm$ tyramine @/sm$ biocontrol agents in a 2 mL micro-cheese fermentation model. The effect of sodium chloride on @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ production was assayed with @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ producing strains from eight different species or subspecies. Generally, an increase in sodium chloride concentration enhanced @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ production, e.g. from 0% to 1.5% of sodium chloride resulted in an increase of @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ of 870% with a @gm$ Staphylococcus xylosus @/gm$ strain. In the biocontrol screening among lactic acid bacteria, a Lactobacillus plantarum JA-1199 strain was screened that could consume in successful competition with other resident bacteria tyrosine in the micro-cheese model as a source of energy gain. Thereby @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ accumulation was reduced between 4% to 99%. The results of this study disclose a feasible strategy for decreasing @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ concentration and increasing the safety level of fermented food.

@sm$ Tyramine @/sm$, histamine, phenylethylamine, tryptamine, putrescine, cadaverine, spermine and spermidine have been detected in a large number of analyzed products. That being said, @sm$ tyramine @/sm$, putrescine and cadaverine are the main determined biogenic amines in fermented sausages. While the presence of putrescine and @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ in fermented sausages is associated with the activity of lactic acid bacteria, it is stated that cadaverine is caused by insufficient hygienic measures and high microbial load of the raw material used in production. Although the aminogenic potential of lactic acid bacteria is low, it can contribute to biogenic amine accumulation. Some lactic acid bacteria have amino acid decarboxylase activity and can form histamine, cadaverine and putrescine, while they are particularly effective in terms of @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ formation. Therefore, the selection of strains used as starter cultures in fermented sausages is very important. On the other hand, lactic acid bacteria are considered microorganisms that are responsible for the formation of biogenic amines in fermented meat products. A high @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ number is reported to have a significant impact on histamine formation. While @sm$ tyramine @/sm$-producing strains have been attributed to Carnobacterium, Latilactobacillus curvatus, and L. plantarum, Micrococcaceae and Latilactobacillus sake have been reported to play no role in @sm$ tyramine @/sm$ formation. It is stated that Enterococcus faecalis and E. faecium species, which belong to the lactic acid bacteria group, also produce high levels of @sm$ tyramine @/sm$. L. curvatus strains are reported to play a role in the formation of phenylethylamine, tryptamine, putrescine and cadaverine as well as @sm$ tyramine @/sm$.

Here, @sm$ vinblastine @/sm$ similarly hindered Y.

@sm$ Vitamin B7 @/sm$ acts as a coenzyme for several biochemical reactions, such as glycolysis and cell signalling and epigenetic regulations. It also controls gene expression, including nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kappaB), through histone binding mechanism, commonly known as biotinylation. Therefore, this vitamin may also have anti-inflammatory effects. @sm$ Biotin @/sm$ is primarily synthesized from either malonyl CoA or pimeloyl-CoA. Enzymes of the @sm$ biotin @/sm$ biosynthesis pathway are overrepresented in enterotype 1, enriched in Bacteroides. Bacteria that can produce @sm$ vitamin B7 @/sm$ include Bacteroides fragilis, @gm$ Prevotella copri @/gm$, Fusobacterium varium, and Campylobacter coli. In contrast, others are extensive @sm$ vitamin B7 @/sm$ reducers, such as Lactobacillus murinus.

@sm$ Vitamin D @/sm$ supplementation alters the composition and richness of the intestinal microflora by decreasing Veillonellaceae and Oscillospiraceae, while increasing beneficial bacteria such Bacteroidetes and Bifidobacteria. Vitamin A dramatically raised Bacteroides/bacteroidetes ratio. Vitamin A deficiency increased Enterococci, while its addition increased @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ in mice's intestines, affecting early viral infection. Vitamin C also helps the organism fight infection and eliminate risky microorganisms. @sm$ Vitamin D @/sm$ intake decreases Veillonellaceae and Oscillospiraceae and increases Bacteroidetes and Bifidobacteria in the gut microbiota.

A 2.00 w/v gamma-PGA solution had 11 mm and 13 mm inhibition zones against Staphylococcus aureus and @gm$ Shigella dysenteriae @/gm$, respectively. A second order polynomial equation for prediction of gamma-PGA was derived as: gammaPGA yield = 3316.061 - 449.708A + 9.036A2 - 139.813B + 3.095B2 - 7.699C - 0.164C2 + 13.116AB - 0.087AB2 - 0.248A2B + 3.781AC - 0.076A2C - 0.394BC. It showed an increase in gamma-PGA yield with increasing L-glutamic acid and @sm$ biotin @/sm$, but a decrease with yeast extract.

A @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ genus-specific PCR primer pair was designed and used as a positive control for the PCR assay of the differentiating regions. This primer pair was screened against all sequences from all organisms currently deposited in the GenBank Database, and is expected to be extremely @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ specific. Each set of PCR reactions also contained a no DNA contamination control. The PCR was performed on @sm$ methanol @/sm$ killed bacterial cells, which is a commonly used diagnostic technique.

A @sm$ glucosamine @/sm$ residue was nonstoichiometrically linked to the branching galacturonic acid, and more interestingly, a Ko unit substitutes in part the terminal Kdo residue. The presence of the Ko residue is not frequent in core structures, and to date it has been described as a substitute for Kdo in the LPS of Yersinia, Burkholderia, Acinetobacter, Serratia. Finally, this new core oligosaccharide confirmed the lack of a uniform core structure for the unique species of the @gm$ Plesiomonas @/gm$ genus.
A DndD homolog in @gm$ P. fluorescens @/gm$, SpfD, has ATPase activity possibly related to DNA structure alteration or nicking during @sm$ PT @/sm$ incorporation.

A Superfrost Plus  slide (Menzel-Glaser, Germany) was heat fixated and stored at room temperature until shipment to the Institute of Tropical Medicine in Antwerp, Belgium (ITM) where it was re-fixated with a Carnoy solution (6:3:1, ethanol:@sm$ chloroform @/sm$:glacial acetic acid) for at least 12 h. For all participants who had @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ detected by qPCR, the slide was examined using Peptide Nucleic Acid (PNA)-FISH employing species-specific probes for A. vaginae (AtoITM1) and @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ (Gard162), and the broad-range BacUni-1 probe.

A bacterial strain isolated from human faeces, M-165T, was characterized in terms of its phenotypic and biochemical features, cellular @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ profile, menaquinone profile and phylogenetic position (based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis). A 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis showed that the isolate was a member of the genus Parabacteroides. Strain M-165T was closely related to @gm$ Parabacteroides merdae @/gm$ strains, showing 98 % sequence similarity. The strain was obligately anaerobic, non-pigmented, non-spore-forming, non-motile, Gram-negative, rod-shaped and was able to grow on media containing 20 % bile. Although the phenotypic characteristics of the strain M-165T were similar to those of @gm$ P. merdae @/gm$, the isolate could be differentiated from @gm$ P. merdae @/gm$ by means of API 20A tests for L-arabinose and L-rhamnose fermentation. DNA-DNA hybridization experiments revealed the genomic distinctiveness of the novel strain with respect to @gm$ P. merdae @/gm$ JCM 9497T (<or=60 % DNA-DNA relatedness).

A cholesterol-rich station in the membrane known as a @sm$ lipid @/sm$ raft is formed when cholesterol is present in membranes with pre-determined membrane dynamics. These @sm$ lipid @/sm$ rafts are intended to serve as a gateway for the entry of numerous pathogens. Pathogens can elude the immune system in an innovative way by using membrane microdomains. Some pathogens have acquired strategies to thwart innate and adaptive immune responses by co-opting raft-associated pathways. Most intracellular pathogens tactically exploit @sm$ lipid @/sm$ rafts for entering the host cell. Salmonella and Shigella have a common requirement for a T3SS (type III secretion system), which is a multicomponent molecular syringe that allows the translocation of so called effector proteins from bacterial cytoplasm, through the inner and outer bacterial membrane, as well as the host plasma membrane, directly into cytoplasm. It has effector proteins called SipB and SipC for Salmonella and IpaB and IpaC for Shigella that must come into contact with the host cell in order to activate the system. The binding of SipB/IpaB to host cells requires cholesterol in the membranes on the downstream of the T3SS activation. The pathogenic vesicles of Enterotoxigenic E. coli fuses to the cell membrane in the cholesterol rich domain of the host cell membrane. Cholesterol depleting agents reduces internalization of Helicobacter pylori in gut epithelial cells. Hole forming bacteria like @gm$ Vibrio cholerae @/gm$ prefers to create holes in the @sm$ lipid @/sm$ rafts as rafts can sustain the holes for longer time.

A closer comparative analysis was performed for the presence/absence of functions involved in biocontrol and the interactions of @gm$ P. fluorescens @/gm$ strains with plants and the environment. Biological control mechanisms include synthesis of secondary metabolites against bacterial and fungal pathogens, including toxins and bacteriocins. The UM270 genome contains biosynthetic genes for multiple secondary metabolites, such as 2,4-DAPG, phenazines and @sm$ HCN @/sm$; the rest of genomes contained only one or two of these functions.

A cohort study with 153 Italian individuals following different diets showed that adherence to the MD correlates to higher fecal levels of @sm$ acetate @/sm$, propionate and butyrate. Accordingly, MD has been associated with increased abundance of butyrate-producing strains like F. prausnitzii and E. rectale and the butyrate-producing genus @gm$ Roseburia @/gm$ and to reduced levels of circulating LPS.

A common feature for all co-cultures is the decrease of a metabolite, which might be @sm$ L-Arginine @/sm$ (metabolite no 1). This could be related to an increased uptake by @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$, since it was reported that @sm$ arginine @/sm$ leads to increased growth in @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$. Another consistently decreased metabolite in co-cultures is metabolite no. 2, which we could putatively identify as 12alpha-Hydroxyamoorstatin, which is a rare metabolite but linked to the bile acid structure and thus is potentially indicating to an increased transformation of bile acids by @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$. In contrast, there is also one metabolite that is consistently increased in co-culture, which could be identified as L-ornithine (metabolite no. 3). L-Ornithine is involved in the synthesis of @sm$ arginine @/sm$ and an increased uptake of @sm$ arginine @/sm$ might result in a decrease of ornithine produced and secreted by @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$. Interestingly, we detected metabolites significantly altered in abundance between the co-culturing with @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ and single culturing for A.

A comparison between control mice and all antidepressant groups together revealed that Ruminococcus, @gm$ Adlercreutzia @/gm$ and an undefined genus in the order RF32, class Alphaproteobacteria were less abundant in antidepressant treated mice (Fig. 2a, b). When analyzing the effects of each individual antidepressant in comparison to control using pairwise comparisons, the same genera were shown to be less abundant in @sm$ escitalopram @/sm$, venlafaxine, duloxetine and desipramine groups, but not in fluoxetine group (Supplemental Figure S2). Further, in both the overall effects of antidepressants and in the pairwise analysis, the differences in genus @gm$ Adlercreutzia @/gm$ contributed to observed decreased abundance of family Coriobacteriaceae, order Coriobacteriales, class Coriobacteriia, phylum Actinobacteria in antidepressant groups (Fig. 2a, b; Supplemental Figure S2). In addition to the LEfSe analysis, we further analyzed the 16S rRNA gene sequencing data with PERMANOVA (Supplementary Table 2). At the genus level, both Ruminococcus and @gm$ Adlercreutzia @/gm$ were effected by antidepressant treatment (p < 0.05), although only @gm$ Adlercreutzia @/gm$ remained significant after corrections for multiple comparisons. In direct pairwise analysis between control and each of the antidepressant groups, some antidepressants significantly decreased levels of Ruminococcus, although they were no longer significant after corrections for multiple comparisons. Therefore, the findings of decrease in Ruminococcus and @gm$ Adlercreutzia @/gm$ were more significant in the LEfSe analysis, and we further explored these findings using qRT-PCR.

A compelling example of extensive AA-dependent metabolic communication between host and pathogen occurs during infection with @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ or Shigella (Figure 1). Those infections rapidly induce a state of AA starvation in epithelial cells, which reduces abundances of leucine/@sm$ isoleucine @/sm$ in cytosol, and inhibits activation of mTORC1, but induces the general control nonderepressible 2-dependent stress response pathway to promote expression of activating transcription factor 3 (ATF3) (Figure 1). This starvation is induced through aseptic membrane damage, but not protein metabolism because chloramphenicol has little effect on the expression of ATF3 while inhibiting synthesis of bacterial proteins. AA starvation may inhibit the host's innate immune responses and adaptive immune responses against pathogens, but activate host cell autophagy responses which are normally inhibited by mTORC1 (Figure 1). Autophagy is a highly conserved cellular process that triggers nutrient recycling to sustain essential metabolic functions during nutrient or energy deprivation. Autophagy involves degradation and recycling of cellular constituents, such as dysfunctional organelles or macromolecular complexes. Autophagy also promotes targeting and degradation of intracellular bacteria, such as Shigella or @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$, and has important roles in the pathogenesis of extracellular bacterial infections, such as ETEC. However, @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ could escape from autophagy-mediated degradation through the replenishment of intracellular AA pools to recruit and reactivate mTORC1 signaling at the surface of the @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$-containing vacuole (SCV) (Figure 1).

A creatine chromogenic solution was added to @gm$ K. variicola @/gm$ cultured in a V-P selective medium for 48 h. Results showed that the fermentation broth containing @gm$ K. variicola @/gm$ turned pink after the addition of the creatine chromogenic solution, while no colour change was observed in the culture medium of the blank control group (Fig. 1F), indicating that @gm$ K. variicola @/gm$ can produce @sm$ acetoin @/sm$. Using different concentrations of @sm$ acetoin @/sm$ standard solution from the colour reaction to draw the standard curve, the @sm$ acetoin @/sm$ production capacity of @gm$ K. variicola @/gm$ was 152.88 +- 13.56 mg L-1.
