Lipid A of @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ was isolated with the Bligh-Dyer method. Specifically, overnight culture was inoculated into 250-mL cultures, in which the initial OD600 was 0.02, and then cells grew to an OD600 of 1.0. All @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ cells were harvested by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 30 min and then washed with ddH2O twice. The cell pellet was first suspended with 76 mL of mixture containing chloroform/H2O/@sm$ methanol @/sm$ (1:0.8:2 v/v/v). The insoluble debris was then collected and washed with 60 mL mixture. The debris was heated and suspended with 12.5 mM sodium acetate (pH 4.5) by boiling water bath for 30 min. The suspension was mixed with @sm$ methanol @/sm$ and chloroform and the mixture containing suspension/@sm$ methanol @/sm$/chloroform (27:30:30 v/v/v).

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) of four nonencapsulated strains of the human enteric pathogen @gm$ Campylobacter jejuni @/gm$ were chemically characterized. When applied to two of the strains, extraction by a modified phenol-chloroform-petroleum ether method (H. Brade and C. Galanos, Eur. J. Biochem. 122:233-237, 1982) gave better yields of LPS than did extraction by the conventional hot phenol-water technique. Constituents common to all LPS were D-glucose, D-galactose, L-glycero-D-manno-heptose, 3-deoxy-D-manno-2-octulosonic acid, D-glucuronic acid, D-galactosamine, and phosphorylethanolamine. Phosphate was present in a relatively high amount. In addition, the LPS of three strains contained N-acetylneuraminic acid, whereas the LPS of the strain lacking this component contained 3-amino-3,6-dideoxy-D-glucose. The lipid A component contained phosphate with D-glucosamine and 2,3-diamino-2,3-dideoxy-D-glucose as the major amino sugars. Ethanolamine-phosphate was present also. The major fatty acids were ester- and amide-bound 3-hydroxytetradecanoic and ester-bound @sm$ hexadecanoic acids @/sm$, with a minor amount of ester-bound tetradecanoic acid. This is the first report of N-acetylneuraminic acid in the oligosaccharide moiety and diaminoglucose in the lipid A of @gm$ C. jejuni @/gm$ LPS.

Non-digestible @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ derived from the diet, together with host-produced glycans found in the mammalian gut represent critical energy sources believed to be responsible for the survival and proliferation of many microbial components of the gut microbiota, including bifidobacteria. It is therefore important to know what molecular strategies are employed by members of the gut microbiota to harvest and metabolize complex glycans in order to understand how they underpin their ecological fitness in, and adaptation to, the GIT environment. Furthermore, @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ metabolism in the mammalian gut may occur in a concerted manner by various members of the microbiota, including bifidobacteria. Thus, @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ are presumed to be partly responsible for microbiota dynamics in this changeable environment. Genomics has been crucial in revealing the complex interactions and molecular dialogue between a host and its resident (bifido)bacteria, and in unraveling bifidobacterial gut colonization strategies. Recently, all 47 currently recognized bifidobacterial sub/species have been genomically decoded, thus providing the necessary genetic background for this group of bacteria. Here, we describe an analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of representatives of all 47 (sub)species that are currently assigned to the @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ genus, predicting bifidobacterial genome-based strategies for @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ metabolism that impact on the overall glycobiome of the gut microbiota and host, while also being pivotal for the establishment of trophic relationships between members of gut microbiota.

Here, we characterized the microbiological and genomic features of a carbapenem-resistant @gm$ K. michiganensis @/gm$ strain harboring the blaNDM-1 gene in China. Methods: K. michiganensis strain 2563 was recovered from the sputum sample of a hospitalized patient with pulmonary infection. Whole-genome sequencing of K. michiganensis strain 2563 was conducted using both the short-read Illumina and long-read MinION platforms to thoroughly characterize the genetic context of blaNDM-carrying plasmid in K. michiganensis 2563. Furthermore, BacWGSTdb server was utilized to perform in silico multilocus sequence typing (MLST), identify antimicrobial resistance genes, and conduct genomic epidemiological analyses of the closely related isolates deposited in the public database. Results: K. michiganensis 2563 was resistant to piperacillin, aztreonam, @sm$ meropenem @/sm$, imipenem, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefotaxime, cefazolin, ampicillin/sulbactam, cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, and ceftazidime. It belonged to sequence type (ST) 43, and the blaNDM-1 gene was found to be located on the plasmid p2563_NDM (54,035 bp). This plasmid showed remarkable similarity to other blaNDM-1-encoding plasmids found in various Enterobacterium species in the public database. The occurrence of global ST43 @gm$ K. michiganensis @/gm$ was primarily sporadic, and the closest relative of K. michiganensis 2563 was another ST43 isolate 12,084 recovered from China in 2013, which differed by 171 SNPs. Conclusion: Our study reports the genome characteristics of a carbapenem-resistant @gm$ K. michiganensis @/gm$ strain carrying the blaNDM-1 gene in China, highlighting the need for ongoing surveillance of this pathogen in clinical settings.

Only five cases of @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ as a cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis have been reported in the literature, with no reports of biofilm formation within the species. METHODS: The aetiological strain was speciated and subspeciated by the VITEK 2 NH card and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionisation time-of-flight mass spectrometry. CFF biofilm formation was analysed using a crystal violet staining method. C. jejuni National Collection of Type Cultures (NCTC) 11168 was used as a positive control organism. Strains were incubated statically in Mueller-Hinton broth and Mueller-Hinton broth supplemented with 0.025% @sm$ sodium deoxycholate @/sm$ for 3 and 7 days at 37 C, microaerobically. RESULTS: The CFF strain formed stronger attached biofilms on polystyrene plates on day 3 (72 hours) than the C. jejuni NCTC 11168 control strain, but were weaker than the control strain on day 7 in Mueller-Hinton broth. Monoculture of this @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ isolate was found to exist in three defined forms of biofilms (attached, air-liquid interface and floccules). CONCLUSIONS: This clinically significant @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ isolate showed considerable biofilm-forming capability, which we suggest conferred a survivalist advantage, contributing to the genesis of infective prosthetic valve endocarditis.

Similar metrics were used to assess SCFA phenotype variations at the genus level. Out of 296 analyzed HGM genera, 163 were represented by more than one genome, and 102 of them (~34%) demonstrated various degrees of phenotype variability. Majority of genera with the highest variability of SCFA binary metabolic phenotypes (NVP >3; OPVS >0.95) belong to the Clostridia class from the Firmicutes phylum (Table 2). In contrast, other HGM phyla including Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteira and Actinobacteria demonstrate relatively low levels of variations of SCFA production phenotypes. For instance, the Bacteroides and @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ genera from the Bacteroidetes phylum were characterized by 5 and 4 variable phenotypes with OPVS values 0.13 and 0.38, respectively. Finally, by comparing cumulative variability metrics between individual SCFA phenotypes across all analyzed HGM genomes, we demonstrated that the L-, D-lactate, formate and propionate production are most variable phenotypes both at the species and genus level, whereas the @sm$ acetate @/sm$ and butyrate production phenotypes are more conserved in closely-related species and genera of HGM strains.

Other strongly biased distributions of genes concerning nitrogen-scavenging capacity, such as nucleic acid catabolism, may also reflect the frugivore/folivore food habit of the host, in which the limitation of protein, i.e., @sm$ amino acid @/sm$, availability in the gut is expected (Table S1). Similar trends were observed in B. thermacidophilum genomes; domestic pig isolates apparently lost the genes for endoglucanase, beta-glucosidase, chitinase, an endoxylanase-related protein, beta-mannosidase, and pullulanase in comparison with wild boar isolates. Instead, starch-related digestive enzymes such as maltodextrin glucosidase and alpha-glucosidase were detected only in pig isolates. Wild boar isolates, thus, are apparently associated with fiber-rich omnivorous feeding behavior. In fact, cellulose and xylan comprise the major part of plant carbohydrates of the above-ground part, which comprises 70% of the plant materials consumed by wild boars. Similarly, the unique presence of genes for fiber degradation may explain the association of @gm$ B. moukalabense @/gm$ with a predicted fiber-rich intestinal environment found in wild boar isolates of B. thermacidophilum. The unique presence of genes for nucleic acid utilization in @gm$ B. moukalabense @/gm$ explains its nitrogen scavenging ability under predicted protein- and @sm$ amino acid @/sm$-limited conditions in the intestinal environment. Our results are consistent with the nature of the diets of gorillas and elephants, and to a lesser extent, with that of chimpanzees, which are composed primarily of carbohydrates and are generally limited in protein. The aforementioned differences in genomes between @gm$ B. moukalabense @/gm$ with 7 known genomes of human-associated Bifidobacterium spp. were confirmed by a comparison between @gm$ B. moukalabense @/gm$ and reconstructed meta bifidobacterial genomes.

Our results showed that the addition of LC-MVs to a starting culture of @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$, H. alvei, C. freundii, S. aureus, B. subtilis, S. epidermidis, E. feacalis reduces the biofilm biomass formed after 24 h of culture by the bacteria. For unknown reasons, we noticed that @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ was the bacteria most affected by the antibiofilm activity of L. casei MVs with an 80% decrease in biofilm biomass. Furthermore, we observed that the earlier MVs were added to @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ cultures, the lower the biofilm biomasses measured after 24 h of growth. This result suggests that LC-MVs do not disrupt already established @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ biofilms. Interestingly, the antibiofilm properties of LC-MVs were not due to bactericidal or bacteriostatic activities against @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$, suggesting a specific mechanism of inhibition. In addition, we showed that a short pretreatment of @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ with LC-MVs was enough to reduce the biofilm biomass formed after 24 h of culture, suggesting that the vesicles interact with the bacterial cells. However, the nature of the interactions between LC-MVs and @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ cells are yet to be characterized. Indeed, vesicles could attach to cell surfaces or fuse to the outer membrane of @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ as previously described for other bacteria. Taken together, these results suggest that LC-MVs impact the early stage of @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ biofilm formation by inhibiting the initial attachment of the bacteria to @sm$ polystyrene @/sm$ plate surfaces.

Our team developed an intravaginal ring (IVR) that delivers @sm$ tenofovir @/sm$ (@sm$ TFV @/sm$) (8-10 mg/day) alone or with levonorgestrel (LNG) (20 ug/day). We evaluated the effect of IVRs on the vaginal microbiota, and describe how the vaginal microbiota impacts mucosal PK of @sm$ TFV @/sm$. CONRAD A13-128 was a randomized, placebo controlled phase I study. We randomized 51 women to @sm$ TFV @/sm$, @sm$ TFV @/sm$/LNG or placebo IVR. We assessed the vaginal microbiota by sequencing the V3-V4 regions of 16S rRNA genes prior to IVR insertion and after approximately 15 days of use. We measured the concentration of @sm$ TFV @/sm$ in the cervicovaginal (CV) aspirate, and @sm$ TFV @/sm$ and TFV-diphosphate (TFV-DP) in vaginal tissue at the end of IVR use. The change in relative or absolute abundance of vaginal bacterial phylotypes was similar among active and placebo IVR users (all q values >0.13). @sm$ TFV @/sm$ concentrations in CV aspirate and vaginal tissue, and TFV-DP concentrations in vaginal tissue were not significantly different among users with community state type (CST) 4 versus those with Lactobacillus dominated microbiota (all p values >0.07). The proportions of participants with CV aspirate concentrations of @sm$ TFV @/sm$ >200,000 ng/mL and those with tissue TFV-DP concentrations >1,000 fmol/mg were similar among women with anaerobe versus Lactobacillus dominated microbiota (p = 0.43, 0.95 respectively). There were no significant correlations between the CV aspirate concentration of @sm$ TFV @/sm$ and the relative abundances of @gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$ or Prevotella species. Tissue concentrations of TFV-DP did not correlate with any the relative abundances of any species, including @gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$. In conclusion, active IVRs did not differ from the placebo IVR on the effect on the vaginal microbiota. Local @sm$ TFV @/sm$ and TFV-DP concentrations were high and similar among IVR users with Lactobacillus dominated microbiota versus CST IV vaginal microbiota.

Out of the 24 physicochemical properties modeled as machine learning targets, we observed that the presence of six elements (Cd, @sm$ Cu @/sm$, Mn, Mo, P, and Si), especially Cd, @sm$ Cu @/sm$ and Si, have a varying degree of negative impacts on the relative abundance of probiotic taxa in the fecal microbiome data (Fig. 5). Literature pertaining to the exact mechanism of action of these elements in modulating the probiotics activities is very limited. The ability of Lactobacillus and Streptococcus as probiotics to effectively bind Cd as a heavy metal and source of oxidative stress and reduce its toxicity has been demonstrated in both mice and rats. Cd has been shown to significantly reduce Lactobacillus and microbiome abundance in general. Similar to our finding here, Zhang and colleagues show that an increased level of @sm$ Cu @/sm$ decreases the abundance of genus @gm$ Parabacteroides @/gm$ in the rat microbiome while the ability of Faecalibacterium in the microbiome to detoxify arsenic, often found in complexes with @sm$ Cu @/sm$, has been demonstrated.

Over 150 species harbour proteins with CWB2 motifs, including @gm$ Clostridium difficile @/gm$, C. tetani, C. botulinum and many Peptostreptococcaceae (http://pfam.xfam.org/family/PF04122). The CWB2 motif, like the SLH motif, is complex and is incompletely conserved. SLH motifs are ~55 amino acids in length, whereas CWB2 motifs are longer, ~100 residues. However, despite performing similar functions, the two motifs share no apparent sequence homology. The @gm$ C. difficile @/gm$ cell wall proteins (CWPs) and the S-layer have been implicated as colonisation factors, enabling the bacterium to survive and proliferate in the intestine (Calabi et al., 2002; Merrigan et al., 2013; Spigaglia et al., 2013). In @gm$ C. difficile @/gm$ the family of 29 CWPs, including SlpA, the adhesin Cwp66 and the phase-variable protein CwpV all contain three tandem CWB2 motifs (Emerson et al., 2009; Fagan and Fairweather, 2011). Other CWPs contain putative peptidoglycan-modifying activities (e.g. glucosaminidases, glycohydrolases and transpeptidases) or protease activities, e.g. Cwp84 and Cwp13 (Fagan and Fairweather, 2011; Fagan et al., 2011). This family of proteins can be released from the cell using chaotropic agents such as @sm$ guanidinium @/sm$ or urea, confirming their non-covalent anchoring to the cell wall.

Over the years in DRC, MDR remained widespread in all serotypes, whereas recent data from Mali, Malawi, South-Africa, Kenya and Ghana showed MDR to be less frequent in @gm$ Salmonella Enteritidis @/gm$ or more variable over time. Since 2013, resistance to ceftriaxone and azithromycin and DCS increased substantially in O5-positive Salmonella Typhimurium in DRC. For the period 2015-2017, a third of them was resistant to ceftriaxone and azithromycin and one out of eight were DCS. @sm$ Pefloxacin @/sm$ disk diffusion methods flawlessly predicted DCS and nalidixic acid performed relatively well. A similar concurrent emergence of ceftriaxone resistance and DCS was seen in Kenya with 15% ceftriaxone resistance and 6% DCS in NTS (on a total of 281 NTS isolates) and in South-Africa with ceftriaxone resistance in 9% of Salmonella Typhimurium (n = 2420) and DCS in around 30% of NTS (Salmonella Typhimurium: n = 2420; @gm$ Salmonella Enteritidis @/gm$: n = 1149), including some fully fluoroquinolone resistant isolates In Mali, 18.2% of @gm$ Salmonella Enteritidis @/gm$ were ceftriaxone resistant.

Oxalate is endogenously produced in the liver as part of normal metabolism and is also absorbed in the intestine from oxalate-containing foods, especially when unopposed by dietary constituents, such as @sm$ calcium @/sm$, that form an insoluble complex with oxalate in the gastrointestinal tract. A direct link between intestinal bacteria and calcium oxalate kidney stone disease came after the discovery of @gm$ Oxalobacter formigenes @/gm$. This commensal intestinal bacterial species uses oxalate as its primary nutrient source because of the expression of a specialized set of enzymes capable of rapidly degrading high concentrations of the compound and prevent its absorption into circulation. A mechanism by which @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ is able to stimulate oxalate secretion from circulation back into the gut has also been suggested. However, numerous studies have investigated the colonization status of recurrent kidney stone formers and non-stone-forming controls and shown that the absence of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ alone is not causative of stone disease, as some recurrent stone formers are colonized whereas some nonstone formers are not. In fact, studies report colonization rates for patients with urinary stone disease (USD) by @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ ranging from 8% to 100% and for healthy individuals from 11% to 100%, with some studies reporting no significant differences. Furthermore, the presence of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ is associated with significantly lower urinary oxalate in only 55% of the studies that reported these results. Finally, in a recent clinical trial involving patients with primary hyperoxaluria, @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ given as a probiotic daily for 8 weeks failed to reduce urinary oxalate excretion, despite substantial recovery of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ DNA from stool samples. These results suggest that bacterial species in addition to @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ may be important to convey protection against USD.

Additionally, nine strains of P. pentosaceus were included in this analysis. The analysis of the free amino @sm$ acids @/sm$ after 3 days of incubation showed that AABA and alanine was formed in all of the samples with @gm$ P. acidilactici @/gm$ (Fig. 1). Concomitantly, serine and threonine were degraded. In addition, the concentration of phenylalanine was on average 0.2 mM lower than in the non-inoculated medium (data now shown). Penicillin resistance mediated by beta-lactamase activity has been reported previously in the anaerobic intestinal spirochaete @gm$ Brachyspira pilosicoli @/gm$, and a novel class D beta-lactamase (OXA-63) hydrolysing oxacillin was described recently in a resistant human strain from France. In the current study, 18 @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ strains from Australia and Papua New Guinea were tested for @sm$ ampicillin @/sm$ and oxacillin susceptibility, and investigated for the presence of the class D beta-lactamase gene blaOXA-63 using PCR. PCR products were amplified from seven human and four porcine strains that were penicillin resistant, but not from seven penicillin-sensitive strains. Sequence analysis of the whole gene amplified from seven of the resistant strains from humans and pigs revealed only minor nucleotide differences among them, but there were significant differences compared with blaOXA-63. The predicted amino acid sequence of the enzyme from all seven strains had the same key structural motifs as the previously reported OXA-63, but two variants with 94-95% identity with OXA-63 were identified. OXA-136 had an additional amino acid and 12 other consistent amino acid substitutions compared with OXA-63. OXA-137 had the same differences compared with OXA-63 as OXA-136, but had an additional amino acid substitution at position 16. No structures consistent with integrons or transposons were found in the nucleotide sequences in the vicinity of blaOXA-136 in partially sequenced B. pilosicoli strain 95/1000, and the GC content (25.2 mol%) of the gene was similar to that of the whole genome. The gene encoding OXA-136 from @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ strain Cof-10 conferred penicillin resistance on Escherichia coli. This study shows that penicillin resistance in human and porcine @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ strains from Australia is associated with the production of two variants of OXA-63, and that susceptible strains lack the genes encoding OXA-63 or the variants.

Phospholipids are converted into arachidonic acid and then into @sm$ prostaglandins @/sm$. Certain vaginal bacteria such as @gm$ Gardnerella @/gm$ may ascend to the uterus and secrete phospholipase A2 to act on uterine membrane phospholipids, resulting in additional @sm$ prostaglandin @/sm$ release. @sm$ Prostaglandins @/sm$ cause uterine muscle contractions, ischemia, hypoxia, and sensitization of nerve endings, all of which contribute to menstrual pain. @sm$ Prostaglandins @/sm$ may get into the circulation and may contribute to gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, bloating, change in bowel frequency). In addition to promoting the release of @sm$ prostaglandins @/sm$, certain vaginal bacteria can stimulate the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Pro-inflammatory cytokines interact with each other and with @sm$ prostaglandins @/sm$, potentially amplifying inflammation and dysmenorrhea symptoms.

Together, these data indicate that AJH120T represents a novel species within the genus @gm$ Megasphaera @/gm$.

Briefly HIV, Hepatitis B and C, CMV, and @gm$ TP @/gm$ were performed by chemiluminescence assay (ARCHITECT I 1000SR, Abbott Diagnostics, USA). TB was ruled out using culture and PCR (Biotron Health care, India) techniques. Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody tests to exclude rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus were performed in the immunology laboratory using nephelometry (BN ProSpec System, Siemens Healthineers, India) and HEp-2 cell substrate-based indirect immunofluorescence assay. "Best match" blood units were selected by Gel CAT using @sm$ DTT @/sm$-treated serum and transfused to patients as per discussed before.

Previous studies dealing with antimicrobial susceptibility testing for the genus @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ are scarce, and disc diffusion and E-test are usually applied. However, MIC testing using broth microdilution is neglected. Lack of standardization, absence of quality standards for the media used and variety in breakpoints due to cultivation with and without CO2 make detection of AMR in @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ a considerable challenge. According to our results, @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ has maintained its susceptibility to doxycycline, new glycylcycline tigecycline, @sm$ aminoglycosides @/sm$ (gentamicin), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin), and rifampicin to some extent. Rifampicin stays in combination with others, the main common treatment option of brucellosis in humans. Susceptibility of 100% of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ strains to doxycycline, tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, streptomycin, gentamicin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and levofloxacin was also reported in isolates from Saudia Arabia, Turkey, China, and Norway.

Previous studies have reported positive associations between RE and the following associated factors: older age, male gender, smoking, alcohol consumption, and hiatal hernia, and a negative association between RE and @gm$ Helicobacter pylori @/gm$ (@gm$ H. pylori @/gm$) infection. Obesity is also known to play an important role in RE. Further evidences have demonstrated that abdominal obesity, which is the core component of metabolic syndrome (MetS), may be a stronger predictor of RE than obesity. MetS is generally recognized to be a combination of metabolic abnormalities, including abdominal obesity, hypertension, hyperglycemia, reduced high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and elevated @sm$ triglycerides @/sm$ (@sm$ TG @/sm$).

Previous studies using culture and molecular methods have also observed that dentinal caries lesions can be classified according to the relative abundance of @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$. A pyrosequencing study showed that @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ was one of the 8 genera that increased significantly in cavitated dentin lesions. Another study using pyrosequencing to evaluate the microbiota associated with dentinal caries revealed that @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ species were one of the most abundant, and the species L. fermentum, L. rhamnosus and @gm$ L. crispatus @/gm$ were dominant in acidic areas of the carious dentin. Lactobacilli are acidogenic and aciduric bacteria that have been strongly associated with caries. They are not high producers of extracellular @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ and, because of their low adherence to smooth tooth surfaces, lactobacilli are more frequent in retentive areas, such as cavities.

Primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized in the liver, conjugated to @sm$ taurine @/sm$ or glycine and released into the GI tract. Gut microbiota deconjugate these primary bile acids to liberate @sm$ taurine @/sm$ or glycine. Deconjugated bile acids are further chemically modified by a variety of chemical processes including oxidation, dihydroxylation, esterification, etc., to produce secondary bile acids. The enzymatic capacity for secondary bile acid formation is distributed across various bacterial species. For example, B. fragilis and B. vulgatus perform deconjugation, and dihydroxylation is carried out by Clostridium spp. and @gm$ Eubacterium @/gm$ spp., while esterification is performed by Bacteroides spp., @gm$ Eubacterium @/gm$ spp.

L. crispatus was also directly linked to the inflammatory cytokine MIP-1alpha, and the immune cells APCs, neutrophils, and CD4+ T cells. Succinate is a metabolite that has been associated with BV, and was linked to both L. crispatus and @gm$ Gardnerella @/gm$ in this network.

Yoda-generated candidate probes were then screened for secondary structure with hybrid-ss-min, from the UNAFold package using 60 C as the folding temperature, @sm$ Sodium @/sm$ concentration of 0.6 mol/L and DNA for the -n option (defaults for all the other parameters ).

Probiotics (e.g., species of Lactobaccillus and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$) often contain a BSH activity, which is related to cholesterol-lowering effects in plasma. Some probiotics can also increase BA synthesis via direct inhibitory actions on FXR and SHP. In addition, probiotics seem to be associated with anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects and enhanced endothelial function in arteries. Besides the genera Lactobacillus and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$, lactic acid bacteria has been shown to have both fermentation productivity and antioxidant properties. Moreover, as previously described, derivates from @sm$ LCA @/sm$ can modulate T cell subsets (Figure 2):3-oxoLCA and isoLCA inhibit the differentiation of Th17 cells, while iso-alloLCA increases the differentiation of Tregs. Higher intestinal levels of these secondary BAs may be beneficial in controlling gut immune homeostasis and reducing systemic inflammation. Screening bacteria in human stool samples for their ability to convert @sm$ LCA @/sm$ into its derivates (3-oxo-, iso-, and iso-allo-LCA) using UPLC-MC traces, is a useful tool to select bacterial species as potential probiotics. Paik et al. revealed that species Eggerthella lenta and Ruminococcus gnavus are able to convert @sm$ LCA @/sm$ to 3-oxoLCA and isoLCA, while species Bacteroides fragilis convert 3-oxoLCA to isoLCA.

Probiotics also have the ability to produce @sm$ gamma-aminobutyric acid @/sm$ (@sm$ GABA @/sm$), a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. In addition, @sm$ GABA @/sm$ exhibits anti-anxiety and tranquilizing effects. Certain strains, such as Latilactobacillus curvatus K285 isolated from gat-kimchi, L. pentosus 9D3 isolated from Thai pickled weed, L. plantarum KB1253, and Companilactobacillus allii WiKim39 and Lactococcus lactis WiKim0124 isolated from kimchi have demonstrated a strong ability to produce @sm$ GABA @/sm$, making them potential starter cultures for producing functional foods. Mannitol, a 6-carbon sugar alcohol naturally present in microorganisms and plants, is slowly absorbed in intestinal tracts and does not increase blood sugar levels. Strains such as Leuconostoc mesenteroides SKP88 and @gm$ Leuconostoc citreum @/gm$ SKP92 isolated from pa (green onion)-kimchi can convert fructose to mannitol.

Probiotics directly inhibit the production of proinflammatory cytokines or indirectly reduce the abundance of the strains involved in proinflammatory processes, maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelial cell wall and lower @sm$ LPS @/sm$ levels to decrease inflammatory reactions. Specifically, Lactobacillus plantarum may increase insulin sensitivity by inhibiting the production of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-alpha). We have found that administration of probiotics can markedly decrease the abundance of @gm$ Butyrivibrio crossotus @/gm$ and Collinsella aerofaciens, both of which are engaged in the proinflammatory response; the former can activate mammalian target of rapamycin complex signalling to induce inflammation, and the latter is connected with the production of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-17 A. Bifidobacterium spp. and Lactobacillus casei are able to reduce intestinal permeability and improve intestinal epithelial cell dysfunction due to glucose transporter type 2 receptor upregulation in a dysglycaemic environment. @sm$ LPS @/sm$ is a constituent of the outer cell membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and stimulates the secretion of proinflammatory cytokines by binding to the TLR4/CD14 complex. However, probiotic supplementation was observed to markedly lower the abundance of some Gram-negative bacteria in the gut, thus reducing @sm$ LPS @/sm$ levels.

Probiotics supplementation significantly reduced @sm$ Kyn @/sm$ in the nAAC mice (Fig. 6H). An additional 2 weeks of probiotics gavage reduced plasma @sm$ Kyn @/sm$ in the GF mice transplanted with nAAC feces (Fig. 6I). S22). Thus, these bacterial species might possibly play a role in reducing plasma @sm$ Kyn @/sm$ and are worth further mechanism research. The aforementioned omics study demonstrated that probiotics effectively reconstruct the gut microbiota and reduce its @sm$ Kyn @/sm$ metabolite content.

Production of the SBAs, deoxycholic acid (DCA) and @sm$ lithocholic acid @/sm$ (@sm$ LCA @/sm$), by removing the 7alpha/beta-hyroxy group from PBAs, has been discovered in several strains, including C. scindens, C. hiranonis and C. hylemonae. Different from oxidation and epimerization, 7alpha/beta-dehydroxylation is limited to free BAs and is a multistep pathway carried out by several BA-inducible (bai) genes. Recently, @gm$ Faecalicatena contorta @/gm$ S122 (S122), which is more prevalent and abundant than C. hiranonis or C. scinden in humans, was shown to harbor putative bai operons and could convert cholic acid (CA)/chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) to DCA/@sm$ LCA @/sm$. Moreover, Eggerthella lenta is capable of oxidizing and epimerizing BA hydroxyl groups as revealed by several functional studies while "bai-like genes" have been identified in E. lenta. Recently, bai genes were identified in E. lenta, however, without any further functional characterization. Collectively, it remains inconclusive whether E. lenta could produce DCA or @sm$ LCA @/sm$.

Propionaldehyde can be converted into propanol, by propanol dehydrogenase (PduQ) or into @sm$ propionyl-CoA @/sm$, a precursor of propionate, by CoA-dependent propionaldehyde dehydrogenase (PduP). Both pduP and pduQ genes are present in the R. gnavus ATCC 29149 genome, suggesting that both propanol and propionate can be produced via the propane-1, 2-diol pathway in this bacterium (Reichardt et al., Crost et al.). Acetate, formate, and ethanol were produced in increasing amounts by R. gnavus ATCC 29149 when in monoculture with glucose or co-culture with @gm$ R. bromii @/gm$ on starch, while neither butyrate or propionate were detected in the growth conditions tested (Crost et al.).

Propionate can also be synthesized from @sm$ acrylate @/sm$ with lactate as a precursor through the @sm$ acrylate @/sm$ pathway by Megasphaera elsdenii and Coprococcus catus, and the propanediol pathway by Salmonella spp., Roseburia inulinivorans, and Ruminococcus obeum. The third major SCFA, butyrate, is generally formed by condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA via either butyrate kinase or the butyryl-CoA: acetate CoA-transferase route by bacteria such as @gm$ Coprococcus comes @/gm$ and Coprococcus eutactus.

Propionate is produced by many different gut microbes, including Veillonella spp., @gm$ Coprococcus catus @/gm$ and Salmonella spp.. Propionate-producing microbes use either the propanediol pathway from deoxyhexose sugars, such as fucose and rhamnose, the succinate pathway by converting succinate to methylmalonyl-CoA, or the acrylate pathway, in which lactate is reduced to propionate. Valerate, a rather poorly studied metabolite, can be produced by Clostridium cluster I and its fermentation involves propionate coupling with ethanol. @sm$ Valproate @/sm$ is a branched SCFA generated from valerate. @sm$ Valproate @/sm$ is not naturally generated upon microbial fermentation, but rather is synthetically produced. @sm$ Valproate @/sm$ is extensively used clinically for the treatment of epilepsy and seizures, but has also been investigated as an adjuvant agent for many other pathologies, such as cancer or HIV therapy, based on its action as an HDAC (histone deacetylase) inhibitor.

Protozoan concentrations increased in S ponies at 92 gd, which could have had an important physiological consequence, especially in host @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ metabolism (Dougal et al.,), or have an unclear clinical significance. It could be that strongyle infection makes the large intestine a more suitable environment for commensal protozoa. It has been observed in chimpanzees that a positive correlation between intestinal parasites and commensal protozoa arose from complex interactions mediated by the host immune response and competition among taxa (McLennan et al.,). In horses, Guiris et al. have shown that helminths cohabit with commensal protozoa in the gastrointestinal tract in natural conditions. In line with the seemingly symbiotic relationship between H. polygyrus and bacteria from the family Lactobacillaceae in mice (Reynolds et al.,), it could be speculated that strongyle and protozoa may contribute to each other's success in the ecological niche of the equine intestines. Variations in protozoan concentrations might also reflect host adaptations for nutrient accessibility and acquisition during infection. In fact, protozoa have an important role in pectin degradation although have a limited role in cellulose digestion (Julliand et al.,). The key contribution of @gm$ Treponema @/gm$, a non-pathogenic @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ metabolizing bacteria (Han et al.,), to the co-occurrence network of S ponies at 92 gd also suggests that compensatory mechanisms were induced to degrade fiber and supply the host with micro and macronutrients needed to face the infection.

Putrescine is also a precursor of @sm$ spermidine @/sm$ and spermine. The polyamines putrescine, @sm$ spermidine @/sm$, spermine, and cadaverine are essential components of living cells, and play an important role in the formation of nucleic acid, protein synthesis, and membrane stability. Of the various biogenic amines detected in a variety of fruits, juices, and vegetables, putrescine was the most common. Kalac reported that putrescine was commonly found in frozen spinach puree (average 12.9 mg/kg), ketchup (average 52.5 mg/kg), concentrated tomato paste (average 25.9 mg/kg), and frozen green pea (average 46.3 mg/kg). The putrescine content of fermented foods and beverages was found to be 9 mg/kg (3-25 mg/kg, n = 28) in sherry, 154 mg/kg (6-550 mg/kg, n = 8) in sauerkraut, 19 mg/kg (1-71 mg/kg, n = 8) in Dutch cheese, and 52 mg/kg (1-190 mg/kg, n = 14) in fermented sausage. Furthermore, the putrescine found in the traditional cheeses made from ewe's whole milk in Sardinia, Italy, increased to 1658 mg/L during ripening. @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ spps. (i.e., @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ CCDM 94, B. adolescentis CCDM 223, B. animalis ssp. lactis CCDM 239, 240, 241, and 374, B. bifidum CCDM 559, and B. longum CCDM 569) are known to produce cadaverine, putrescine, tyramine, and @sm$ spermidine @/sm$.

Raw milk from 27 farms was sampled over 6 months for listerias, salmonellas, @gm$ Yersinia enterocolitica @/gm$ and campylobacters. Total bacterial counts and somatic cell counts were measured. Lactococci, lactobacilli, dextran-producing leuconostocs, Brevibacterium linens, yeasts and moulds, Staphylococcus aureus and other Micrococcaceae, Pseudomonas, coliforms, Escherichia coli, enterococci, Clostridium perfringens and spores of anaerobic @sm$ lactate @/sm$-fermenting bacteria were also counted. Pseudomonas (2000 cfu ml-1), lactococci (760 cfu ml-1) and Micrococcaceae (720 cfu ml-1) were the most numerous groups. Lactic acid bacteria were detected in all samples. Coliforms were present in most samples, but 84% of samples had counts < 100 cfu ml-1. Staphylococcus aureus was detected in 62% of milks, the average count was 410 cfu ml-1. About 80% of supplies had < or = 10 E. coli cfu ml-1 and all samples had < or = 1 Cl. perfringens cfu ml-1. Two of the tested milks were positive for salmonellas (2.9%), four were positive for Listeria monocytogenes (5.8%), 25 for @gm$ Yersinia enterocolitica @/gm$ (36%) and one for campylobacters (1.4%).

Recently, @sm$ lipid @/sm$ profiling has emerged as a way to complement bacterial identification where protein-based methods fail to provide accurate results. This study aimed to address the challenge of rapid discrimination between Escherichia coli and Shigella spp. using MALDI-TOF MS in the negative ion mode for @sm$ lipid @/sm$ profiling coupled with machine learning. Both E. coli and @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ species are closely related; they share high sequence homology, reported for 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities between E. coli and Shigella spp. exceeding 99%, and a similar protein expression pattern but are epidemiologically distinct. A bacterial collection of 45 E. coli, 48 @gm$ Shigella flexneri @/gm$, and 62 Shigella sonnei clinical isolates were submitted to @sm$ lipid @/sm$ profiling in negative ion mode using the MALDI Biotyper Sirius  system after treatment with mild-acid hydrolysis (acetic acid 1% v/v for 15 min at 98 C). Spectra were then analyzed using our in-house machine learning algorithm and top-ranked features used for the discrimination of the bacterial species. Here, as a proof-of-concept, we showed that @sm$ lipid @/sm$ profiling might have the potential to differentiate E. coli from @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ species using the analysis of the top five ranked features obtained by MALDI-TOF MS in the negative ion mode of the MALDI Biotyper Sirius  system. Based on this new approach, MALDI-TOF MS analysis of @sm$ lipids @/sm$ might help pave the way toward these goals.

Recently, ccas (gene locus_tag: AXCY01000026.1, protein ID: KGM11272.1) and btas (gene locus_tag: BTHE_RS02440, protein ID: WP_044279707.1) genes from Cellulomonas carboniz T26 and @gm$ Bifidobacterium thermophilum @/gm$ @gm$ ATCC 25525 @/gm$, respectively, were cloned in E. coli through sequence analysis, and each enzyme showed typical AS activity (Choi et al.,; Wang et al.,). Summary information and comparisons of the cloned AS genes are presented in Table 1. The enzyme characteristics of the microbial AS were studied with recombinant protein expression in E. coli. In most studies, the optimal temperature, pH, and enzyme units were measured using the simple 3,5-dinitrosalicylic acid (@sm$ DNS @/sm$) method to measure the ability of AS to utilize sucrose as a sole substrate. There is a difference in the enzyme measurement methodologies between research groups, and it is thus difficult to compare the exact AS activity levels. This review discusses the activity of AS when the activity were measured by the same experimental method. Most of the AS showed optimum enzyme activities in neutral conditions of pH 7.0-8.0 (Table 1). Interestingly, the BtAS present in @gm$ Bifidobacterium thermophilum @/gm$ cultured under acidic conditions, showed optimal activity at weakly acidic conditions of pH 6.0 (Choi et al.,).

Antimicrobial efficacy via different delivery systems (passive and active sintering of the vapor) was determined in water, and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis of the antimicrobial components (@sm$ linalool @/sm$, citral, and beta-pinene) was conducted. There was up to a 5-log cells ml(-1) reduction in Legionella spp. in soil after exposure to the citrus EO vapors (15 mg/liter air). The most susceptible strain in water was L. pneumophila, with a 4-log cells ml(-1) reduction after 24 h via sintering (15 g/liter air). Sintering the vapor through water increased the presence of the antimicrobial components, with a 61% increase of @sm$ linalool @/sm$.

Reports show that the intestinal bacteria can elaborate a plethora of neurotransmitters including dopamine, gamma-amino butyrate, norepinephrine, @sm$ acetylcholine @/sm$, and serotonin that can affect mood as well as short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) (e.g., butyrate) and hormones such as cortisol and chemicals that modulate the immune system (e.g., quinolinic acid). Resistance of @gm$ A. hydrophila @/gm$ to broad-spectrum cephalosporins or carbapenems has been reported, though it is uncommon in @gm$ A. hydrophila @/gm$ isolates. In this study, all three isolates exhibited resistance to @sm$ imipenem @/sm$, piperacillin/tazobactam sodium, ceftriaxone, ceftazidime, cefuroxime sodium, and cefoxitin. Three patients had severe spinal infections with fever; meropenem was administered since @sm$ imipenem @/sm$ is contraindicated for increased risk of neurological infection. Therefore, the emergence of this multidrug-resistant @gm$ A. hydrophila @/gm$ may have an impact on therapeutic decisions.

Resistance to @sm$ aminoglycosides @/sm$ in @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ occurs through the production of efflux pumps, @sm$ aminoglycoside @/sm$ modifying enzymes that work via adenylation, acetylation or phosphorylation of target drugs, or by the production of 16SrRNA methylase, an enzyme that blocks the binding of @sm$ aminoglycoside @/sm$ antibiotics to the 30S ribosomal subunit. In contrast to the narrow-spectrum of activity of the modifying enzymes, 16SrRNA methylase confers extremely high levels of resistance to nearly all @sm$ aminoglycosides @/sm$, including tobramycin, gentamicin and amikacin, which are commonly used in clinical practice.

Cefotaxime was described to have a lower in vitro bactericidal activity compared with ampicillin, gentamicin, and imipenem, and its susceptibility was described as intermediate in 12-62% of studied strains in Canada and France, respectively (Spelhaug et al.,; Tremblay et al.,; Gazaigne et al.,). This fact confirmed the possibility of transient @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ bacteremia, resolved without antimicrobial therapy.

Resistant maltodextrin and inulin produced the greatest increase in total SCFA levels followed by resistant @sm$ starch @/sm$ and rice bran (Fig. 2b and Supplementary Table S1). Each fiber type had a distinct metabolic signature: resistant @sm$ starch @/sm$ was highly butyrogenic, resistant maltodextrin was highly propiogenic, and inulin and rice bran promoted the production of all three SCFA (Fig. 2c-f and Supplementary Table S1). Although rice bran produced less SCFA than the other fibers, it increased the abundance of unique bacteria that were not enriched by other fibers (e.g., @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$, Dorea, Fusobacterium). Thus, to support the growth of a diverse group of beneficial bacterial groups and promote the production of all three SCFA, the following fiber mixture composition was used: 30% resistant @sm$ starch @/sm$ (raw potato @sm$ starch @/sm$), 30% resistant maltodextrin (NutrioseTM), 30% stabilized rice bran, and 10% agave branched inulin.

Ruminococcus bromii generates @sm$ formate @/sm$, acetate, and ethanol when provided resistant starch. When co-cultured with @gm$ Blautia hydrogenotrophica @/gm$, @sm$ formate @/sm$ was consumed and additional acetate was produced. A consequence of sugar fermentation is the generation of H2. Fermentation efficiency is reduced as H2 accumulates, inhibiting bacterial NADH-dependent dehydrogenases. Mutualism between B. thetaiotaomicron and D. piger has been reported. In co-colonized mice, B. thetaiotaomicron increases the fitness of D. piger by providing sulfate, compensating for the lack of sulfatase functions encoded by the D. piger genome. D. piger consumes H2 thus allowing fermentation efficiency of B. thetaiotaomicron to be maintained. Moreover, the activities of some species alter the metabolic preferences of others. S-equol is produced as a result of the breakdown of dietary isoflavones such as daidzein and @sm$ genistein @/sm$ by gut bacteria. S-equol production requires a complete set of enzymes daidzein reductase dihydrodaidzein reductase and tetrahydrodaidzein reductase to metabolize daidzein to S-equol. @sm$ Genistein @/sm$ was found to be catalyzed at an even higher rate by daidzein reductase compared to daidzein. Our previous study showed that both isoflavone-metabolizing bacteria and their product is required for EAE suppression. Even though rodents can efficiently produce S-equol from phytoestrogen metabolism we did not find well-known bacterial "equol producers" such as Adlercreutzia equolifaciens, @gm$ Eggerthella @/gm$ species Slackia isoflavoniconvertens and Lactococcus garvieae that were differentially enriched at baseline between the ISO and PF fed mice or at endpoint after the diet change.

S-layer proteins are found in most bacteria, such as @gm$ L. helveticus @/gm$, L. acidophilus, L. bulgaricus and L. brevis (Johnson et al.). Most S-layer proteins can be broken down via their @sm$ hydrogen @/sm$ bonds using high concentrations of solvents to achieve separation (Baumeister et al.).

SCFAs are bacterial metabolic products known to play a critical role in host-intestinal immunity and function and previous reports have highlighted @gm$ O. splanchnicus @/gm$ as a significant SCFA-producer. To determine the metabolic function of our clinical isolates, germ-free mice were mono-colonized with patient-derived @gm$ O. splanchnicus @/gm$, A. finegoldii or B. producta for 10 days. As expected, a significantly higher abundance of @sm$ acetate @/sm$, butyrate and propionate was detected in cecal contents of @gm$ O. splanchnicus @/gm$ mono-colonized mice compared to germ-free controls (Figure 5A). While B. producta mono-colonized mice had similar SCFA levels to that observed in germ-free mice, mono-colonization with A. finegoldii led to significantly higher production of @sm$ acetate @/sm$ and lower butyrate and propionate compared to @gm$ O. splanchnicus @/gm$ (Figure 5A).

SCFAs are defined as groups of fatty acids comprising less than six carbons, mainly @sm$ acetate @/sm$, propionate, and butyrate. These three fatty acids accounted for more than 95% of the total SCFAs, with a ratio of 60:20:20. However, this proportion was not constant, as it relies on many factors, such as dietary components, microbiota composition, and the site of fermentation. @sm$ Acetate @/sm$ is most abundant in the colon, accounting for more than half of the total SCFAs detected in feces and can be formed through two major pathways: the acetyl-CoA and Wood-Ljungdahl pathways. Bacteroides spp., Bifidobacterium spp Ruminococcus spp., @gm$ Blautia hydrogenotrophica @/gm$, and Clostridium spp. are involved in these two pathways. Aacetogenic bacteria can also synthesize @sm$ acetate @/sm$ from carbon dioxide and formate through the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway.

SCFAs are fatty acids with fewer than six carbons produced by bacteria, such as @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$, Clostridium, and Lactobacillus during polysaccharide fermentation in the colon. The main SCFAs produced by GIM are @sm$ acetate @/sm$, propionate, and butyrate, which are absorbed through the intestine before being circulated to the liver and other organs, namely, the brain.

SCFAs are involved in maintaining intestinal mucosal integrity, controlling glucose, @sm$ lipid @/sm$, and energy metabolism, and regulating the immune system and inflammatory responses based on multiple pathways, such as the G protein-coupled receptor family, and epigenetic modification by acting as a histone deacetylase inhibitor. Most acetates and propionates are mainly derived from the gut microbiota of phylum Bacteroidetes, such as species Blautia hydrogenotrophica, Methanobrevibacter smithii, Eubacterium hallii, and @gm$ Eubacterium cylindroides @/gm$, whereas phylum Firmicutes, the main producers of butyrate, includes species Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, Roseburia intestinalis, and Ruminococcus gnavus.

SCFAs can be synthesized in the oral cavity using two primary approaches: @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ hydrolysis or amino acid metabolism. @sm$ Carbohydrates @/sm$ undergo fermentation, leading to the formation of monosaccharides, followed by the conversion to pyruvate through either the pentose phosphate pathway (C5) or glycolysis (C6). Bacterial species with the capability to convert sugars into SCFAs include Streptococcus, Actinomyces, Lactobacillus, Propionibacterium, and @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$.

SCFAs, such as @sm$ acetate @/sm$, proprionate, and butyrate, exert multiple beneficial physiological effects in the host: acting as anti-inflammatory agents, supporting the barrier function of intestinal epithelial cells, serving as modulators of chemotaxis and adhesion of immune cells, promoting GI motility through direct inhibition of G-coupled-receptors, inhibiting histone deacetylases, and serving as energy substrates for intestinal epithelial cells. SCFAs produced by @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and cross-fed microbial communities also act as general growth suppressants for a variety of gut pathogens. These same SCFAs may slow bacterial translocation from the intestine, limiting the scope of infection through enhanced epithelial barrier function. Other metabolites of B. bifidum and @gm$ B. crudilactis @/gm$ produced from fermented 3'-SL suppress expression of virulence factors found in E. coli and Salmonella. The presence of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ is associated with broad changes in gene expression within the neonatal intestine.

SCZ gut microbiota were notably enriched in Flavonifractor plautii, @gm$ Collinsella aerofaciens @/gm$, Bilophila wadsworthia, and Sellimonas intestinalis, while depleted in Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, Ruminococcus lactaris, Ruminococcus bicirculans, and Veillonella rogosae. Functional potential of the gut microbiota accounted for 11% of cognition variability. In particular, the bacterial functional module for synthesizing tyrosine, a precursor for @sm$ dopamine @/sm$, was in SCZ cases positively associated with cognitive score (rho = 0.34, q <= .1).

SD_Bt-00002, predicted to belong to the genus @gm$ Ethanoligenens @/gm$ of the family Ruminococcaceae, was identified from the rumen of cow C. Originally isolated from the anaerobic sludge of molasses wastewater, @gm$ E. harbinense @/gm$ is thus far the only cultured representative of its genus. It is capable of fermenting various mono-, di- and oligosaccharides, including d-glucose and cellobiose, into ethanol, @sm$ acetate @/sm$, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide. Based on these metabolic activities, co-enrichment of an uncharacterized species of @gm$ Ethanoligenens @/gm$ suggests that it may benefit from the cellulose metabolizing activity of other rumen bacteria, such as perhaps SD_Bt-00003 and/or SD_Bt-00004, that were also enriched from the same animal. These results would be consistent with reports from other research groups. Indeed, @gm$ E. harbinense @/gm$ was found to be among the main species enriched in the second generation of a repeated-batch culture of ruminal fluid supplemented with napiergrass, and an @gm$ Ethanoligenens @/gm$-related OTU was recently identified from rumen fluid supplemented with wheat straw. While SD_Bt-00002 and other uncharacterized rumen species of @gm$ Ethanoligenens @/gm$ may be capable of metabolizing cellulose, future investigations will be required to determine their metabolic activities in the gastro-intestinal tract of ruminants.

STATEMENT OF PROBLEM: Acid producing bacteria including @gm$ Streptococcus mutans @/gm$ and lactobacilli cause tooth demineralization and lead to tooth decay. Also, oral colonization of the species of Candida has been reported in many studies that are resistant to antifungal agents. OBJECTIVES: In this study, antibacterial and antifungal effects of nano-CuO were studied against some oral bacteria and yeast fungi. MATERIALS AND METHODS: The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) of copper oxide nanoparticles (CuO NPs) for oral bacterial and fungal test strains were determined in 96-well microtiter plate technique. The agar diffusion test (ADT) was employed to assess the antifungal properties of @sm$ nystatin @/sm$. RESULTS: The MIC50 value of CuO NPs was determined at the range of 1-10 microg/ml for @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$, < 1 microg/ml for L. acidophilus, and 10 microg/ml for L. casei. Higher concentrations of CuO NPs (100-1000 microg/ml) were effective on the bacterial cell growth, resulting in 100% reduction in the optical density in TSB medium. The cells of Candida albicans, C. krusei and C. glabrata were treated with CuO NPs and the results showed a decrease in fungal growth at a concentration of 1-1000 microg/ml in TSB medium. The MIC50 value of CuO NPs was determined 1000 microg/ml for three species of Candida. The diameter of growth inhibition zones of 1100 microg/ml @sm$ nystatin @/sm$ was obtained 15-21 mm for clinical isolates of three species of Candida.

Seaweeds are rich in @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ such as alginates, fucoidans, and sulfated galactans. Although there are no studies in humans of the effect of seaweeds and @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ in them on gut microbiota, a study in rats showed that intake of Laminaria japonica increased the abundance of lactic acid-producing bacteria such as @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$ and Streptococcus. @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$ reportedly assimilates a wide range of carbohydrates and uses enzymes such as beta-glucosidase and beta-galactosidase in their degradation of carbohydrates. No studies have reported on the assimilation of @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ by @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$, but we found a positive association between intake of seaweeds and the number of @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$ (Table 4). Therefore, @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ in seaweeds are likely to affect the number of @gm$ Subdoligranulum @/gm$.

Second, we found the phylum Verrucomicrobia and the corresponding genus @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ to be virtually absent in Ag-treated rats, whereas @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ accounted for 1-4% of the total gut microbiomes in untreated controls and in @sm$ SiO2 @/sm$-treated animals in close accordance to established levels for @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ municiphila. Although the observed alterations could not be proven to be statistically significant due to individual variations in the vehicle control group, it should remain under consideration for future studies that @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ may be strongly affected by an oral uptake of Ag nanomaterials. Comparable effects have been reported for different metals (Al, Cu, Pb, Cd), where subchronic oral exposures greatly reduced abundance of @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ in mice (for review see). @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ contributes to the host immune system and stimulates the proliferation of anti-inflammatory regulatory T-cells in mice. In numerous studies, abundance of @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ was found to be reduced in various intestinal diseases, such as Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) or appendicitis as well as in extra-intestinal diseases like obesity, autism or atopy.

Sera positive for the mRBPT were further tested with CFT for confirmation using the standard Brucella @gm$ abortus @/gm$ antigen (New Haw, Addleston, Surrey KT15 3NB, UK). The CFT test proper and reagent preparation procedures followed the procedures outlined by the OIE. A sheep red blood cell (1%) suspension was prepared before the beginning of the test, and test sera with >= 50% sedimentation at a dilution of 1:5 and above were considered to be positive. The reading was: complete fixation (no hemolysis) with a @sm$ water @/sm$-clear supernatant was recorded as + + + +, nearly complete fixation (75% clearing) as + + +, partial hemolysis (50%) as + + and some fixation (25% clearing) as +.

Serum biochemistry confirmed the metabolic switch from carbohydrates to @sm$ fatty acids @/sm$ and ketones. Emotional and physical well-being were enhanced. Faecal 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing showed that fasting caused a decrease in the abundance of bacteria known to degrade dietary polysaccharides such as Lachnospiraceae and Ruminococcaceae. There was a concomitant increase in Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria (Escherichia coli and @gm$ Bilophila wadsworthia @/gm$), known to use host-derived energy substrates.

Serum metabolites differentially expressed with glyphosate treatment were associated with nicotinamide, branched-chain amino acid, methionine, cysteine, and @sm$ taurine @/sm$ metabolism, indicative of a response to oxidative stress. MON 52276 had similar, but more pronounced, effects than glyphosate on the serum metabolome. Shotgun metagenomics of the cecum showed that treatment with glyphosate and MON 52276 resulted in higher levels of Eggerthella spp., Shinella zoogleoides, @gm$ Acinetobacter johnsonii @/gm$, and Akkermansia muciniphila.

Several abundant saturated fatty acids were also identified, including hexadecanoic acid (C16:0, 30%), @sm$ octadecanoic acid @/sm$ (@sm$ C18:0 @/sm$, 7%), tetradecanoic acid (C14:0, 13%), and dodecanoic acid (C12:0, 6%) (Table S1). By comparison, @gm$ C. aerofaciens @/gm$, C. intestinalis, and C. stercoris possessed @sm$ octadecanoic acid @/sm$ as major fatty acid (Nagai et al., 2010).

Several bacterial genera that are common in the distal intestine (e.g., @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$, Bifidobacterium, and Enterococcus) are known to synthesize vitamins. @sm$ Thiamine @/sm$, folate, biotin, riboflavin, and panthothenic acid are water-soluble vitamins that are plentiful in the diet, but that are also synthesized by gut bacteria.

Several bacterial species, e.g., Escherichia, Salmonella, @gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$, possess specific enzymes to produce @sm$ H2S. @/sm$ A phosphate-sulfite reductase maintains the redox balance by reducing sulfite to @sm$ H2S @/sm$ and NADP+ or oxidizing @sm$ H2S @/sm$ to sulfite and recovering NADPH. Bacteria expressing cysteine desulfhydrase convert cysteine to @sm$ H2S @/sm$, pyruvate and ammonia. Bilophila wadsworthia utilizes taurine by taurine:pyruvate aminotransferase to sulfoacetaldhyde and alanine, which is further metabolized by sulfoacetaldhyde sulfolyase to sulfite and acetate. Subsequent sulfite reduction by sulfite reductase produces @sm$ H2S @/sm$ and CO2. Tissue enzymes also metabolize methionine to homocysteine, which is coupled with serine to form cystathionine by cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS). Cystathionine gamma-lyase (CSE) subsequently converts cystathionine to cysteine, which CBS or CSE may further transform to @sm$ H2S. @/sm$ Half of the luminal @sm$ H2S @/sm$ is produced by gut microbiota and half by colonic tissues. Interestingly, the inhibition of the colonic tissue enzymes promotes the production of @sm$ H2S @/sm$ by gut microbiota.

Several evidences (both in vivo and in vitro) suggest the involvement of fluoroquinolones in the inhibition of @sm$ LPS @/sm$-induced tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha and several interleukins, such as IL-1 and IL-6 production. One of the critical components in acne is host-mediated inflammation. @gm$ C. acnes @/gm$ is known to induce inflammatory cytokine expression, including TNFalpha, IL-6, IL-8 and IL-12, in macrophages via activation of TLR-2. The role of IL-6 in @gm$ C. acnes @/gm$-induced cell lines, such as macrophages, keratinocytes and sebocytes, has been shown in multiple reports. Alestas et al. found enhanced IL-6 expression in acne-involved skin. The IL-1 family of cytokines has been found to be associated with tissue damage in acne patients. VB-1953 was found to reduce dead @gm$ C. acnes @/gm$-induced inflammation in both in vitro and in vivo models. This action is independent of its bactericidal action. In vitro, VB-1953 significantly reduced IL-6 levels in the human monocyte cell line THP-1. Furthermore, VB-1953 showed a dose-dependent reduction in messenger RNA (mRNA) expression of IL-1alpha, IL-1beta, IL-6, IL-8 and IL-12 in THP-1 cells (unpublished data). VB-1953 formulation was also found to exert anti-inflammatory effects in a dead @gm$ C. acnes @/gm$-induced rat paw edema model (unpublished data).

This suggests an important role for @sm$ pyruvate @/sm$ in host inflammation and infection.

Shigella is a gram-negative, @sm$ lactose @/sm$-negative, facultative intracellular pathogen, closely related to Escherichia coli (E. coli). It was recognized as the etiologic agent of bacillary dysentery or shigellosis in the 1890s, and in the 1950s, Shigella was adopted as a genus and subgrouped into four species (spp.): Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella flexnerii, @gm$ Shigella boydii @/gm$, and Shigella sonnei.

Short chain fatty acids (SCFA) are volatile fatty acids consisting of a straight-chain, aliphatic tail of fewer than six @sm$ carbon @/sm$ atoms and are produced by fermentation of oligosaccharide concomitant with increases in beneficial bacteria including @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$.

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are major end-products of anaerobic fermentation by microbiota in the large intestine, including acetic acid, propionic acid, isobutyric acid, butyric acid, isovaleric acid, @sm$ valeric acid @/sm$ and hexanoic acid. Acetic acid is produced by most enteric bacteria, such as acetogenic bacteria through the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway. But propionic acid is mainly produced by Bacteroides and Propionibacterium through succinate pathway. Butyrate-producing bacteria mainly include Faecalibacterium, Eubacterium, and Roseburia genera, whereas Roseburia Inulinivorans and @gm$ Coprococcus Catus @/gm$ are able to produce propionic acid and butyric acid.

Shredded carrots were inoculated with approximately 6-7 log CFU/g of @gm$ Escherichia coli O157:H7 @/gm$ (932, and 933) and Listeria monocytogenes (ATCC 19116, and 19111) and then dip treated with alkaline electrolyzed water (AlEW), acidic electrolyzed water (AcEW), 100 ppm @sm$ sodium hypochlorite @/sm$ (@sm$ NaOCl @/sm$), deionized water (DaIW), or 1% citric acid (CA) alone or with combinations of AlEW and 1% CA (AlEW + CA). The populations of spoilage bacteria on the carrots were investigated after various exposure times (1, 3, and 5 min) and treatment at different dipping temperatures (1, 20, 40, and 50  C) and then optimal condition (3 min at 50  C) was applied against foodborne pathogens on the carrots. When compared to the untreated control, treatment AcEW most effectively reduced the numbers of total bacteria, yeast and fungi, followed by AlEW and 100 ppm @sm$ NaOCl @/sm$. Exposure to all treatments for 3 min significantly reduced the numbers of total bacteria, yeast and fungi on the carrots. As the dipping temperature increased from 1  C to 50  C, the reductions of total bacteria, yeast and fungi increased significantly from 0.22 to 2.67 log CFU/g during the wash treatment (p <= 0.05). The combined 1% citric acid and AlEW treatment at 50  C showed a reduction of the total bacterial count and the yeast and fungi of around 3.7 log CFU/g, as well as effective reduction of L. monocytogenes (3.97 log CFU/g), and @gm$ E. Coli O157:H7 @/gm$ (4 log CFU/g).

Since @gm$ C. difficile @/gm$ colonizes the large intestinal surface and the intestine is recognized as the initial site of infection, it is postulated that antigen specific IgA may play a role in the protection against the colonization of @gm$ C. difficile @/gm$ in the intestine. However, within these studies, we did not determine if antigen specific IgA was present in the gut at time of challenge. Challenge studies, using both acute and relapsing models of disease in mice showed that vaccination did not influence colonization or persistence. The failure of this approach suggests that either immunity to the glycosylated BclA3 protein is not protective, however, it could also indicate that presentation of the antigen is insufficient to stimulate sufficient levels of immunity to drive protection. Recently, Broecker, et al. and Monteiro reported protection against C. difficile was achievable by vaccination using glycans of the surface polysaccharides of @gm$ C. difficile @/gm$, @sm$ PS-I @/sm$, PS-II, and PS-III.

Since GABA and @sm$ glutamate @/sm$ are important molecules linking the carbohydrate and amino acid metabolic pathways, the consumption or production of 36 compounds including glucose, SCFA, amino acids, and biogenic amines was measured in the supernatants of mYCFA and mYCFA-@sm$ Glu @/sm$ cultures (Supplementary Data File 1). As expected, a significant correlation (r = -0.99; p < 0.001) between @sm$ glutamate @/sm$ and GABA levels was observed, further highlighting the nature of @sm$ glutamate @/sm$ as primary precursor of GABA. However, no other metabolites strongly correlated with GABA levels (-0.60 <= r <= 0.65; Supplementary Figure S2). @sm$ Glutamate @/sm$ was primarily consumed for the production of GABA, with high GABA yield coefficients (YGABA/@sm$ Glu @/sm$) ranging from 0.769 to 0.993 (mol/mol) after 48 h for the high producers B. faecis PB-SESWS, B. fragilis PB-SZSJC, B. ovatus DSM 1896, and @gm$ B. xylanisolvens @/gm$ @gm$ DSM 18836 @/gm$. B. plebeius PB-SLKZP was the only strain accumulating @sm$ glutamate @/sm$ (Supplementary Table S1). The final pH was variable across strains, ranging from 4.8 (B. vulgatus DSM 1447, mYCFA) to 6.4 (B. ovatus DSM 1896, mYCFA-@sm$ Glu @/sm$), and correlated with @sm$ glutamate @/sm$ (r = -0.82; p < 0.001) and GABA (r = 0.85; p < 0.001) levels (Supplementary Figure S3), thus providing initial evidence of the association between GABA production and pH regulation in Bacteroides.

Since the acidic environment of the stomach is an important protection barrier against foodborne pathogen infections in hosts, we evaluated whether TolC played a role in the acid tolerance of @gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$. Comparison of the acid tolerance of the tolC mutant and the parental wild-type strain showed that the absence of TolC limits the ability of @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ to sustain life under extreme acidic conditions. Additionally, the mutant exhibited morphological changes during growth in an acidic medium, leading to the conflicting results of cell viability measured by spectrophotometry and colony-forming unit counting. Reverse-transcriptional-PCR analysis indicated that acid-related molecules, apparatus, or enzymes and oxidation-induced factors were significantly affected by the acidic environment in the null-tolC mutant. The elongated cellular morphology was restored by adding antioxidants to the culture medium. Furthermore, we found that increased cellular antioxidative activity provides an overlapping protection against acid killing, demonstrating the complexity of the bacterial acid stress response. Our findings reinforce the multifunctional characteristics of TolC in acid tolerance or oxidative stress resistance and support the correlative protection mechanism between @sm$ oxygen @/sm$- and acid-mediated stress responses in @gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$.

Since the use of antimicrobial agents is required in endodontic therapies, this study aimed at determining the minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) of chlorhexidine digluconate and @sm$ paramonochlorophenol @/sm$ (PMC) against microorganisms commonly found in endodontic infections. Both agents were tested by agar dilution tests against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, Candida albicans, Prevotella intermedia, @gm$ Porphyromonas gingivalis @/gm$, Porphyromonas endodontalis, Prevotella denticola and Prevotella melaninogenica.

Sinigrin hydrolysis by plant or bacterial myrosinase yields @sm$ allyl isothiocyanate @/sm$ (@sm$ AITC @/sm$) which is bactericidal. In silico analysis using public databases found sequence similarity between plant myrosinase and enzymes encoded by genes from beta-glucosidase families in @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$. Specifically, 6-phospho-beta-glucosidase encoded by the genes bglA and ascB (family 1), and chbF (family 4) present in @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ showed the highest similarity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) confirmed the presence of bglA, ascB, and chbF in the clinical E. coli strain tested. Disruption of these genes in wild-type E. coli O157:H7 strain 02-0304 using lambda-red replacement created single and double mutants. The relative importance of each gene in the hydrolysis of sinigrin by @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ was also assessed by comparing gene expression and sinigrin degradation rates among the @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ wild-type strain and its mutants.

Six microorganisms that produced acetoin or @sm$ diacetyl @/sm$ or both from glucose were tested for the production of 2,3-butylene glycol from lactose. Bacillus polymyxa and @gm$ Streptococcus faecalis @/gm$ gave positive results and were tested in unmodified wheys. Cottage cheese whey was unsatisfactory, but B. polymyxa produced large amounts of the glycol in sweet whey, about 60 mmol of glycol per 100 mmol of lactose utilized. Aeration and an increased ratio of surface area to volume of whey enhanced the production of glycol. 2,3-Butylene was separated from the spent whey and from acetoin and @sm$ diacetyl @/sm$ with a Sephadex G-10 column.

Snippy uses the Burrows-Wheelers Aligner and SAMtools to align reads of the 53 NZ @gm$ L. longbeachae @/gm$ isolates to our reference genome Legionella longbeachae F1157CHC and FreeBayes to identify variants among the alignments. Gubbins was used to remove areas of recombination on the full alignment. SNPs were exported into BEAUti v2.5 to create an Extensive Markup Language (xml) file for BEAST v2.5. So far, studies on the effect of @sm$ flavones @/sm$ on gut microbiota are lacking. However, studies reporting the beneficial role of other flavonoids as potent gut microbiota modifiers are emerging. For example, quercetin reduced the microbiota composition including the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio and the growth of species associated with diet-induced obesity like Erysipelotrichaceae, Bacillus, and @gm$ Eubacterium cylindroides @/gm$, while restoring the barrier integrity in obese NAFLD model. In HFD/high sucrose-induced obesity models, polyphenol-rich cranberry extract diet and concord grape anthocyanins inhibited insulin resistance and inflammation by mediating an increase in Akkermansia muciniphila in the gut microbiota. Anthocyanins from plum and peach juices decreased fecal short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), a subset of key gut microbiota metabolites, including acetate, propionate, and butyrate, and modified the bacterial composition of the microbiota, by increasing the population of Faecalibacterium, Lactobacillus, and Bacteroidetes. Several flavonoids are shown to enrich beneficial bacterial abundance while reducing potential detrimental microbes in the human gut. Quercetin and resveratrol decreased the Enterobacteriaceae family and reduced the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio in the human gut, as shown through the 16S rRNA sequencing of fecal samples. Diet supplementation with soy bars significantly enhances the abundance of beneficial Bifidobacterium bacteria in postmenopausal women, which results in increased lipid catabolism. The ability of other flavonoids to regulate dysbiosis establishes a promising platform, urging the investigation of the potential of @sm$ flavones @/sm$ in the regulation of the gut microbiota.

Some Ruminococcus species are non-cellulolytic, including @gm$ Ruminococcus callidus @/gm$ and Ruminococcus bicirculans. @gm$ R. callidus @/gm$ can ferment saccharides and its major fermentation products are succinate and acetate, with a less amount of formate, @sm$ lactate @/sm$, and pyruvate.

Some antigens containing structures comprising exactly those found in the @gm$ Y. enterocolitica @/gm$ O:9 OPS, with no Brucella unique components, gave DSp and AUC values better than expected. These were, in descending order of DSp and AUC, the Mono (1), the 2,2-Tri (5) and 2,2,2,2,2-Hexa (9) antigens. Each gave DSp and AUC values higher than all native antigens; the sLPS and modified OPS. The ranking of these antigens suggests that the terminal D-Rha4NFo not only facilitates sensitive antibody detection but does so in a relatively specific manner and that addition of further alpha1,2-linked D-Rha4NFo units decreases specificity. This further suggests that epitopes comprising linear alpha1,2 D-Rha4NFo sequences are less specific to Brucella infection, compared to infection with @gm$ Y. enterocolitica @/gm$ O:9. However, the tip epitope only appears to be more specific after the initial induction of antibodies following @gm$ Y. enterocolitica @/gm$ O:9 infection (Figure 4). Although the results from the @gm$ Y. enterocolitica @/gm$ O:9 samples generally fall over time for all antigens, the fall-off is quicker with the shorter oligosaccharide antigens, slower with the longer antigens and @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ and with the mOPS antigens even initially increasing.

Sp., P. aeruginosa, @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$, S. sonnei and S. boydii . The variation observed of the diameters of inhibition zone of the bacteria tested can be attributed either to the difference in the composition of the bio-active molecules present in the extract or to their mechanism of action on Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. The mechanism of action of the glycosides, polyphenols, tannins and alkaloids on Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria was demonstrated. Some bacteria decreased only in the responders (e.g., Alistipes putredenis, Alistipes shahii, @gm$ Bacteroides xylanisolvens @/gm$), while some increased among them (Streptococcus mitis group, Lachnospiraceae bacterium). Among the bacteria with the strongest correlation with improved glucose and insulin homeostasis were Ruminococcus gnavus, Alistipes shahii, Streptococcus mitis group, Eubacterium hallii and Escherichia coli, the abundance of which were also differently changed in responders and non-responders. Liu et al. continued the study further with the functional and metabolomic analyses of the GM, showing segregation of functional variations and pathways according to the response to exercise. The amino acid fermentation was shifted towards the production of metabolically harmful components and colonic gases in the non-responders, while in the responders towards the production of SCFA. In terms of insulin sensitivity, several other important metabolic adaptations in the GM were found to differentiate the two exercise-responsive groups. The results were confirmed by using a random forest algorithm, to screen those differences in the GM and metabolites at the baseline, which would most efficiently predict the exercise response. Those were @gm$ Bacteroides xylanisolvens @/gm$, B. cellulosilyticus and @sm$ GABA @/sm$.

Some carbohydrate fermentation products, including lactate, succinate and @sm$ 1,2-propanediol @/sm$, do not usually accumulate to high levels in the human colon of healthy adults, as they can serve as substrates for other bacteria, including propionate and butyrate producers. For example, acetate produced by fermentation of resistant starch by R. bromii or lactate produced by lactic acid bacteria such as lactobacilli and bifidobacteria provides substrate for other microbiota members such as Eubacterium hallii and Anaerostipes caccae which convert it into butyrate. Recently, @gm$ B. ovatus @/gm$ has been demonstrated to perform extracellular digestion of inulin at its own cost, but at an advantage to other species which provide reciprocal benefits.
Some glucans, including beta-glucan, can promote the growth of @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$ as it is capable of decomposing dietary @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$.

An isoflavone-rich (ISO) diet consists of the key compounds daidzein and @sm$ genistein @/sm$ which are metabolized by the gut microbiota to produce biologically active S-equol to exert numerous health benefits.

Some intestinal bacteria have been reported to be able to metabolize soybean daidzein @sm$ isoflavone @/sm$ into equol and/or O-desmethylangolensin (O-DMA), such as Lactobacillus mucosae, Bifidobacterium spp., Slackia isoflavoniconvertens, Bacteroides ovatus, Eggerthella spp. strain YY7918, Eggerthella spp. Julong 732, Enterococcus faecium, @gm$ Adlercreutzia equolifaciens @/gm$, and Slackia equolifaciens. However, only about 30-50% of individuals have intestinal bacteria capable of synthesizing equol. The transformation of @sm$ isoflavone @/sm$ into equol is directly related to patient diet, the composition and fermentation capacity of the intestinal microbiota, as well as the oxidation-reduction reactions carried out in the intestine.

Khelaifia and M. Drancourt, unpublished data) were reported to require ruminal fluid for growth. Methanosphaera stadtmanae  has the most restricted energy metabolism of all known human-associated methanogenic archaea, generating methane through the reduction of @sm$ methanol @/sm$ with H2 and being strictly dependent on acetate as a carbon source.

Some of the detected sessile microbiota-specific species, such as @gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$, Parabacteroides distasonis, Rikenellaceae sp., Finegoldia sp., Bilophila sp., and Pyramidobacter piscolens, have previously been reported to be associated with colonic biofilms on intestinal biliary stents.
