(Proteobacteria), with a relative abundance of 12% in sessM_F2. The occurrence of these two species in the sessile microbiota points at trophic interactions. Pyramidobacter sp. and Bilophila sp. are phylogenetically different but exhibit similar physiologies. Both genera are asaccharolytic amino acid degraders that mainly produce acetate as well as small amounts of isovalerate, isobutyrate and @sm$ hydrogen sulfide @/sm$. P. piscolens, rarely cultivated in vitro, was successfully isolated from dental plaque communities in coculture with Methanobrevibacter massiliense, suggesting a symbiotic relationship where P. piscolens uses methane produced by M. massiliense to form @sm$ hydrogen sulfide @/sm$. Indeed, Methanobrevibacter sp. was exclusively found in sessM_F1 at a relative abundance of 2% and was the only representative of the archaeal community (Fig. 3, bottom panel). Similarly, Bilophila wadsworthia was previously recovered in mixed cultures, where growth depended on a "helper strain" producing essential growth-promoting factors (quinones). Several bacteria can act as "helpers" supplying quinones, including @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$, Eubacterium rectale, and different Bacteroides species. Some of the sugars available to enteric pathogens as food sources include fucose, galactose, galactosamine, glucosamine, Neu5Ac, mannose, glucose, @sm$ glucuronate @/sm$, gluconate and galacturonate. Neu5Ac is an excellent source of carbon and energy for intestinal commensals and pathogens, thus it is not surprising that there are a number of commensal species that encode the genes required to utilize Neu5Ac as a carbon source, such as, Bacteroides caccae, B. fragilis, B. ovatus, B. stercoris, B. uniformis, B. vulgatus, Parabacteroides distasonis,, B. breve, Escherichia coli, E. blattae, Edwardsiella tarda, Dorea formicigenerans, @gm$ D. longicatena @/gm$, Faecalibacterium prausnitzii, Fusobacterium nucleatum, Proteus mirabilis, Providencia rettgeri, Ruminococcus gnavus, Lactobacillus plantarum, L.

Some researchers have reported that HN-AD bacteria can oxidise ammonium to nitrate or @sm$ nitrite @/sm$ and convert these products to N2O and/or N2 by denitrification. Therefore, NO2--N and NO3--N accumulated in the culture process but were gradually consumed after rapid growth. In this study, the concentration of NO3--N in the culture medium first increased and then decreased, before finally accumulating to a certain amount. In the process of removing NH4+-N by Acinetobacter sp. T1, NO3--N had a similar change trend. A small amount of NO2--N accumulated in the medium during the reaction, which may be because NO2--N is an intermediate product. It is inferred that the dissimilatory ammonia nitrogen removal pathway of strain K17 may be, leaving the NO3--N (or NO2--N) to be reduced to gaseous nitrogen. However, some HN-AD bacteria, such as Cupriavidus sp. S1, Acinetobacter sp. and @gm$ Acinetobacter junii @/gm$, did not detect (or was very low levels) NO3--N, NO2--N during ammonia removal. Pseudomonas aeruginosa DBT1BNH3 grew well in the presence of nitrate, but no @sm$ nitrite @/sm$ was detected.

Some species (Akkermansia muciniphila, Alistipes indistinctus, Clostridium leptum, Eggerthella lenta, @gm$ Gordonibacter pamelaeae @/gm$, Ruthenibacterium lactatiformans, and Streptococcus oralis) were also predicted to harbor four or more ARG subtypes. Other bacterial species were speculated to carry three or one ARG subtypes. For instance, K. pneumoniae carried one ARG subtypes to fosfomycin (fosA), Prevotella copri carried one ARG subtype to tetracycline (tet37), and Erysipelatoclostridium ramosum carried three ARG subtypes to @sm$ vancomycin @/sm$ (vanH and vanD) and MLS (ermT).

Some species such as @gm$ B. producta @/gm$ possess both heterotrophic and autotrophic properties and can use CO, H2/CO2, and carbohydrates as energy sources. Carbohydrate utilization experiments have shown that all Blautia strains can use glucose, but different strains showed different abilities to use sucrose, fructose, lactose, maltose, rhamnose, and raffinose (Table 2). The final products of glucose fermentation by Blautia are @sm$ acetic acid @/sm$, succinic acid, lactic acid, and ethanol, and the main biochemical tests have revealed negative results for lecithin, lipase, catalase, and indole.

Some strains can consume xylose or other sugars, such as glucose, saccharose, fructose, @sm$ lactose @/sm$, or arabinose. R. flavefaciens produces formate, acetate, and succinate. The production of lactate and ethanol by this species is strain dependent and its DNA G + C content is 39%-44%. R. albus consumes xylose, glucose, saccharose, @sm$ lactose @/sm$, mannose, and fructose, depending on the strain. This species produces formate, ethanol, and acetate, and some strains can produce lactate, succinate, and dihydrogen in small quantities. Its DNA content is 42.6%-45.8%. @gm$ R. champanellensis @/gm$ ferments cellulose and xylane and metabolizes cellobiose to acetate, succinate, dihydrogen, ethanol, and small quantities of formate and lactate. Its DNA G + C content is 53.07%. The type strain of @gm$ R. champanellensis @/gm$ from human feces is 18P13, which is the only strain studied to date.

Some studies have shown that prebiotics has positive effects on metabolic markers and immunomodulatory properties because they induce the growth of both @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and Lactobacillus, which in turn produce an important reduction in fasting plasma @sm$ glucose @/sm$, serum TG, total cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol, and a significant increase in HDL cholesterol levels.

Some studies have shown the effect of stress-related hormones such as CRF, ACTH, @sm$ catecholamines @/sm$, and cortisol produced through the SAM and HPA axis on the gut microbiota. Most of these hormones are released into the gut through circulation. Hormones such as CRF and cortisol is produced in small amount in the gut by enteric neurons, enterochromaffin cells, and epithelial cells of the gut. The direct effect of @sm$ catecholamines @/sm$ on gut bacteria such as @gm$ Yersinia enterocolitica @/gm$, Escherichia coli, Campylobacter jejuni, Helicobacter pylori, and Salmonella enetrica has been previously demonstrated. The effect of cortisol on gut microbiome was shown in pigs where gut Ruminococcus negatively predicted the level of serum cortisol. The serum cortisol fully mediated the relationship between fecal Ruminococcus and a brain metabolite N-acetyl aspartate which highlighted the role of the gut-brain axis. Post-stressor salivary cortisol in humans was negatively associated with the alpha and beta diversity of gut microbiota. This direct interaction of stress-related hormones with microbiota has been commonly termed microbial endocrinology. Stress hormones may also affect the gut microbiota through the modulation of host epithelium. ACTH, @sm$ catecholamines @/sm$, and cortisol are known to increase the adherence of bacteria to gut mucosa as well contribute to the uptake of microbiota into Peyer's patches.

Some water quality measurements have been suggested as alternative approaches to predict the @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ risk for building's water system instead of directly culturing analysis. However, as reported in the study of Pierre and collaborators, a poor correlation and a low positive predictive value between the hot water return line and distal outlet positivity in different buildings was revealed. Moreover, no correlation between @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ distal site positivity and total bacteria, pH, free chlorine, calcium, magnesium, zinc, manganese, copper, temperature, total organic @sm$ carbon @/sm$, or incoming cold-water chlorine concentration was observed. These data confirm that these water quality parameters should not be used alone to determine the building's @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ colonization rate and effectiveness of water management programs.

Spearman analysis showed that four species, including Prevotella fusca and Prevotella melaninogenica, were negatively correlated with age of the subjects while three species, including @gm$ Acinetobacter johnsonii @/gm$ and S. thermophilus, had a negative association. In addition, seven species, including Thermococcus gammatolerans and Burkholderia diffusa were negatively correlated, whereas ten species including @gm$ A. johnsonii @/gm$ and S. thermophilus had a positive relationship with BMI (Figure 6B). Furthermore, seven species, including Prevotella denticola and P. melaninogenica, were positively correlated with @sm$ testosterone @/sm$ levels, whereas only @gm$ A. johnsonii @/gm$ was negatively correlated with @sm$ testosterone @/sm$ levels.

Spearman correlation analysis revealed that @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and @gm$ B. pseudolongum @/gm$, showed significantly negative associations with LPC(18:0) (P = 0.020 and P = 0.011, respectively), and other metabolites participating in glycerophospholipid metabolism [LPC(16:0), PC(16:0/18:1), PC(16:0/16:0), phosphatidic acid 16:0/18:1 {PA(16:0/18:1)}, PC(18:0/18:1)]. Inversely, these metabolites were positively correlated with the Dorea and Parabacteroides genera and the Mogibacteriaceae and Clostridiaceae families. Notably, the abundances of these bacterial taxa were remarkably decreased by GML supplementation compared with their abundances in the HFD control. @sm$ Linoleic acid @/sm$, an n-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid, was present at a relatively high concentration in the sera of HFD-fed rats and showed negative correlations with the abundances of the Allobaculum (P = 0.003) and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ (P = 0.047) genera and @gm$ B. pseudolongum @/gm$ (P = 0.036). The increase in serum acetoacetic acid was associated with higher abundances of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ (P < 0.001) and @gm$ B. pseudolongum @/gm$ (P < 0.001) and lower abundances of the Bacteroides (P = 0.003) and Eggerthella (P = 0.002) genera and E. lenta (P = 0.002). Additionally, palmitoylcarnitine was positively correlated with @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ (P = 0.003) and @gm$ B. pseudolongum @/gm$ (P = 0.002) but negatively associated with the Dorea (P = 0.009) genus and the Mogibacteriaceae (P = 0.004) and Clostridiaceae (P = 0.003) families.

Spearman correlation analysis revealed that metabolites including nucleotides, @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$, peptides, cofactors and vitamins, xenobiotics, amino acids, and lipids were closely correlated with genera mainly belonging to Firmicutes, Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria phyla. Previous studies in fish and mammals have reported the involvement of gut microbiota in lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis and de novo synthesis of essential amino acids and vitamins. This suggests that supplementation of GOS and @gm$ P. acidilactici @/gm$ in the diet could have modulated gut microbiota associated with some of those functions in the post-smolt Atlantic salmon in the present study as well. Further, increased transcripts and metabolite levels related to immunomodulatory effects could also potentially link to the increased abundance of @gm$ P. acidilactici @/gm$ when in combination with GOS.

Speciation of 41 isolates which were difficult to distinguish as either alpha or beta hemolytic on sheep blood agar plates showed that the majority were either @gm$ S. parasanguinis @/gm$ or S. mitis (31.7 % each). S. oralis, S. pneumoniae, S. constellatus, and S. perioris accounted for 7.3, 4.9, 2.4, and 2.4 % of these strains, respectively. However, 19.5 % @sm$ bacitracin @/sm$-susceptible isolates could not be classified further. Most @gm$ S. parasanguinis @/gm$ (84.6 %) and about half of S. mitis (54.5 %) were similarly @sm$ bacitracin @/sm$-sensitive.

Species belonging to the genera Alistipes, Bacteroides, Parabacteroides, @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$, Paraprevotella, Alloprevotella, Barnesiella, and Tannerella are saccharolytic, while species belonging to Odoribacter and Porphyromonas are predominantly asaccharolytic. Some Bacteroides spp. and @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ spp. can degrade complex plant polysaccharides such as starch, @sm$ cellulose @/sm$, xylans, and pectins.

Species producing industrially-relevant alcohols include Lachnoclostridium phytofermentans, which ferments cellulose to ethanol at 68% of the maximum theoretical yield and, similar to @gm$ Roseburia inulinivorans @/gm$, metabolizes fucose and rhamnose to @sm$ 1-propanol @/sm$ through a 1,2-propanediol intermediate in polyhedral microcompartments.

Specific BV-associated bacteria were correlated with the presence of amino acid catabolites, whereas @gm$ L. crispatus @/gm$ and L. jensenii were associated with the presence of intact amino acids and dipeptides. These data support the notion that BV-associated bacteria may use amino acids as a carbon and @sm$ nitrogen @/sm$ source, in contrast to lactobacilli, which are known to metabolize sugars, such as glycogen. In line with our findings, another study that performed comparative analysis of @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ genomes from the human vagina suggested that @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ genomes were underrepresented in amino acid transport and metabolism, while being overrepresented for carbohydrate transport and metabolism. Furthermore, genome analysis of L. iners AB-1 showed that it lacks genes necessary for the de novo synthesis of amino acids, with the possible exception of serine, and that ~15% of its genome is dedicated to various transport mechanisms, suggesting that it acquires metabolites, such as amino acids, crucial for survival from the environment. This is consistent with our observations that the metabolite profile of L. iners is intermediate to those of @gm$ L. crispatus @/gm$/L.

Specific intestinal microflora can convert @sm$ ETs @/sm$ and EA consumed by some people into urolithins. Selma et al. reported that the abundance of Gordonibacter in the feces of UM-A individuals was higher than those of UM-B and UM-0 individuals. In addition, two strains from the genus Gordonibacter with a Uro-C-producing ability were identified: G. urolithinfaciens and @gm$ G. pamelaeae @/gm$.

Specifically, bacterial taxa typical of the 1-6 M group intestinal microbiota together with certain bacterial species characterizing the other two age groups positively correlated with at least one complex plant-derived glycan, such as inulin, pectin, arabinogalactan, @sm$ maltodextrin @/sm$, guar gum or xylan (Supplementary Table 12). Notably, members of the genus Bifidobacterium are skilled degraders of a wide range of plant-derived carbohydrates due to the presence, in their genetic arsenal, of several genes dedicated to this activity, while they also participate in intra- and inter-genus cross-feeding behaviour. Similarly, members of the genera @gm$ Anaerostipes @/gm$, Faecalibacterium, Prevotella and Ruminococcus are known for their ability to utilize different complex sugars as energy source.

Specifically, the majority of Enterobacteriaceae were characterized by a significant @sm$ Zn @/sm$-induced increase in relative abundance. Additionally, bacterial species with relative abundance of >1%, @sm$ Zn @/sm$ exposure resulted in a significant increase in Weissella cibaria, Weissella confusa, @gm$ Leuconostoc citreum @/gm$, and Streptococcus equinus. In contrast, the most abundant species @gm$ Leuconostoc @/gm$ reuteri decreased from 45% to 18% in response to @sm$ Zn @/sm$ exposure. Lastly, a significant increase in intestinal microbiota richness and relative abundance of Lachnospiraceae, with a parallel decrease in Ruminococcus flavefaciens was observed in response to coated nano ZnO supplementation. Interestingly, the effect of @sm$ Zn @/sm$ on the gut microbiota in weaned piglets seems to be specific for intestinal sites. For example, ZnO nanoparticle (ZnONP) supplementation significantly reduced bacterial abundance and diversity in ileum with increases in Streptococcus and decreases in Lactobacillus numbers. In turn, cecal and colonic microflora biodiversity and abundance were increased, with a specific elevation in Lactobacillus numbers and a decrease in Oscillospira and Prevotella abundance. ZnONP-induced modulation of gut microbiome was associated with increased expression of tight junction and antioxidant proteins, as well as reduced IL-1beta, TNFalpha, and IFNgamma mRNA expression due to inhibition of NF-kappaB signaling, altogether resulting in lower incidence of diarrhea. @sm$ Zn @/sm$ has also been shown to modulate microbial metabolite production in pigs.

Sphingolipids accounted for 19-29% of the total @sm$ lipids @/sm$ detected in Bacteroides species, with DHCer making up approximately 20% of the sphingolipid fraction in @gm$ B. ovatus @/gm$, B. vulgatus, and B. thetaiotaomicron, but only 2% in B. fragilis. Instead, B. fragilis appeared to accumulate higher levels of keto-sphinganine (keto-sph). Additionally, detectable levels of sphinganine (sph) and deoxy-sph were found in both B. thetaiotaomicron and @gm$ B. ovatus @/gm$.

SrtA is a virulence factor in oral gram-positive species, including Streptococcus spp., Staphylococcus spp., and @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$ spp.. SrtA in S. mutans is essential for sucrose-independent adhesion, which facilitates the antigen I/II and Gbps attachment to the cell wall, while the srtA gene expression in S. mutans was downregulated by approximately one-fold after curcumin treatment. SrtA in @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$ spp. has played a key role in bacterial survival and is the potential treatment target to combat @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$ spp.. Berberine, one of the main alkaloids isolated from Rhizoma coptidis, inhibited SrtA gene expression by 50% compared with the control group at 80 mug/ml. SrtA in Staphylococcus spp. also acts as a catalyst for the adhesion of proteins (such as FnBPA and FnBPB) to the cell wall. Kaempferol, a typical @sm$ flavonol @/sm$, inhibited both SrtA activity and cell adhesion at 64 mug/ml, suggesting that its inhibition of biofilm formation was achieved by inhibiting SrtA activity to weaken the adhesion of S.

Pure cultures of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$, strain OxCC13, were grown anaerobically at 37 C in 100 ml Schaedler broth (SBO, BD Biosciences) supplemented with 100 mM @sm$ sodium oxalate @/sm$ and 10 mM sodium acetate. For generation of samples for proteomic analysis, @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ cells were taken at OD595 0.05 and 0.13 (n=4 each growth stage).

Standard solid media, i.e., MacConkey, xylose lysine deoxycholate, bismuth sulfite (Wilson-Blair), and @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$-Shigella agars, as well as selenite and tetrathionate (Preuss) broths (all Oxoid, Wesel, Germany) were used to detect @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$, Shigella, Aeromonas, Plesiomonas, and Vibrio species. In addition, cefsulodin irgasan novobiocin agar, Skirrow agar supplemented with 10% sheep blood, PALCAM listeria agar, and cycloserine-cefoxitin fructose agar (all Oxoid) were inoculated for the detection of Yersinia spp., Campylobacter spp., Listeria monocytogenes, and C. difficile, respectively. To detect Arcobacter butzleri, Skirrow agar plates were inoculated and cultured at 37 C. Suspicious bacterial colonies were further isolated and differentiated using routine techniques (e.g., oxidase, @sm$ hippurate @/sm$, and motility for Campylobacter spp. and A. butzleri, agglutination for @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ spp., Shigella spp., and Vibrio spp.) and the API system (BioMerieux, Nurtingen, Germany).

Standard treatment includes oral @sm$ metronidazole @/sm$, which typically restores Lactobacillus species to dominance. However, recurrence rates are high; recurrent BV patients recur 3-4 times annually and are often refractory to treatment. Our previous qPCR-based study of recurrent BV patients pointed to putatively more virulent species of Gardnerella that were associated with refractory responses to oral @sm$ metronidazole @/sm$, and less robust recovery of Lactobacillus species associated with recurrence after an initial period of remission. However, these associations did not account for outcomes in all patients, suggesting that other bacterial species were involved. In this follow-up study, we sequenced the V4 domain of 16S rRNA sequences of 41of these same patients pre- and posttreatment. Overall compositions among pretreatment clinical outcome groups were not different, although alpha diversity significantly decreased: refractory > recurrent > remission. Combinations of key species were associated with and prognostic for outcome. Higher pretreatment abundance of Megasphaera lornae together with lower abundance of Gardnerella Gsp07 and Finegoldia magna predicted long term remission after oral @sm$ metronidazole @/sm$. Patients who recurred after transient remission had elevated abundance of species including Atopobium vaginae, Gardnerella, and Aerococcus christensenii, compared to long-term remission patients. Core bacterial species among refractory patients did not change in abundance after @sm$ metronidazole @/sm$, suggesting resistance or tolerance, in contrast to the loss in abundance of the same species among recurrent or remission patients.

Sustainably produced H2, CO2, and @sm$ CO @/sm$ can be co-fed to microorganisms as a source for acetyl-CoA, while a small amount of an ATP-generating organic substrate helps overcome the kinetic hindrances associated with autotrophic carboxylate production. Here, we operated two semi-continuous bioreactor systems with continuous recirculation of H2, CO2, and @sm$ CO @/sm$ while co-feeding an organic model feedstock (lactate and acetate) to understand how a mixotrophic community is shaped during carboxylate production. Contrary to the assumption that H2, CO2, and @sm$ CO @/sm$ support chain elongation via ethanol production in open cultures, significant correlations (p < 0.01) indicated that relatives of Clostridium luticellarii and Eubacterium aggregans produced carboxylates (acetate to n-caproate) while consuming H2, CO2, @sm$ CO @/sm$, and lactate themselves. After 100 days, the enriched community was dominated by these two bacteria coexisting in cyclic dynamics shaped by the @sm$ CO @/sm$ partial pressure. Homoacetogenesis was strongest when the acetate concentration was low (3.2 g L-1), while heterotrophs had the following roles: Pseudoramibacter, @gm$ Oscillibacter @/gm$, and Colidextribacter contributed to n-caproate production and Clostridium tyrobutyricum and Acidipropionibacterium spp. grew opportunistically producing n-butyrate and propionate, respectively. The mixotrophic chain elongation community was more efficient in carboxylate production compared with the heterotrophic one and maintained average carbon fixation rates between 0.088 and 1.4 g CO2 equivalents L-1 days-1. The extra H2 and @sm$ CO @/sm$ consumed routed 82% more electrons to carboxylates and 50% more electrons to carboxylates longer than acetate.

Table 4 shows also the numerical results of the EDA-NOCV calculations of the alkaline earth dicarbonyls M(CO)2 (M = Ca, Sr, @sm$ Ba @/sm$) using neutral and charged fragments as interacting moieties and the experimentally observed [Ba(CO)] +. The dicarbonyls have been calculated as model compounds in order to examine the suggestion that the red-shift of the alkaline earth octacarbonyls M(CO)8 (M = Ca, Sr, @sm$ Ba @/sm$) comes from interligand interaction between neighboring CO ligands rather than from M   (CO)8 pi-backdonation. The trans-relative position in the linear dicarbonyls, which are minima on the potential energy surface, effectively precludes a direct interaction between the CO ligands. The EDA-NOCV data in Table 4 show that the orbital interactions in M(CO)2 are in the same way dominated by M   (CO) pi-backdonation as in the octacarbonyls M(CO)8. This is equally true for the calculations with neutral and charged fragments. Note that the pi-backdonation in the dicarbonyls is distributed over only two CO ligands whereas it covers eight CO ligands in the octacarbonyls. This explains why the red-shift of the C-O stretching frequencies in M(CO)2 is much larger than in M(CO)8 (Table 1). Table 4 shows that the largest contribution to the orbital interactions even in the radical cation [Ba(@gm$ CO)] + comes @/gm$ from Ba+   (CO) pi-backdonation. This has been discussed in detail before. The EDA-NOCV results clearly show that the red-shift in the alkaline earth octacarbonyls M(CO)8 (M = Ca, Sr, @sm$ Ba @/sm$) comes from M   (CO)8 pi-backdonation.

Tea saponin is also an important fungicide, composed of sugar chains, triterpenoids, and steroids or steroid alkaloids that are linked by carbon-@sm$ oxygen @/sm$ bonds. The structures of insect gut microbiomes have been significantly changed after feeding on fruits containing tea saponin. The soil microbiomes evaluated here also exhibited similar changes in response to saponin contents. Moreover, the relative abundances of Enterobacter, @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$, Aquabacterium, and Rhodoplanes were associated with the increasing tea saponin accumulation that accrued across plantation ages (Fig. 1e and f). In addition, @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ abundance was significantly and positively correlated with tea saponin accumulation (Fig. 1f). This bacterium is frequently associated with both aspen foliage and the gypsy moths that consume aspen foliage tissue, metabolizing phenolic glycosides within the foliage. Further, the species @gm$ A. calcoaceticus @/gm$ and A. oleivorans were able to degrade catechin, modulating host physiology and metabolism to improve hexadecane utilization efficiency. @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ derived from wood-fed termite guts can efficiently degrade phenolic compounds by using phenol as its sole carbon source. Community interaction networks and random forest classification analyses conducted in this study indicated that @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ was one of the core soil bacteria in old C. oleifera plantations. The relative abundance of @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ was significantly and positively correlated with tea saponin accumulation, firmly suggesting that @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ is closely involved in tea saponin degradation.

Ten patients were evaluated after taking 250 mg/day of @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ for 2 to 7 years. Ten other patients who had been on @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ for at least 2 years were evaluated 6 months to 2 years after stopping the antibiotic. Subgingival plaque was cultured anaerobically on nonselective media (ETSA) and ETSA with 1 microgram/ml of @sm$ tetracycline HCl @/sm$. Pocket depth, plaque and gingivitis were scored. Those patients on @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ had no bleeding on probing despite residual pockets ranging from 3 to 7 mm. Gram-negative anaerobic rods made up to 49.8% of the microflora of these patients, with Fusobacterium nucleatum dominating. @gm$ B. melaninogenicus @/gm$, and B. gingivalis were not detected in the samples. Five of ten patients off @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ bled on probing and had pocket depths in the same range as those on @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$. The microflora of @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$-off sites was predominately Gram-negative rods (63.1% with B. gingivalis and F. nucleatum 7.3% and 3.1% of the flora respectively). In @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$-on samples 76.6% of the isolates were resistant to 1 microgram/ml of @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ compared to 25.9% in the patients off @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ and 7.1% resistant organisms in 14 untreated control samples from periodontitis patients not exposed to any long-term @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ therapy. Long-term, low-dose @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ was associated with a healthy clinical condition and diverse Gram-negative anaerobic flora resistant to the antibiotic. After discontinuing @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ the clinical and bacterial status was more characteristic of disease.

The 16S rRNA profile-based functional prediction using PICRUSt2 demonstrated @sm$ indole @/sm$-metabolic enzymes such as tryptophanase and indolepyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase were notably elevated in the microbiota exposed to STR ( Figure 6A ). @sm$ Indole @/sm$ metabolites are a pivotal type of URS that accumulates in the blood and tissues during acute or chronic renal diseases through human and microbial tryptophan metabolism. We addressed bacteria with genes encoding URS-producing enzymes in the present bacterial community. Based on sequence alignments of the bacterial genes, ten different species of bacteria were identified as having genes for tryptophanase (TNase) (B. acidifaciens, E. coli, Akkermansia muciniphila, B. uniformis, B. xylanisolvens, @gm$ Alistipes finegoldii @/gm$, Oscillibacter, Anaerotruncus colihominis, Porphyromonadaceae, and B. faecis), aryl sulfotransferase (Bifidobacterium longum group and Lactobacillus plantarum), and choline TMA-lyase (CutC) (E. coli). In particular, bacterial TNase is the key enzyme for the conversion of tryptophan into @sm$ indole @/sm$ in the gastrointestinal tract, which is then further metabolized into renal toxic indoxyl sulfate (IS) in the liver by the hepatic CYP450 enzyme. Consistent with the microbial genetic features of @sm$ indole @/sm$ metabolism, the blood level of IS was significantly elevated by CDDP treatment in STR-exposed animals whose microbiota showed an elevated composition of B. acidifaciens ( Figure 6B ). On an assumption that B. acidifaciens is a pivotal IS producer in renal injury model, this bacterium was assessed for its ability to convert tryptophan into @sm$ indole @/sm$ in vitro. B. acidifaciens produced @sm$ indole @/sm$ in GAM broth which already includes tryptophan ( Figure 6C ). Although the bacteria displayed Ehrlich's test negative in the minimal media without tryptophan, they produced @sm$ indole @/sm$ in the presence of tryptophan ( Figure 6D ).

The 39 @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ spp. strains isolated from broiler farms were classified as MDR strains that were resistant to the four antibiotic classes of penicillins, aminoglycosides, sulfonamides, and cephalosporins (AM, GM, STR, SXT, CRO, and @sm$ CAZ @/sm$) (Table-2). Regarding the strains isolated from human subjects with gastroenteritis, the serotype Typhimurium (n=1) was classified as an MDR strain that exhibited resistance to GM, STR, chloramphenicol, and florfenicol. In total, 83.6% (41/49) of the strains were resistant to STR and 79.5% (39/49) were resistant to AM. The @gm$ Aeromonas @/gm$ populations from water samples of 9 different fish farming sites across Darjeeling and Jalpaiguri districts of Sub-Himalayan West Bengal were investigated. Samples were collected in sterilized vials, kept at 4 C, and analyzed within 24 h of procuring. For isolation of the bacteria, 0.1 ml of ten-fold diluted samples prepared in sterile distilled water was spread plated on @gm$ Aeromonas @/gm$ isolation medium (HiMedia Laboratories Ltd., Mumbai, India). The plates were incubated for 24 h at 30 C in the bacterial incubator. Altogether, 83 single colonies were selected based on the expected morphology from the spread plates, and pure cultures were maintained by streaking them on tryptone soya agar slants. Glycerol stocks of cultures were maintained in 10% glycerol at -20 C. All of the isolates were initially screened presumptively using a slightly modified key test called Aerokey II, described by Carnahan et al., to identify the genus @gm$ Aeromonas @/gm$. The isolates were tested for Gram-staining, oxidase, catalase, glucose fermentation, resistance to 0/129 discs, and @sm$ esculin @/sm$ hydrolysis. The strains were labeled as presumptive @gm$ Aeromonas @/gm$ spp.

The @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ requirements of the isolation host for each phage also appear to influence the RNR class present, consistent with the observation that class I RNR is aerobic, class II is @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ independent, and class III is anaerobic. Regardless of isolation environment or phage family, phages infecting aerobes contain primarily class I or class II RNR genes (Figure 2). Most of the phages that infect facultative anaerobes contain class I+III genes, and all three phages that contain only class III RNR genes are known to infect strict anaerobes (@gm$ Clostridium @/gm$ spp.). In bacteria, the class II nrdJ gene can enable DNA replication and repair under @sm$ oxygen @/sm$-limiting conditions, potentially explaining the presence of class II RNR in some phages infecting facultative aerobes and facultative anaerobes. The class II+III combination was completely absent amongst the 685 phage genomes analyzed, suggesting that the combination of class I+II or class I+III is more advantageous for infection under fluctuating @sm$ oxygen @/sm$ conditions.

The @sm$ quinolone @/sm$ resistance-determining regions (QRDRs) of the gyrA gene of @sm$ quinolone @/sm$-resistant @gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ isolates were sequenced. Four types of point mutation, Ser-83-to-Phe (TCC --> TTc), Ser-83-to-Tyr (TCC --> TAC), Asp-87-to-Gly (GAC --> GGC), and Asp-87-to-Asn (GAC --> AAC), were found. PCR-RFLP and MAS-touch down PCR were performed on fifty swine clinical isolates of @gm$ S. enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ (NalR) collected during 1997-2002. The analysis indicated seven isolates with point mutations in codon 83, 13 with point mutations in codon 87, and 30 with double mutations in both codons 83 and 87. The MICs of enrofloxacin of the isolates with a single mutation in codon 83 or 87 were <2microg/ml, while the MICs of the isolates with double mutations in both codon 83 and 87 ranged from 2 to 64microg/ml. A class I integron comprised of dhfr, orfF and aad2 was also identified in both human and swine @gm$ S. enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ isolates. These results indicate that PCR-RFLP and MAS-touchdown PCR assays can be used for surveillance of gyrA gene mutations, which are important for fluoroquinolone resistance in @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$. Isolates with double mutations in gyrA codons 83 and 87 are the major type of @sm$ quinolone @/sm$-resistant @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ isolated from swine in Taiwan. A surveillance system may be applied to the swine industry to monitor the emergence of fluoroquinolone and/or multi-drug-resistant @gm$ S. enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ in Taiwan.

The ESX-5 system is the other well studied T7SS, mostly in @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$. EsxN and EsxM are cognate substrates of the ESX-5. In addition, the PE/PPE family proteins are also substrates of ESX-5. These proteins are named after the proline-@sm$ glutamate @/sm$ (PE) and proline-proline-glutamate (PPE) motifs at their N-terminal homology domain, respectively. The C-terminal domain varies extensively in sequence and length. Although nonpathogenic mycobacteria only contain a few pe/ppe genes, these gene families are greatly expanded in the genome of M. tb (169 pe/ppe genes) and @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ (281 pe/ppe genes).

The GPx activity of all samples was stable from 0 to 2 d of storage regardless of @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ inoculation status and @sm$ ozone @/sm$ exposure. On 3 d of storage, a significant decrease (p<0.05) in GPx activity occurred in all treatments. There was no significant (p>0.05) effect of @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ inoculation and @sm$ ozone @/sm$ on the activity of the GPx enzyme from 0 to 2 d of storage. On the last day of storage, @sm$ ozone @/sm$ exposure significantly decreased the GPx activity regardless of the @gm$ E. coli O157:H7 @/gm$ inoculation status. These results indicate that GPx was more resistant to @sm$ ozone @/sm$ than CAT. This result is in accordance with that of. CAT and GPx, together with superoxide dismutase (SOD), are known to act to prevent the accumulation of lipid oxidation products. As the activity of CAT and GPx was reduced by @sm$ ozone @/sm$, these enzymes lost their abilities, which resulted in increased lipid oxidation rates. This outcome can be an additional explanation for the higher TBARS values found in samples under @sm$ ozone @/sm$ exposure (Table 3).

The GmpC protein from @gm$ Staphylococcus aureus @/gm$ binds specifically to the dipeptide glycylmethionine, yet is related in sequence to the E. coli methionine-binding protein, MetQ. Although this is an interesting case, it is unlikely that the cluster F SBPs would accommodate larger peptides like the cluster C SBPs. The flexibility of the cluster C SBPs that allows them to bind large ligands has also been demonstrated recently by the discovery of SBPs from this cluster that are @sm$ oligosaccharide @/sm$-binding proteins.

The Gram-positive, thermophilic @gm$ Bacillus methanolicus @/gm$ can utilize methanol as its sole carbon and energy source, supporting fast growth at its optimal temperature of 50 C. The wild-type (WT) strain B. methanolicus MGA3 is able to overproduce 59 g/L of L-glutamate, and it has been engineered for methanol-based production of 65 g/L of L-lysine. Introduction of genes coding for L-glutamate decarboxylase and L-lysine decarboxylase converted this strain to produce 11.3 g/L of cadaverine and 9 g/L of GABA, respectively, in fed-batch fermentations from methanol. Methanol-based production of @sm$ acetoin @/sm$ was achieved by heterologous expression of genes for two decarboxylating enzymes, acetolactate synthase, and acetolactate decarboxylase. Biochemical, genetic, and omics analyses provided a sound basis for the biochemical and genetic understanding of @gm$ B. methanolicus @/gm$, and metabolic fluxes during growth with methanol, mannitol, and arabitol have been unraveled. However, an insight into the response of this bacterium to non-native chemical compounds, such as cadaverine, GABA, and @sm$ acetoin @/sm$ that were synthesized upon introduction of non-native enzymes, typically does not exist. Since @gm$ B. methanolicus @/gm$ is used for the methanol-based production of proteins, amino acids, and derived chemicals, the response of @gm$ B. methanolicus @/gm$ to the non-native L-lysine-derived omega-amino acid 5AVA has been studied.

The plasma metabolite profile of IF2-P participants displayed significant increases in serine, trimethylamine oxide (TMAO), levulinic acid, 3-aminobutyric acid, citrate, isocitrate, and @sm$ glucuronic acid @/sm$ (q <= 0.049) compared to IF1-P.

The L-fucose permease-encoding gene fucP and the surrounding coding region (CFT03427_1042-1047) was present in all @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ strains examined, but was absent from its closest relatives C. iguaniorum and C. hyointestinalis. Low homology orthologs (57-65% identity) were identified in C. coli and C. jejuni by an online BLASTP search against the nonredundant database. In some C. jejuni strains, fucP and the surrounding coding region (cj0480c-cj0490) are implicated in the uptake of the sugar @sm$ L-fucose @/sm$, which is released from the host's mucin glycoproteins and has been shown to be important in colonizing hosts. Noteworthy, fucP and the surrounding coding region were present in C. coli showing introgression by C. jejuni genes, suggesting that the presence of this region provides C. coli an advantage in the gastrointestinal tract. Fermentation of carbohydrates is considered uncommon in Campylobacter, which might be related to the absence of 6-phosphofructokinase needed for glycolysis and key enzymes in the Entner-Doudoroff pathway. However, the presence of fucP and the surrounding coding region in @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ predicts that, besides amino acids and organic acids, @sm$ L-fucose @/sm$ can be metabolized by @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$.

The O-PS, a key virulence factor in smooth @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ spp., remains the most studied component of this pathogen's LPS (; Figure 1). The lack of O-PS is what differentiates the LPS of @gm$ B. canis @/gm$ and B. ovis from their smooth counterparts. In other Gram-negative bacteria, the O-PS typically exhibits a high degree of variability, allowing for strain differentiation by molecular methods. In contrast, @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ O-PS is highly homogeneous, possibly due to its niche within the intracellular environment limiting horizontal transfer with other bacteria, as suggested by. The @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ O-PS is composed of homopolymers of N-formylperosamine with minor variations depending on strain, in which "A-dominant" strains exhibit a linear alpha-1,2-linked polymer with approximately 2% alpha-1,3 linkages while the O-PS from "M-dominant" strains is a linear polymer of tetrasaccharide repeating units containing one alpha-1,3 linkage and three alpha-1,2-linked monosaccharide residues. Although not sufficient for speciation, serotyping using monoclonal antibodies directed against A or M epitopes can allow for distinction of different biovars within a particular smooth @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ species. Further discussion of O-PS in this review will focus on the classical smooth @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ spp. (B. abortus, B. melitensis, and B. suis). Although more recently identified @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ species have been characterized as smooth (B. neotomae, B. ceti, B. pinnipedialis, B. microti, B. papionis, and B. inopinata), the complete structure of their LPS, including the O-PS, remains to be elucidated. Preliminary work has suggested that some of these strains not only lack typical O-PS epitopes but also suspected alterations to the core and/or @sm$ lipid A @/sm$, possibly accounting for a lack of zoonotic potential in the majority of these species.

The ankB mutant of @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ is severely defective in intracellular proliferation in amoebae and human macrophages due to the defect in assembly of K48-linked polyubiquitinated proteins decorating the LCV (Fig. 1). Due to lack of proteasomal degradation of K48-linked polyubiquitin during infection by the ankB mutant, cellular levels of amino acid do not increase. This triggers a bacterial starvation response, mediated by the induced expression of RelA and SpoT, and results in elevated ppGpp levels. Intracellular growth can be restored to the ankB mutant within amoebae and human cells by supplementing excess amino acids. Thus, higher levels of cellular amino acids are needed for intracellular replication of @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$. Remarkably, supplementation of infected cells with certain single amino acids, such as @sm$ cysteine @/sm$, reverses the growth defect of the ankB mutant in amoebae and human cells. Interestingly, in human cells @sm$ cysteine @/sm$ is semi-essential and is the least abundant amino acid, but in amoebae @sm$ cysteine @/sm$ is essential. Similar to @sm$ cysteine @/sm$, supplementation of infected cells with pyruvate or citrate to feed the TCA cycle, rescues the ankB mutant for intracellular proliferation. Interestingly, in vitro growth of @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ in rich medium requires supplementation with 3.3 mM @sm$ cysteine @/sm$. Therefore, AnkB is a remarkable example of an effector involved in exploitation of multiple host processes that are highly conserved in unicellular eukaryotes and mammals. By promoting proteasomal degradation in amoebae and human cells though the AnkB F-box effector, @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ generates a gratuitous supply of cellular amino acids (Fig. 2), particularly the limiting ones such as @sm$ Cys @/sm$, which is a metabolically favorable source of carbon and energy for @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ to power intracellular growth within amoebae and human cells.

The antibody response specific to the 25-kDa major outer-membrane protein (Omp25) of @gm$ Brucella melitensis @/gm$ expressed in Escherichia coli was assessed in BALB/c mice. Groups of mice were immunised and boosted either with sonicated E. coli carrying plasmid pAC2533-E. coli (pAC2533)-expressing the gene coding for Omp25 (omp25 gene) of @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$, or with E. coli carrying plasmid pUC19-E. coli (pUC19). One control group received saline. The evolution of antibody responses was investigated by indirect ELISA with whole rough (R) B. melitensis H38 cells as antigen. Serum antibody titres of mice immunised with E. coli (pAC2533) were appreciably higher than those of mice immunised with E. coli (pUC19). The specificity to Omp25 of murine antibodies induced by E. coli (pAC2533) was demonstrated by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting of five @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$ strains. Binding of antibody in E. coli (pAC2533) immune sera to the surface of @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$ strains differing in their smooth @sm$ lipopolysaccharide @/sm$ (S-LPS) expression was also studied by whole-cell ELISA and by flow cytometry. Antibody reactivity to R and smooth-rough (S-R) was much stronger than that to smooth (S) @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$ strains, indicating a much better accessibility of Omp25 to antibody on strains lacking or expressing less O-polysaccharide on their surface. The antibodies to Omp25 were predominantly of IgG2a isotype. The capacity of E. coli (pAC2533) to induce protective immune responses against four challenge strains of @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$ was further evaluated in mice. Significant reductions in splenic infections, in comparison with mice immunised with E. coli (pUC19) and unimmunised (saline injection) mice, were observed in R B. melitensis B115, S-R B. melitensis EP and S B. melitensis H38 infected mice. Protection against S @gm$ B. melitensis @/gm$ 16M was not significant.

The bacterial production of lactate from @sm$ pyruvate @/sm$ involved the catalysis of stereospecific lactate dehydrogenase. The genome of B. thetaiotaomicron encoded only for a d-lactate dehydrogenase (BT_1575), leading to d-lactate production. The lactate-utilizing butyrate-producing bacteria (LUB) could subsequently convert acetate and lactate into butyrate. Our model organism, @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$, was reported to metabolize both d- and l-lactate. Despite the phenotypic observation, @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$ possessed two l-lactate dehydrogenases (ANACAC_01148 and ANACAC_03769) while no d-lactate dehydrogenase or lactate racemase were found in the genome. The homologous protein check against d-lactate dehydrogenase from Lactobacillus helveticus (UniProt identifier P30901) showed no match in the @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$ genome except the general NAD-binding domain. Besides, no domain matching the lactate racemase from Lactobacillus plantarum (UniProt identifier F9USS9) was found in the @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$ genome.

The binding of TNF to the extracellular domains of TNFR1 bridges the receptors, thus gathering the death domains of the cytoplasmic moiety and initiating the signaling cascade ending either in apoptosis or in the production of many inflammatory mediators (@sm$ eicosanoids @/sm$, proteases, free radicals, adhesion molecules...). TNF also induces the release of other cytokines, which can act in synergy with TNF within an amplificatory feedback loop (e.g. interferon-gamma (IFNgamma) and interleukin-1beta (IL-1beta)), or which drive TNF-induced lethal shock (i.e. type I interferon, Huys et al,). In TNFR1 KO mice, both the negative impact of the deletion of the receptor in @gm$ Listeria monocytogenes @/gm$ infection, and the beneficial consequence when mice were injected with endotoxin or a Gram-positive-derived exotoxin were demonstrated (Pfeffer et al,).

The biosynthesis of @sm$ ansamycin @/sm$ was the only and slightly enriched pathway with Anaerotruncus spp., which has previously been reported in patients with lung, gastric, and ovarian cancers. Ansamycins such as rifamycin, ansamitocin, and geldanamycin are an important class of polyketide natural products. @sm$ Ansamycin @/sm$ antibiotics include important antibacterial agents, such as rifamycin, and anticancer agents such as ansamitocin. Previous studies have shown high expressions of Hsp90 in lung cancer specimens and that this is associated with a poor survival rate and lymphatic metastasis in lung cancer patients, indicating that the upregulation of Hsp90 can potentially facilitate the proliferation and metastasis of lung cancer. Ansamycins have also been shown to be able to bind to a conserved pocket in the NH2-terminal adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-binding domain of Hsp90, inhibiting its activity. A positive correlation between the biosynthesis of @sm$ ansamycin @/sm$ and Anaerotruncus spp. may represent a compensatory impact on lung cancer formation. However, the biosynthesis of @sm$ ansamycin @/sm$ was not significantly different between the lung cancer and normal groups in this study. Although the role of Anaerotruncus spp. in the development of lung cancer requires further investigation, the enrichment of @gm$ Anaerotruncus colihominis @/gm$ has been found in PD-1 blockade non-responders.

The dominant genera in the duodenum of STH were @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ 1, Christensenellaceae R-7 group, Ruminococcus 2, Rikenellaceae RC9 gut group, Eubacterium coprostanoligenes group, Ruminococcaceae NK4A214 group, Saccharofermentans, Ruminococcaceae UCG-014, and Prevotellaceae UCG-001. Relative abundances of Prevotella 1, Ruminococcus 2, and Eubacterium coprostanoligenes group were significantly higher in BLW, DLW, and DLW than in the other group (p < 0.001, p < 0.001, and p = 0.001, respectively). @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ 1 can degrade fiber-derived feeds such as hemicellulose or xylan. In addition, @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ can use starch, monosaccharides, and other noncellulosic @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$. Ruminococcus 2 belongs to Ruminococcus, which primarily inhabits the rumen and hindgut of ruminants and contributes to the degradation of cellulose and starch. Ruminococcus also produces acetic acid, formic acid, and a small amount of lactic acid. Short-chain fatty acids, including formic acid and acetate, have key roles in regulating gut microbiota balance and maintaining the morphology and function of intestinal epithelial cells. The Eubacterium coprostanoligenes group functions in converting cholesterol to coproitol, which can further affect the fat metabolism of a host. The effect of fluoride in caries control may be due to disruption of the ecological balance in the mouth, through prevention of adsorption of salivary glycoproteins to hydroxyapatite or perhaps by inhibiting growth of @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ directly. Fluoride caused inhibition of growth rate of @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ with glucose as the primary energy and @sm$ carbon @/sm$ source. Metabolism of glucose or lactose requires enolase enzyme. It is the most fluoride-sensitive enzyme in the glycolytic pathway. Fermentative growth which is dependent upon glycolysis is inhibited by fluoride and thus blocks phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) synthesis. Since PEP is used for both energy and transport in @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$, fluoride is detrimental to growth for @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$.

The effect of proteolytic starter cultures of Staphylococcus carnosus and @gm$ Staphylococcus xylosus @/gm$ on biogenic amine production was examined during the fermentation process of dry sausages. Microbial counts (lactic acid bacteria, Micrococcaceae and Enterobactenaceae), pH, moisture and proteolysis-related parameters were also studied. The polyamines spermine and spermidine were the main @sm$ amines @/sm$ found in the raw material and they only showed slight fluctuations during the fermentation. The four elaborated batches presented a significant (P < 0.001) formation of tyramine and putrescine. The main rate of @sm$ amine @/sm$ production was during the first three days, when a sharp pH decrease and the development of lactic acid bacteria occurred. Sausages fermented with starters had lower amounts of tyramine than naturally fermented sausages (control), but differences in the Micrococcaceae counts were only significant during the first week of the ripening process. A slight formation of diaminopropane, cadaverine, agmatine, tryptamine and phenylethylamine was observed. The amounts of histamine were constant and remained below 0.5 mg/kg of dry matter, while serotonin, octopamine and dopamine were not detected. The sausages with @gm$ Staphylococcus @/gm$ as starter culture showed strong proteolysis that was correlated with higher pH values than those of the control sausages. However, no positive correlation was found between the proteolysis index and biogenic amine production. Since proteolysis was stronger during the second half of the ripening process, the release of free amino acids as @sm$ amine @/sm$ precursors occurred later than the early @sm$ amine @/sm$ production.

The results suggested that the combination of @sm$ erythrosine @/sm$ and laser light at 532 nm could be a candidate to a photodynamic therapy against @gm$ C. freundii @/gm$.

The effects of hydrated clay minerals on @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ growth and wound progression in infected mice are likely due to a combination of both physical and chemical characteristics of clay minerals. Clays are small phyllosilicate minerals that are commonly grouped into three main classes - smectite, illite and kaolinite - based on their overall crystal layer structure and expandability. Smectite minerals, which include @sm$ montmorillonite clay @/sm$, exhibit high expansion (swelling) capabilities in the presence of water. Conversely, illite and kaolinite are non-expanding clays. We have previously assessed the ability of different hydrated clays to treat MRSA-infected superficial, cutaneous wounds in mice. We demonstrated that natural and ion-exchanged illite clays performed best, as measured by bacterial load, inflammatory response and gross wound morphology with significant decreases in bacterial viability and dermatitis. Topical application of kaolinite clay was the least effective, resulting in the lowest decrease in bacterial load and exhibiting severe dermatitis. Although the CB09 clay mixture used in this study is a heterogeneous mixture of illite-smectite, @sm$ montmorillonite @/sm$, kaolinite, and non-clay minerals with different structural and expansion properties, daily application and removal of the clay poultices could diminish @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ growth due to an unfavorable chemical environment and could result in physical removal of @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ and/or mycolactone via adsorption. Mycolactone plays a central role in the pathogenesis of @gm$ M. ulcerans @/gm$ and is thought to be responsible for most of the tissue destruction that occurs in a Buruli ulcer wound.

The evidence suggests that this pathogenic gut-brain circuit involves: (i) @sm$ lipopolysaccharide @/sm$ (@sm$ LPS @/sm$) from the GI-tract resident enterotoxigenic Gram-negative bacteria @gm$ Bacteroides fragilis @/gm$ (BF-@sm$ LPS @/sm$); (ii) @sm$ LPS @/sm$ transit across the GI-tract barrier into the systemic circulation; (iii) transport of a highly pro-inflammatory systemic BF-@sm$ LPS @/sm$ across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) into the brain-parenchyma and neuronal-cytoplasm; (iv) activation and signaling via the pro-inflammatory NF-kB (p50/p65) transcription-factor complex; (v) NF-kB-coupling and significant up-regulation of the inducible pro-inflammatory microRNA-146a (miRNA-146a) and microRNA-155 (miRNA-155); each containing multiple NF-kB DNA-binding and activation sites in their immediate promoters; and (vi) subsequent down-regulation of miRNA-146a-miRNA-155 regulated mRNA targets such as that encoding complement factor H (CFH), a soluble complement control glycoprotein and key repressor of the innate-immune response. Down-regulated CFH expression activates the complement-system, the major non-cellular component of the innate-immune system while propagating neuro-inflammation. Other GI-tract microbes and their highly complex pro-inflammatory exudates may contribute to this pathogenic GI-tract-brain pathway. We speculate that it may be significant that the first Gram-negative anaerobic bacterial species intensively studied as a potential contributor to the onset of Alzheimer's disease (AD), that being the bacillus @gm$ Bacteroides fragilis @/gm$ appears to utilize damaged or leaky physiological barriers and an activated NF-kB (p50-p65) - pro-inflammatory miRNA-146a-miRNA-155 signaling circuit to convey microbiome-derived pathogenic signals into the brain.

The final evidence that they represent a new order of methanogens was recently given with the isolation of Methanomassiliicoccus luminyenis B10 from human feces  and the culture in consortia of several strains of this order: "Candidatus Methanomethylophilus alvus"  and "@gm$ Candidatus Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$"  from human feces samples, MpT1 and MpM2  from termite gut and "Candidatus Methanogranum caenicola"  from waste treatment sludge. All the culture-based studies agreed on a common methanogenic pathway relying on the obligate dependence of the strains on an external @sm$ H2 @/sm$ source to reduce methyl-compounds into methane. The restriction to this metabolism was previously only observed in two methanogens from digestive tract (Methanosphaera stadtmanae and Methanomicrococcus blatticola) and considered an exception . The apparently large distribution of this obligate metabolism among this novel order of methanogens turns this exception into one of the important pathways among the overall methanogens. It also highlights the need for a more cautious utilisation of the term of "hydrogenotrophic methanogens" which is generally used to refer to methanogens growing on @sm$ H2 @/sm$ + CO2, but also fits for an increasing number of described methanogens growing on @sm$ H2 @/sm$ + methyl-compounds.

The genomes of @gm$ Treponema denticola @/gm$ and Treponema pallidum contain a gene, licCA, which is predicted to encode a fusion protein containing choline kinase and CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activities. Because both organisms have been reported to contain phosphatidylcholine, this raises the possibility that they use a CDP-choline pathway for the biosynthesis of phosphatidylcholine. This report shows that phosphatidylcholine is a major phospholipid in @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$, accounting for 35-40% of total phospholipid. This organism readily incorporated [14C]choline into phosphatidylcholine, indicating the presence of a choline-dependent biosynthetic pathway. The licCA gene was cloned, and recombinant LicCA had choline kinase and CTP:phosphocholine cytidylyltransferase activity. The licCA gene was disrupted in @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$ by erythromycin cassette mutagenesis, resulting in a viable mutant. This disruption completely blocked incorporation of either [14C]choline or 32Pi into phosphatidylcholine. The rate of production of another phospholipid in @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$, phosphatidylethanolamine, was elevated considerably in the licCA mutant, suggesting that the elevated level of this @sm$ lipid @/sm$ compensated for the loss of phosphatidylcholine in the membranes. Thus it appears that @gm$ T. denticola @/gm$ does contain a licCA-dependent CDP-choline pathway for phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis.

The genus @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ contains anaerobic, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped bacteria that present a bifurcated, termed 'bifid', morphology under certain growth conditions in some species. Bifidobacteria are commonly found in animal gastrointestinal tracts including mammals, birds, and insects. These bacteria have been extensively characterized regarding their ability to metabolize host-indigestible @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$, which often enables their persistence within the gut environment.

The genus @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ represents one of the most important bacterial group in human and animal feces. This organism has stringent nutrient requirements and grows poorly outside of the animal gut, making this bacterial group a potentially useful indicator of fecal pollution as previously described. In addition, an advantage in using bifidobacteria instead of other fecal contamination indicators is the host specificity, human or animal, of some groups of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ species contrary to coliforms, which are ubiquitous. The genus @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ has been associated with both negative and positive health outcomes in the wider human population. Increases in the @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ genus have been associated with diets high in plant-based fiber and lower in animal-based fats, as well as with the production of anti-inflammatory fecal short chain fatty acids. As such, gut microbiota dominant in the genus @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ may be linked to potential health benefits. In particular, P. copri has been associated in several studies with improved @sm$ glucose @/sm$ metabolism or overall anti-inflammatory effects of diet.

The gut microbiota includes probiotics (mainly @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ and Bifidobacteria) and opportunistic pathogens (members of the Escherichia/Shigella, Streptococcus, etc.). @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ collaborates with other endogenous, beneficial bacteria to maintain gut homeostasis. Through competition and the production of antimicrobial secondary metabolites, these microbes also play an important role in preventing pathogen colonization. @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ secretion (@sm$ lactic acid @/sm$) is converted to butyric acid by other bacteria in the gut, preventing @sm$ lactic acid @/sm$ accumulation. @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ has also been shown to maintain intestinal barrier integrity by acting on epithelial cells. @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ also stimulates adaptive immune responses by activating macrophages and lymphocytes, indicating its role in the host's immune response. In addition, @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ has been shown to bind to mucosal epithelial cells easily and to play an immunomodulatory role by lowering the expression of proinflammatory interleukin and toll-like receptors. @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$, which is normally beneficial in healthy people, can be invasive and fatal in people with gut dysbiosis. For example, @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ can cause severe infection in immunocompromised people. Over 200 @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$-infected cases with various disorders have been reported. Additional probiotic formulations containing @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ were linked to increased mortality in pancreatitis patients.

The inflammatory manifestations of acne result from @gm$ Propionibacterium acnes @/gm$ colonization, and are of particular relevance as they can develop into nodules and cysts, potentially leading to permanent scarring. Acne severity is classified according to different scales. It is widely agreed, however, that the mild and moderate forms of acne display primary lesions only, while severe acne also includes nodules, cysts, and eventually open lesions. It is noteworthy that acne severity and scarring have been related to @gm$ P. acnes @/gm$ inflammatory factors, bacterial growth metabolites such as allergens, toxins, or @sm$ porphyrins @/sm$, and enzymes.

The intracellular life of @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ in the DC is very interesting. @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ does not get killed or proliferate in the DC population. Intracellular survival of @gm$ S. Typhimurium @/gm$ in murine DC was independent from the function of virulence factors known to be important for survival in macrophages, such as the SPI2-T3SS. Surprisingly, the bacterial LPS O antigen is found to be very crucial to maintain bacterial steady burden in the DCs. As known from previous studies, the effect of CpG mediated TLR-9 activation on @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ proliferation is a cell line dependent phenomenon. In the case of cultured hepatocytes, @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ growth is inhibited by the CpG DNA treatment, whereas in the case of human monocyte-derived macrophages it has no effect. In hepatocytes, an enhanced @sm$ ROS @/sm$ production after the CpG DNA treatment has been attributed to be the cause of decreased @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ burden. However, in bone marrow derived macrophages CpG-antagonist act in a TLR-9 independent manner to inhibit @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ killing. Our study is the first report which indicates that in the dendritic cells CpG DNA enhances @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ killing. We went ahead to check the exact mechanism behind, and noticed that CpG induction leads to an enhanced generation of @sm$ ROS @/sm$ from the infected cells. To look into the mechanism behind this phenomenon, we blocked the @sm$ ROS @/sm$ production in the ligand treated infected dendritic cells. Under that condition this enhanced killing was no more observed. This finding clearly demonstrates that the CpG treatment allows better killing of @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ in a @sm$ ROS @/sm$ dependent manner.

The limited number of @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ antigens makes the identification of sialidase as a novel target of the human immune response notable. Like CT, @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ sialidase is secreted by a type II secretion system and interacts directly with the host enterocyte. @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ sialidase converts higher-order gangliosides into GM1, the receptor for CT, by removing @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ residues. The sialidase-encoding nanH gene is located on Vibrio pathogenicity island 2 (VPI2), a genomic island uniformly present in pathogenic @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ but typically absent in nonpathogenic Vibrio. While these features suggest a key role of the @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ sialidase in the pathogenesis of cholera, sialidase was not shown to potentiate the effects of CT in a rabbit ileal loop model of cholera and had a modest effect on cholera pathogenesis in a suckling mouse model. These studies have led to speculation that sialidase may play a limited role in the pathogenesis of cholera. In our study, sialidase augmented CT responses in vitro, a potentiating effect that, importantly, could be fully neutralized by sialidase-specific human monoclonal antibodies. Thus, our findings support a role for @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ sialidase in host-pathogen interactions in human cholera.

The meat curing processing involves using either nitrite and/or @sm$ nitrate salts @/sm$ to improve meat products' preservation due to the pronounced inhibitory effects of nitrite on anaerobic bacteria, namely @gm$ Clostridium botulinum @/gm$. Aside from acting as an antibotulinal agent, nitrite is also a strong oxidizer and is quickly transformed into nitric oxide, which reacts with the Fe3+ and Fe2+ of both myoglobin and metmyoglobin, respectively. It forms heat stable red-colored complexes, developing the appealing cherry-red color of cured meat, which consumers are used to. However, there has been a growing demand for healthy foods with fewer additives, especially curing salts that may lead to carcinogens formation. No replacement has yet been available on the market that may be capable to present both antimicrobial and color-forming effects in either raw or cooked meat products. Studies have been carried out to inhibit @gm$ Clostridium @/gm$ genus bacteria in meat products without using any @sm$ nitrates @/sm$ and nitrites.

These results indicate that anti-CF serum exerts its protective effect by opsonic activity and that opsonized @gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$ are eliminated mainly by PMN.

The microbes identified in our study have potential roles with respect to wheat such as productivity, health, components like carbon, nitrogen fixation, @sm$ phosphorus @/sm$ solubilization, resistance to diseases, and so on. @gm$ Acinetobacter lwoffii @/gm$ is relatively more abundant in MW (2.7%) than in all other samples. It is an endophytic bacterium that benefit plants by their colonization and acts as a barrier against pathogenic microbes. It plays role in plant growth regulation through nitrogen fixation, siderophores, root growth, and @sm$ phosphorus @/sm$ solubilization. Bacillus species like B. badius (Bur, 0.9%, and TCPF, 0.6%), B. firmus (Org, 3%; TCPF, 2.5%; Bur, 1.7%; and WAPC, 1.2%), B. flexus (highly expressed in Org [73%] and TCPF, WAPC, and TS [all 16%]; MW, 10.9%; and Bur, 4.9%), B. foraminis (Org, 5.7%; TS, 1.6%; TCPF, 1.4%; and WAPC, 0.8%), and B. selenatarsenatis (Bur, 2.9%; Org, 2.3%; and TCPF, 1.5%) expressed in the samples are described, along with their relative abundances. Apart from the above Bacillus species list, there are few species that were very specific to a single sample only, which may be of significant interest. They are B. cereus and B. horikoshii, which were expressed only in the MW (2.4%) and Bur (1%) samples, respectively. All these Bacillus species have wider roles in plant regulation like @sm$ phosphorus @/sm$ solubilization, zinc and silicate solubilization, salt tolerance, siderophore, nitrogen fixation, as producers of phytohormones like cytokinin, as biofertilizers for micronutrients, and as biocontrol agents against pathogens.

The most commonly used microorganisms in probiotics are @sm$ lactic acid @/sm$-producing bacteria belonging to the Lactobacillus and Bifibacterium species, bacillus strains and yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Enterococcus bacteria, more precisely Enterococcus faecium and Enterococcus faecalis, are also commonly used as probiotics. @sm$ Lactic acid @/sm$-producing bacteria, or LAB, complexes are often produced as probiotic blends and can comprise various genera of LAB such as Lactobacillus, @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$, Lactococcus, Enterococcus, Pediococcus, and Streptococcus. The mucin protein is heavily O-glycosylated and has multiple structures of repeating alpha- and beta-linked N-acetyl-galactosamine (GalNAc), N-acetyl-glucosamine (GlcNAc), and galactose (Gal) residues, terminated with alpha-linked fucose (Fuc), and @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ (Neu5Ac) residues. Mucus-degrading bacteria harbor specific glycosyl hydrolases (GHs) that enzymatically degrade mucin glycans. After cleavage, the released glycan oligosaccharides can feed the bacteria or other microbes in the vicinity. In order to degrade mucin glycans, intestinal bacteria must possess GH33 sialidases (also known as neuraminidases), which cleave terminal @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ residues. For efficient glycan cleavage, bacteria can also generate GH29 or GH95 to remove fucose residues. Once the terminal sugars are removed, the underlying GalNAc, GlcNAc, and galactose residues can be removed. Bacteria can have GH101 or GH129 to remove GalNAc, GH84, GH85, GH89, or GH20 to remove GlcNAc, or GH2, GH35, GH42, and GH98 to remove galactose residues. Some bacteria also encode for GH16, endo-acting O-glycanases that remove larger glycan structures. A recent genome analysis confirmed that B. bifidum harbored the largest repertoire of mucus-degrading GHs among the Bifidobacterium species. All B. bifidum genomes had GH33, GH29, GH95, GH20, GH2, GH42, GH101, GH129, GH89, and GH84, suggesting that this species was capable of cleaving @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$, fucose, GalNAc, GlcNAc, and galactose from mucus glycans. B. breve, B. longum, and B. scardovii were also found to possess multiple mucus-associated GHs. This finding is consistent with other genome studies and in vitro studies, which report that B. bifidum, B. longum, and B. breve can degrade mucus. In contrast, B. adolescentis, B. angulatum, B. animalis, B. dentium, B. pseudolongum, and @gm$ B. thermophilum @/gm$ possessed few mucus-associated GHs.

The multienzyme complexes system can efficiently degrade @sm$ cellulose @/sm$ or resistant starch by interacting with dockerins and cohesins domains. This system has been found in @gm$ Ruminococcus champanellensis @/gm$ in human feces; dockerin is a small domain found in enzyme components and cohesin is a beta-sandwich domain found in non-catalytic scaffold proteins that provides carbohydrate binding and/or cell wall anchoring functions. These findings show that at least some Firmicutes in the microbiome have evolved to use @sm$ cellulose @/sm$ in the human gut.

The nan cluster of @gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$, a food-borne pathogen, consists of two divergently transcribed operons, nanT(PSL)AR and nanEK nagA, required for transport and catabolism of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac). A mutation of nanR abolished the extensive lag phase observed for the bacteria growing on Neu5Ac and increased transcription of nanT(P) and nanE, suggesting that NanR is a transcriptional repressor of both nan operons. Intracellular accumulation of Neu5Ac was dependent on the @sm$ carbon @/sm$ source, implying that the nan operons are also subject to catabolite repression. Hence, cAMP receptor protein (CRP) appeared to activate and repress transcription of nanT(PSL)AR and nanEK nagA, respectively. Direct bindings of NanR and CRP to the nanT(P)-nanE intergenic DNA were demonstrated by EMSA. Two adjacent NanR-binding sites centered at +44.5 and -10 and a CRP-binding site centered at -60.5 from the transcription start site of nanT(P) were identified by DNase I protection assays. Mutagenesis approaches, in vitro transcription, and isothermal titration calorimetry experiments demonstrated that N-acetylmannosamine 6-phosphate specifically binds to NanR and functions as the inducer of the nan operons. The combined results propose a model in which NanR, CRP, and N-acetylmannosamine 6-phosphate cooperate for precise adjustment of the expression level of the @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ nan cluster.

The objective of this study was to evaluate the antimicrobial effect of the combination of the photosensitizers (PSs) erythrosine/@sm$ methylene blue @/sm$ activated by a white halogen light device on Streptococcus mutans biofilm. METHODS: Two separate experiments were conducted, the first using the PSs at the concentration of 100 muM, and the second 250 muM. The PSs were tested on @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ biofilms cultured for 24 h in isolation, in combination, with and without light activation for 2 min fractionated in 4 periods of 30 s. After treatment, biofilms were diluted and plated on BHI medium and incubated for 24 h for colony forming units (CFU) counting. The results (log10) were analyzed with ANOVA followed by Tukey test (p < 0.05). RESULTS: The erythrosine/@sm$ methylene blue @/sm$ combination activated by white halogen light at 100 and 250 muM, and erythrosine at 250 muM, @sm$ methylene blue @/sm$ at 250 muM presented significantly reduced cell counts (3.2 log10, 5.3 log10, 4.5 log10, 4.3 log10, respectively) when compared to controls (p < 0.05). CONCLUSION: PDT with the combination of erythrosine/@sm$ methylene blue @/sm$ demonstrated better results that the PSs in isolation regardless of the concentration.

The patterns of Prevotella and @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ in prediabetes and T2D are highly inconsistent across cohorts as shown in our and other studies. Higher abundance of P. copri in the gut microbiota has been suggested to be both conducive and detrimental to @sm$ glucose @/sm$ homeostasis and host metabolism in different studies, and its role in human health is still under investigation. Tett et al. found no association between the prevalence and abundance of the four P. copri clades and the etiology of several diseases, including T2D. However, the two cohorts of T2D included in the Tett et al.'s study are from the Chinese and European populations that generally have low prevalence of P. copri dominated by clade A. Therefore, the potential clade-specific effects of P. copri in T2D require further investigation in Prevotella-rich populations with non-Westernized P. copri clades using metagenomic sequencing. Additionally, we propose a scenario where some of the observed microbiota signatures in Pakistani T2D patients, namely the reduction in Prevotella and expansion in @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and butyrate production capacity, are reflective of their transitioning gut microbial ecosystem toward the industrialized one. Supporting this, the microbiota profiling of non-industrialized/non-urbanized African communities suggests a different ecological layout supporting SCFA production with little or no contribution from @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and typical butyrate producers, corresponding to their "high-propionate and low-butyrate" SCFA profile. In general, the effects of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ and butyrate in promoting human health have been understudied in non-Western populations, where human-microbe associations may need to be interpreted in an entirely different context.

The permease and ATPase subunits (Wzm and Wzt) are encoded by the first two ORFs of the OAg locus and are closely related to enzymes encoded by @sm$ polysaccharide @/sm$ biosynthesis gene clusters in Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae and Aggregatibacter aphrophilus, also members of the Pasteurellaceae family. Modal chain length regulation in ABC transporter dependent OAg systems is poorly understood; in some E. coli serotypes, chain termination and transport occurs upon methylation of the terminal sugar. No methylated sugars were found in the @gm$ H. parainfluenzae @/gm$ 13 OAg by structural analysis (Twelkmeyer et al., manuscript in preparation) and none of the proteins encoded by its OAg locus is predicted to contain the coiled coil motif that is typical of methyltransferases, suggesting that the tight OAg chain length distribution in this strain is controlled by a different mechanism. Following the ABC transporter nucleotide-binding domain classification scheme of, the @gm$ H. parainfluenzae @/gm$ strain 13 Wzt protein falls into phylogenetic group D. Members of this group lack C-terminal extensions and the @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$ that they transport do not typically contain chain-terminating modifications.

The polyphosphate glucokinases can phosphorylate @sm$ glucose @/sm$ to glucose 6-phosphate using polyphosphate as the substrate. ORF all1371 encodes a putative polyphosphate glucokinase in the filamentous heterocyst-forming cyanobacterium Anabaena sp. PCC 7120. Here, ORF all1371 was heterologously expressed in @gm$ Escherichia coli @/gm$, and its purified product was characterized. Enzyme activity assays revealed that All1371 is an active polyphosphate glucokinase that can phosphorylate both @sm$ glucose @/sm$ and mannose in the presence of divalent cations in vitro. Unlike many other polyphosphate glucokinases, for which nucleoside triphosphates (e.g. ATP or GTP) act as phosphoryl group donors, All1371 required polyphosphate to confer its enzymic activity. The enzymic reaction catalysed by All1371 followed classical Michaelis-Menten kinetics, with kcat = 48.2 s(-1) at pH 7.5 and 28  C and KM = 1.76 microM and 0.118 mM for polyphosphate and @sm$ glucose @/sm$, respectively.
