The presence of lactic acid is key to a healthy homeostasis of the vagina and its production comes from two different sources: by the vaginal epithelium (mainly L-lactate representing 20% of the total lactic acid) and by the microbiota, responsible for metabolizing approximately 80% of @sm$ glycogen @/sm$ producing the two isoforms of lactic acid with a predominance of D-lactic acid. When the squamous epithelium requires energy in the form of ATP, the @sm$ glycogen @/sm$ from the vaginal epithelial cells is converted to glucose, then to pyruvate, and from this to lactic acid, which is released into the vaginal lumen as the epithelium undergoes desquamation. This production of lactic acid is performed under the control of the estrogen levels present in the blood, as these promote maturation and deposition in the vaginal epithelial cells. Therefore, due to the known change in estrogens production throughout the woman's life cycle, the vaginal ecosystem can be subjected to modifications. The second and main mechanism for producing lactic acid comes from the @sm$ glycogen @/sm$ found in the vaginal lumen, which is catabolized by alpha amylases to produce maltose, maltotriose and alpha dextrins, which are subsequently converted into lactic acid, due to the action of the @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$-stimulated lactic dehydrogenase.

The present clinical trial has been carried out in order to evaluate the efficacy of @sm$ benzydamine @/sm$ in treatment of vaginitis caused by @gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$. Fifty women affected by this specific pathology have been submitted to topical treatment with 0.5% @sm$ benzydamine @/sm$ vaginal cream. The treatment has been carried out for 9 consecutive days using a local application of @sm$ benzydamine @/sm$ twice a day. The clinical result was evaluated after 12 and 60 days. The following parameters were taken into consideration: symptoms (leucorrhea, itching, burning), clinical signs (oedema, hyperemia, vaginal secretion), instrumental data (pH, colposcopy, sniff test) and microbiological findings (searching of clue cells, Lactobacillus and @gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$). At the first check point after 12 days 84% of patients have been considered healed; at the second check the percentage of healing rose to 92%. Therefore @sm$ benzydamine @/sm$ was considered highly effective in 92% of vaginitis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis.

The principal products of endogenous metabolism of the obligate anaerobe @gm$ Peptococcus prevotii @/gm$ were carbon dioxide, ammonia, @sm$ acetate @/sm$ and butyrate, which are also produced by fermentation of nucleosides, purines and ribose, thus supporting our previous finding that RNA is the only cellular component to undergo substantial degradation under starvation conditions. Minor products were hydrogen, formate and propionate. The stoicheiometries of fermentation of xanthine, adenine, adenosine and ribose were determined. The ability to ferment exogenous nucleosides, purines and ribose declined rapidly on starvation, as did the ability to generate ATP from xanthine, and was paralleled by the loss of viability. However, addition of pulses of xanthine or adenine to organisms in the early stages of starvation sustained their adenylate energy charge and prolonged their viability. Evidence suggests that @gm$ P. prevotii @/gm$ dies when its principal energy source (RNA) is depleted, and a possible explanation is that the transport function of the cytoplasmic membrane decays rapidly under these conditions so that, on transfer to a recovery medium, uptake of nutrients is inadequate to support growth.

The protective effects of Caulis Spatholobi polysaccharide (CSP) on immune function, intestinal mucosal barrier, and intestinal microflora in @sm$ cyclophosphamide @/sm$ (@sm$ CY @/sm$)-induced immunosuppressed chickens have been rarely reported. This study was designed to investigate the cecal microbiota in chickens and to elucidate the immune mechanism involved in the CSP effect on @sm$ CY @/sm$ induced-immunosuppressed chickens. A total of 288 cocks were equally divided into six groups and used to evaluate the immune effect of CSP. Results showed that the CSP increased the body weight and immune organ index of immunosuppressed chickens, significantly increased the secretion of cytokines (IL-4, IL-10) and immunoglobulins (IgG, IgM) in sera of chickens, and restored the body immune function. The CSP reduced intestinal injury of the jejunum and ileum, increased the ratio of the intestinal villus height to crypt depth (V/C), improved the expression of tight junction protein, and protected intestinal health. The CSP activated the toll-like receptor (TLR)/MyD88/NF-kappaB pathway and enhanced the expression of TLR4, MyD88, NF-kappaB, Claudin1, and Zo-1, protecting the intestinal tract. High-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene showed that CSP increased species richness, restored @sm$ CY @/sm$-induced intestinal microbiome imbalance, and enhanced the abundance of @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ in the intestinal tract.

The purpose of the present study was to determine the prevalence of @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ in poultry carcasses at slaughter in Poland. For the isolated strains, resistance to selected antibiotics and the associated genetic determinants were identified. A total of 498 @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ isolates were obtained from 802 poultry samples during the 2-year study period. Strains were identified to species with the PCR method; 53.6% of the strains were Campylobacter jejuni and 46.4% were @gm$ Campylobacter coli @/gm$. A high percentage of the tested @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ strains were resistant to ciprofloxacin and nalidixic acid (74.1 and 73.5%, respectively) followed by @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ (47.4%) and streptomycin (20.5%). Only one C. jejuni and two @gm$ C. coli @/gm$ isolates were resistant to gentamicin. Seventy-nine (15.9%) of the 498 strains were resistant to three or more classes of antibiotics examined. Higher levels of resistance, irrespective of the antimicrobial agent tested, were found within the @gm$ C. coli @/gm$ group. Almost all strains resistant to quinolones (99.5%) and to @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ (99.6%) carried the Thr-86-to-Ile mutation in the gyrA gene and possessed the tet(O) marker, respectively. All isolates resistant to erythromycin had the A2075G mutation in the 23S rRNA gene. These results reveal that poultry carcasses in Poland are a reservoir of potentially pathogenic and antimicrobial-resistant @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ strains for humans, which may pose a public health risk.

The purpose of this study was to determine the presence of @sm$ lipopolysaccharide @/sm$-like material in the intestinal spirochaete @gm$ Serpulina pilosicoli @/gm$ and the extent of antigenic cross-reactivity of this material in different strains of the species. Hot water-phenol, aqueous-phase extracts from five porcine and three human strains of @gm$ S. pilosicoli @/gm$, and from seven strains of four other Serpulina spp., were separated by SDS-PAGE and silver-stained profiles were obtained. All @gm$ S. pilosicoli @/gm$ strains had a predominant band at c. 16 kDa. Some also had a partial ladder-like profile, consistent with the presence of semi-rough lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS); this was more obvious in Western immunoblot analysis. LOS from each @gm$ S. pilosicoli @/gm$ strain was serologically distinct in immunoblot analysis and there was no cross-reactivity with other Serpulina spp. The serological diversity found amongst the LOS of @gm$ S. pilosicoli @/gm$ strains may help to explain why individual people and animals can suffer repeated infections with different strains of the organism.

In this study, the genus @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ was significantly increased after EPS-m2 treatment at 24 and 72 h. The more abundant @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ might be linked to EPS-m2 degradation in the human intestine. It has been reported that Acinetobacter can degrade and use benzyl alcohol, black liquor, and kraft lignin as carbon sources. However, there is no report that Acinetobacter was related to degrading bacterial polysaccharides. Also, the abundance of genera Alloprevotella increased during in vitro fermentation of bee-collected pollen of Chinese wolfberry. Recently, studies have revealed that the high-fiber group is associated with increased abundances of Oxalobacter compared with the low-fiber group. The relative abundance of Weissneria and @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$ increased, and they gradually became the dominant microorganisms. This was similar to the results of "three-phase evolution," which has been discussed in recent studies. Regardless of the type of flour, naturally fermented sourdoughs go through three stages in the fermentation process, which were comprised of "the three-phase evolution." They are (i) dominance of LAB species belonging to the genera Enterococcus, @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$, and Leuconostoc; (ii) increasingly important presence of sourdough-specific LAB, such as Pediococcus and Weissella; and (iii) dominance of well-adapted sourdough strains, including heterofermentative species. The microbial community changes of LAB were mainly related to the degree of microbial tolerance to acidic environments and the way the microorganisms used @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ and nitrogen sources in the fermentation substrate.

The results from the ZOI test of the SNAP-PEG coating unveiled a significant difference in the diameter of the inhibited zone of growth for each tested formulation containing 1, 5, and 10 wt % of @sm$ SNAP @/sm$, and no zone of inhibition was observed for the control PEG sample, which was expected since the PEG control coating lacked any inherent antibacterial mechanism of action. The lack of a zone and the subsequent absence of antibacterial activity in the control PEG samples confirmed that the observed antibacterial effects were primarily attributed to the presence of @sm$ SNAP @/sm$ in the coating. The increased zone of inhibition was observed to be directly proportional to the increasing concentration of @sm$ SNAP @/sm$ present in the coating (Figure 4B,C). On average, the ZOI against @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ for the 5 wt % samples was 3.2 +- 0.54 mm2 and 7.5 +- 0.28 mm2 for 10 wt %. Similarly, the ZOI for E. coli was 7.5 +- 0.67 mm2 for 5 wt % and 14.8 +- 0.46 mm2 for 10 wt %. The ZOI for @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ against the 10 wt % SNAP-PEG coating had approximately 2x more than the 5 wt % (p < 0.05). Comparatively, the zone of inhibition for E. coli against the 10 wt % SNAP-PEG coating had approximately 2x and greater ZOI than the 1 and 5 wt %, respectively (p < 0.05). The surgical procedure for retrograde pancreatic ductal infusion of the @gm$ AAV6 @/gm$ was as previously described. Briefly, 100 muL of purified @gm$ AAV6 @/gm$ (titer 2 x 1012 plaque-forming units) was infused into the biliopancreatic duct at a rate of 10 muL/min for 10 minutes using a P33 peristaltic syringe pump (Harvard Apparatus, Holliston, MA). Surgical anesthesia was achieved by inhaling isoflurane and @sm$ oxygen @/sm$. A single injection of the analgesic buprenorphine (0.075 mg/kg) was given immediately after the surgery. Mice recovered on a heating pad for 30 minutes and were housed for 4-6 weeks with free access to food and water before induction of PEP. To verify the efficacy of the @gm$ AAV6 @/gm$ infusion, LSL-Tm mice were used.

The survival of single strains of @gm$ Bifidobacterium breve @/gm$, Bifidobacterium longum, Lactobacillus acidophilus, and Lactobacillus reuteri was investigated in synbiotics that included 10 mg/ml of fructo-oligosaccharides, inulin and pectic-oligosaccharides in an alginate matrix under refrigerated (4  C) aerobic storage conditions. When the matrices were cross-linked with @sm$ calcium @/sm$ (45 mM), 102-103 cfu/ml of L. acidophilus and L. reuteri, and 0-103 cfu/ml of B. breve and B. longum survived refrigerated aerobic storage for 28 days. Following refrigerated storage, acetic (3-9 mM), butyric (0-2 mM), propionic (5-16 mM) and lactic acids (1-48 mM) were produced during the growth of probiotics in BHI broth at 37  C, suggesting their metabolic activity after storage was stressed. When @sm$ calcium @/sm$ cross-linking was not used in synbiotics, the matrix remained more gel-like after inoculation when compared to the @sm$ calcium @/sm$ cross-linked matrix.

The tet gene is known to be responsible for @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ resistance. Most tet genes originated from periodontal pathogens such as P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum. The percentage of @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$-resistant isolates in dental plaque-associated bacteria is high in children from South Asia and Japan. Isolates of T. denticola that are resistant to @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ have also been reported. Resistance to @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ is a frequent co-marker among penicillin-resistant species of oral origin. Resistance to erythromycin usually occurs due to acquiring two significant genes, ermF and erm. Major periodontal bacteria such as T. forsythia and P. gingivalis can carry both emr and tet resistance genes. Clindamycin resistance shows a high prevalence among periodontal isolates of F. nucleatum (36%), P. gingivalis (23%), and @gm$ Prevotella melaninogenica @/gm$ (22%) in Columbia.

The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the most established organism for ethanol production, efficiently converts @sm$ glucose @/sm$ and other hexoses to ethanol. In addition, the yeast Brettanomyces bruxellensis and the bacterium Zymomonas mobilis can produce ethanol under industrial conditions (Blomqvist and Passoth; Gupta et al.); it has for instance been shown that B. bruxellensis can ferment oat straw hydrolysate to ethanol (Tiukova et al.). Those industrial ethanol producers have a high ethanol tolerance and they can adapt to inhibitors present in lignocellulose hydrolysate (e.g. Blomqvist et al.; Tiukova et al.). However, these microorganisms cannot assimilate xylose and other pentoses derived from hemicellulose. To obtain an economically feasible ethanol process from lignocellulose, it is also desirable to convert the hemicellulose sugars to ethanol. Substantial efforts have been made to obtain xylose-fermenting, inhibitor-tolerant S. cerevisiae strains (Passoth; Passoth). Finally, by a combination of metabolic and evolutionary engineering of industrial S. cerevisiae isolates, strains were obtained that can ferment both @sm$ glucose @/sm$ and xylose in lignocellulose hydrolysate. These strains overexpress specific transporters for xylose, the pentose-phosphate pathway, and the xylose assimilation pathway:either xylose reductase/xylitol dehydrogenase of the xylose-fermenting yeast Scheffersomyces stipitis (Garcia Sanchez et al.) or a codon-optimised xylose isomerase from @gm$ Clostridium phytofermentans @/gm$ (Demeke et al.; Demeke et al., Fig.

These probes were mainly comprised of gold nanoparticles conjugated with capturing DNA probes of 20-mer @sm$ oligonucleotides @/sm$ specifically targeting Sdf I sequence of @gm$ S. Enteritidis @/gm$ (Figure S1). The capturing DNA @sm$ oligonucleotides @/sm$ are preferentially modified with a thiol group at 3' end and a Raman active dye of cy5 at the thymine nucleotide exists at position 6 from the same end of DNA to allow controlled and directional coupling of the @sm$ oligonucleotides @/sm$ to gold nanoparticles. This eventually brings cy5 in the close proximity (< 2 nm) to the surface of gold nanoparticles, allowing a significant enhancement of Raman signal intensity. When these probes are added to the target DNA, and as a result for the specific hybridization of cy5 labeled DNA capturing probes to its complementary sequence, Au nanoprobes-target DNA hybridization complexes are formed and easily detected using SERS based upon the distinctive Raman spectral features of cy5. In addition, we relied on an enzyme digestion step using S1 nuclease to differentiate the presence and absence of target DNA. S1 nuclease is known to specifically degrade single-stranded (ss) DNA into free mononucleotides (dNTPs). In the presence of the target DNA, the probes specifically bind to its complementary sequence and form a double-stranded DNA structure in which the complex cy5-DNAs are protected from nuclease digestion and eventually cy5 remains linked to the surface of gold nanoparticles. In contrast, in the absence of the target DNA, S1 nuclease triggers the release of cy5 from the surface of gold nanoparticles by digesting the surface capturing DNA @sm$ oligonucleotides @/sm$ of Au-nanoprobes, resulting in a significantly reduced Raman signal intensity.

Furthermore, some pathogenic G- bacteria produce another type of vesicle, called Inner Outer Membrane Vesicles (IOMVs). They contain pieces from both cytoplasmic and periplasmic membranes and are enriched with ATPs and DNA. Three models demonstrating OMV production were reviewed by C. Volgers and his team in 2018 (Figure 2). These models suggest that the production technique maintains the outer membrane homeostatic state. Accordingly, OMVs are produced when outer membrane asymmetry is achieved (Model A), misfolded proteins are condensed in the outer membrane (Model B), and lipopolysaccharides are modified (Model C). The outer membrane of G- bacteria is characterized by the asymmetric distribution of @sm$ lipids @/sm$ with lipopolysaccharides on the outer side and phospholipids on the inner side of the membrane. Defects in this asymmetric distribution lead to increased microbial vesiculation (Model A). Furthermore, model A can be achieved by reduced interactions between the outer membrane @sm$ lipids @/sm$ and the peptidoglycan layer. The genes involved in this model include genes encoding the proteins associated with the peptidoglycan layer, such as: Oprl, OmpA, Pal or TolA in Pseudomonas aeruginosa; TolA, TolQ and Tol/Pal in E. coli; OmpA in Acinetobacter baumannii; and the ABC-transporter VacJ/YrbC in Haemophilus influenzae and @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$, and its homolog, Mla, in E.

This study examined the antibacterial activities of a triclosan containing (Seal & Protect), a benzalconium containing desensitizer (Micro Prime), a @sm$ fluoride @/sm$ containing prophilaxy paste (Sultan Desensitizer), two @sm$ fluoride @/sm$ containing varnishes (Cavity Shealth and Ultra EZ), and a dentin bonding primer (All Bond). METHODS: The test materials were inserted in the wells of Muller Hinton agar plates inoculated with @gm$ Streptococcus mutans @/gm$, Streptococcus salivarious, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus faecalis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The diameters of the inhibition zones produced around the materials were measured after 24 h of incubation. The results were analyzed by the Kruskal Wallis one way ANOVA and the Mann-Whitney tests at a significance level of P<.05. RESULTS: Micro Prime Desensitizer containing benzalkonium chloride had the highest antibacterial effectiveness compared to other desensitizers used in this study. In addition, triclosan containing Seal & Protect and acidic components containing All Bond showed very high antibacterial efficacy. On the other hand, @sm$ fluoride @/sm$ within both varnishes had little antibacterial effectiveness. However a @sm$ fluoride @/sm$ component in a paste (Sultan Desensitizer) showed very high bactericidal effect.

This study examines the use of a covalently @sm$ selenium @/sm$-bonded peptide and phage that binds to the @gm$ Yersinia pestis @/gm$ F1 antigen for the targeting and killing of E. coli expressing this surface antigen. Using a Ph.D.-12 phage-display library for affinity selection of the phage which would bind the F1 antigen of @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$, a phage displaying a peptide that binds the F1 antigen with high affinity and specificity was identified. @sm$ Selenium @/sm$ was then covalently attached to the display phage and the corresponding F1-antigen-binding peptide. Both the phage and peptides with @sm$ selenium @/sm$ covalently attached retained their binding specificity for the @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ F1 antigen. The phage or peptide not labeled with @sm$ selenium @/sm$ did not kill the targeted bacteria, while the phage or peptide labeled with @sm$ selenium @/sm$ did. In addition, the seleno-peptide, expressing the F1 targeting sequence only, killed cells expressing the F1 antigen but not the parent strain that did not express the F1 antigen. Specifically, the seleno-peptide could kill eight logs of bacteria in less than two hours at a 10-microM concentration. These results demonstrate a novel approach for the development of an antibacterial agent that can target a specific bacterial pathogen for destruction through the use of covalently attached @sm$ selenium @/sm$ and will not affect other bacteria.

This study further strengthened that @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ MM045 is a potentially effective bacterium that completely degrades high and low molecular weight of PAHs within 24 h. This has further highlighted the good metabolic strength of @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ MM045 in degrading PAHs, which might be previously endorsed from the contaminated environment.

The addition of glycerol, sucrose and @sm$ inulin @/sm$ strongly enhanced the viability of B.

This study investigates the antibacterial effects of erbium chromium laser at 2780 nm, silver nanoparticles, and erbium chromium along with silver nanoparticles on @gm$ Enterococcus faecalis @/gm$ in comparison with @sm$ sodium hypochlorite @/sm$. In the present study, 90 extracted human single-rooted teeth were selected and standardized to a length of 15 mm. The samples were divided into four experimental groups including @sm$ hypochlorite sodium @/sm$, silver nanoparticle, erbium chromium laser, and erbium chromium laser along with silver nanoparticle groups. Results showed that there was a significant reduction in colony count for all groups after interventions. Moreover, there was a significant reduction in the colony count for @sm$ sodium hypochlorite @/sm$ group in comparison with another groups, and this group showed the highest reduction of colony count. There was a significant difference between silver nanoparticles and erbium chromium laser groups in colony count. According to the results, the silver nanoparticles offered strong antibacterial effects on @gm$ E. faecalis @/gm$ and therefore can decrease bacterial colonies, while the use of the laser, despite the reduction of the bacterial colony, could not be sufficiently used for disinfection of root canal system.

Three @gm$ Porphyromonas @/gm$ species (@gm$ Porphyromonas asaccharolytica @/gm$, P. endodontalis, and the novel species that is the subject of the present report, P. uenonis) are very much alike in terms of biochemical characteristics, such as enzyme profiles and cellular fatty acid contents. @gm$ P. asaccharolytica @/gm$ is distinguished from the other two species by virtue of production of alpha-fucosidase and @sm$ glyoxylic acid @/sm$ positivity. The novel species is difficult to differentiate from P. endodontalis phenotypically and was designated a P. endodontalis-like organism for some time. However, P. endodontalis is recovered almost exclusively from oral sources and also grows poorly on Biolog Universal Agar, both characteristics that are in contrast to those of the other two organisms. Furthermore, P. uenonis is glycerol positive in the Biolog AN Microplate system. Both @gm$ P. asaccharolytica @/gm$ and P. uenonis are positive by 13 other tests in the Biolog system, whereas P. endodontalis is negative by all of these tests. @gm$ P. asaccharolytica @/gm$ grew well in both solid and liquid media without supplementation with 5% horse serum, whereas the other two species grew poorly without supplementation. Sequencing of 16S rRNA revealed about 10% divergence between the novel species and P. endodontalis but less than 2% sequence difference between the novel species and @gm$ P. asaccharolytica @/gm$. Subsequent DNA-DNA hybridization studies documented that the novel organism was indeed distinct from @gm$ P. asaccharolytica @/gm$.

Tigecycline, polymyxins, @sm$ carbapenems @/sm$, aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, fosfomycin, rifampicin, ampicillin-sulbactam, piperacillin-tazobactam, and tetracyclines (minocycline and doxycycline) are common antibiotics that have been used in combinations. Although colistin, tigecycline, and some aminoglycosides remain most likely to be active in vitro against @sm$ carbapenem @/sm$-hydrolyzing beta-lactamases producing Enterobacteriaceae, current data do not reliably support the use of these agents as monotherapy for systemic infections. However, most studies have been conducted to determine the in vitro activity of combination therapy against @gm$ Klebsiella pneumoniae @/gm$ carbapenemase (KPC)-producing @gm$ Klebsiella pneumoniae @/gm$. Enhanced activity was noted following treatment with doxycycline combined with amikacin against KPC-producing @gm$ K. pneumoniae @/gm$ isolates in a recent study; however, other in vitro studies of the combination effect of an aminoglycoside-amikacin with doxycycline or tigecycline against multi-drug resistant E. coli are rare. The goal of this study was to assess the in vitro antibacterial activity of the combinations of an aminoglycoside (amikacin) and doxycycline or tigecycline against ESBL-, @sm$ carbapenem @/sm$-resistant, New Delhi Metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM)- and KPC-producing E.

To demonstrate the utility of this system, we focused on @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ (@sm$ N-acetylneuraminic acid @/sm$), a sugar liberated from the gut mucosa by sialidases expressed by certain commensal bacteria lacking the necessary enzymes for @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ catabolism. Free @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ is a nutrient source for the antibiotic-associated enteric pathogens @gm$ Clostridium difficile @/gm$ and Salmonella typhimurium, and can determine pathogen burden in mouse models. Mucosal glycoproteins carrying @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ also serve as viral receptors. Despite this broad importance, how commensal sialidase activity determines @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ levels in the gut lumen is unexplored. While a healthy microbiota has been reported to produce low levels of free @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$, at least one antibiotic formulation alters the community to increase luminal @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ concentrations, creating a pathogen-sensitive state. It is unknown whether antibiotic-induced @sm$ sialic acid @/sm$ release reflects a specific reconfiguration of the microbiota dependent on the initial community composition and antibiotics used, or instead is a result of fundamental properties of this microbiome-host interaction.

To determine if the released compounds (including metabolic byproducts and PBPs) from BU could impact butyrate producer growth, we characterized the growth of butyrate producers in BU conditioned @sm$ glycan @/sm$ media. We computed the ratio of total growth (area under the curve or AUC) of each butyrate producer in conditioned @sm$ glycan @/sm$ media (AUCCM) to the corresponding fresh media (AUCFM). This metric showed that the conditioned @sm$ glycan @/sm$ media enhanced the growth of butyrate producers across many conditions. For instance, a growth benefit for all butyrate producers was observed in conditioned inulin or laminarin media, whereas a negligible growth benefit was observed for other conditions such as @gm$ CC @/gm$ in conditioned xyloglucan media (Figure S8B and Supplementary Data 5). Therefore, our results demonstrate that the effect of released compounds from BU on the growth of each butyrate producer was determined by the specific @sm$ glycan @/sm$, consistent with the @sm$ glycan @/sm$-dependent variation in the inferred inter-species interaction networks of the communities (Figure 5B).

To evaluate the impact of @sm$ IBU @/sm$ on EC migration, a scratch assay has been performed. Data showed that early treatment of @gm$ Pg @/gm$-LPS-stimulated EC with @sm$ IBU @/sm$ significantly reduced their migration rate (42% decrease at 12 h; p < 0.05) (Figure 2C).

To evaluate the resistance trends of isolated strains, ciprofloxacin (CIP), ceftriaxone (CRO), meropenem (MER), gentamicin (GEN; relevant in case of @gm$ Citrobacter @/gm$ and Enterobacter spp.), and sulfamethoxazole/trimetoprim (SXT) were chosen as indicator antibiotics based on local antibiotic utilization data. In addition, susceptibility data for @sm$ doxycycline @/sm$ (@sm$ DOX @/sm$; relevant in case of @gm$ Citrobacter @/gm$ and Enterobacter spp.) was available for the first half (2008-2012) of the study period, and for fosfomycin (FOS), data was available for the second half (2013-2017) of the study period.

To expand the structure-activity relationship within this scaffold and further understand the role of indole in the antibacterial activity, we synthesized NQE derivatives with and without substituent at the carbon bearing the epoxide and tested their inhibitory activity against @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ ATCC 29213 (see Supporting Information, Table S3). Not surprisingly, we found that these compounds were significantly less effective in inhibiting @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$ compared to their indole counterparts. Furthermore, the @sm$ quinones @/sm$ containing indoles were also relatively poor inhibitors (see Supporting Information, Table S4). Previously, Sieber and co-workers have reported aminoepoxycyclohexenones with higher MICs; one analogue with an indole tether was found to have good potency against @gm$ S. aureus @/gm$.

To further analyze the impact of sphingolipid-deficient @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$ colonization on barrier function, we first looked at transcriptional levels of tight-junction proteins TJP1 and CLDN2 in the colon, but both remained unchanged between BTWT- and BTDeltaSPT-colonized mice (Fig. S3H, I). We then cultured colonic epithelial monolayers in vitro and used @sm$ lipid @/sm$ extracts from BTWT and BTDeltaSPT strains as stimulants. Comparing the transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) of monolayers after 24 hours, we observed no difference between monolayers stimulated with BTWT or BTDeltaSPT extracts (Fig. S3J). We next tested whether @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$ sphingolipids altered the ability of monolayers to repair after injury by performing a calcium switch assay but found no difference in recovery between monolayers stimulated with BTWT or BTDeltaSPT extracts (Fig. S3K). Thus, the barrier dysfunction and inflammation seen in our in vivo data likely involves an immune component and more than only @sm$ lipid @/sm$-epithelial interactions.

To identify @gm$ Yersinia pestis @/gm$ genes involved in the microbe's resistance to cationic antimicrobial @sm$ peptides @/sm$, the strategy of random transposon mutagenesis with a Tn5 minitransposon was used, and the library was screened for detecting polymyxin B (PMB) susceptible mutants. The mutation responsible for PMB-sensitive phenotype and the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) structure were characterized for the @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ strain KM218-A3. In this strain the mini-Tn5 was located in an open reading frame with the product homologous to the E. coli protein GmhB (82% identity) functioning as d-glycero-d-manno-heptose-1,7-diphosphate phosphatase. ESI FT ICR mass spectrometry of anions was used to study the structure of the unmodified LPS of Y. pestis KM218-A3, and molecules were revealed with the full-size LPS core or with two types of an incomplete core: consisting of Kdo-Kdo or Ko-Kdo disaccharides and Hep-(Kdo)-Kdo or Hep-(Ko)-Kdo trisaccharides. The performed complementation confirmed that the defect in the biological properties of the mutant strain was caused by inactivation of the gmhB gene. These findings indicated that the gmhB gene product of @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ is essential for production of wild-type LPS resistant to antimicrobial @sm$ peptides @/sm$ and serum.

To identify genes unique to ESOS44-1 and shared by ESOS44-4, first, comparative genomic analyses were performed against the other nine @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolates, with a total of 60 proteins found to be unique to ESOS44-1 (Fig. 4A; Additional file 1: Table S15). A substantial number of these unique proteins were found in syntenic groups, with two large regions corresponding to Prophage CP4-57 (region I) and proteins involved in @sm$ lipid A @/sm$ biosynthesis (region II) (Fig. 4A; Additional file 1: Table S15). @sm$ Lipid A @/sm$ modifications are important in modulating outer-membrane permeability, resistance to antimicrobial peptides, and host recognition, whereas prophage CP4-57 has been implicated in acid resistance, biofilm formation, and lactate utilization, suggesting that these elements may contribute to enhanced fitness of this isolate.

To identify the protective or worsening effect on liver damage, we administered four representative species-level bacteria belonging to Ruminococcaceae and Veillonellaceae-Ruminococcus faecis (@gm$ R. faecis @/gm$), R. bromii, Megamonas funiformis (M. funiformis), and Veillonella parvula (V. parvula) to C57BL/6 mice fed @sm$ methionine @/sm$- and choline-deficient (MCD) diets for 5 weeks (Fig. 8a). We demonstrated that @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ feeding decreased serum ALT and AST levels compared to sham feeding (Fig. 8b). No worsening effect was found in mice given M. funiformis and V. parvula. An alleviating effect of @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ on fibrosis was shown with H&E and Sirius red staining (Fig. 8c), and the histological severity of NAFLD induced by an MCD diet was significantly regressed in mice fed @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ (Fig. 8d, e). The mRNA expression of fibrogenic genes (Col1a1, Timp1, and a-SMA) was also downregulated in mice treated with @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ compared to untreated control mice fed an MCD diet (Fig. 8f). In parallel with the changes in biochemical and histological liver injury markers, the cecal levels of secondary bile acids (DCA and LCA) were also decreased by an MCD diet and increased by @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ treatment (Fig. 8g). To confirm the alleviating effect of @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ on liver damage in other mouse NAFLD models, we used a choline-deficient, L-amino acid-defined, high-fat diet (CDAHFD) model which prevents body weight loss in mice and shows no insulin resistance, and a genetic leptin-deficient (db/db) model, which develops spontaneously diabetes and fatty liver with insulin resistance. In both models, @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ administration decreased ALT and AST levels (Supplementary Fig. 12). However, the liver ratio against body weight decreased only in db/db mice. Nevertheless, the fasting insulin levels in serum and insulin resistance measured by ipGTT in db/db mice were not affected by @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$ treatment.

To investigate the adaptation responses of @gm$ A. baumannii @/gm$ to NAg, Ag+ (supplied as AgNO3) and the model antibiotic Nx, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of each antibacterial agent was first determined against strain @gm$ ATCC 19606 @/gm$. From our dose-dependent growth inhibition studies, the MIC was observed to be 1 mug/mL for NAg and 2 mug/mL for Ag+ (Fig. 1A). NAg and Ag+ are known to target cell envelopes, which, in the case of Gram-negative bacteria, such as @gm$ A. baumannii @/gm$, involves damage to phospholipid moieties in their outer and inner membranes. The targeting of the inner membrane is thought to disrupt bacterial respiratory components (embedded within the membrane). For instance, Ag+ can form complexes with electron donor groups in proteins (e.g., thiol and @sm$ amine @/sm$ groups), including those that are present in the respiratory enzyme NADH dehydrogenase. This membrane-targeting activity likely causes electron leakage from respiratory components, which can result in the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that further damage biomolecules, including DNA, lipids, and other proteins. Although there are some similarities, studies have shown that NAg exerts unique antimicrobial mechanisms, compared to Ag+. In an aqueous environment, NAg can undergo oxidative dissolution and release Ag+ ions that can interact with various moieties (including halides, sulfides, and organics) and transform into other distinct silver species, each with its own toxicity. Previous studies have shown that Ag+, in general, exerts a higher extent of antibacterial activity, compared to NAg, as the activity of the nanoparticle is determined by its physicochemical characteristics, such as size, shape, and surface charge. Our results, however, are indeed consistent with the reported NAg MICs of 0.39 to 2.5 mug/mL on @gm$ A. baumannii @/gm$, as well as with one Ag+ study that reported a MIC of 4 mug/mL.

To investigate the potential relationship between gastrointestinal microbiota and meat quality traits, we performed a Spearman correlation analysis on the different microbiota present in different gastrointestinal tracts and @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ content. The results revealed interesting associations. Specifically, within the rumen, Achromobacter xylosoxidans, Oscillibacter sp. PEA192, and @gm$ Mageeibacillus indolicus @/gm$ showed significant positive correlations with C12:0 fatty acid, while Methanobrevibacter millerae displayed a negative correlation with C12:0 (Fig. 6A). Moving to the duodenum, Solibacillus silvestris, and Advenella mimigardefordensis exhibited significant negative correlations with C12:0, whereas Mycobacterium dioxanotrophicus showed a positive correlation with C12:0 (Fig. 6B). Furthermore, in the colon, several bacteria, including Bacteroidales bacterium CF, Bacteroides coprosuis, and Solitalea canadensis showed significant negative correlations with C12:0 (Fig. 6C). Additionally, Bacillus subtilis was found to be negatively correlated with C16:0. These findings provide insight into the potential impact of certain bacteria on the @sm$ fatty acid @/sm$ and thus meat quality.

To investigate the role of protein folding in the second step, one or more @sm$ cysteine @/sm$ residues were introduced and the mutant proaerolysins were expressed in @gm$ Aeromonas hydrophila @/gm$ and Aeromonas salmonicida, as well as Vibrio cholerae.

As shown in Fig. 1a, bacteria inside the cells were labeled with Cy3 (red), whereas @gm$ Fn @/gm$ bacteria external to the host cell were labeled with both Cy3 and @sm$ FITC @/sm$ (green, appearing yellow when channels were merged). Intracellular @gm$ Fn @/gm$ were distributed mainly around the cell nucleus, and exhibited obvious morphological changes into short rod or spheres shapes in the cytoplasm of dTHP1 cells, whereas extracellular @gm$ Fn @/gm$ showed normal fusiform rod shapes (Fig. 1a). In contrast, heat-killed @gm$ Fn @/gm$ were not observed to enter host cells (Fig.

To overcome these challenges, a coassembly of the M13 virus, cyanine 3 dye, and @sm$ silver @/sm$ nanoparticles is developed to create a fluorescent tag capable of binding with molecular precision with high emissivity. Enhanced emission of cyanine 3 of up to 24-fold is achieved by varying nanoparticle size and particle-fluorophore separation. In addition, it is found that the fluorescence enhancement increases with increasing dye surface density on the viral capsid. Finally, this highly fluorescent probe is applied for in vitro staining of @gm$ E. coli @/gm$.

To probe the relationship between the @gm$ E. faecalis @/gm$ being compared and members of the fecal consortium, various @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ were added, including some utilizable by @gm$ E. faecalis @/gm$ and others utilizable only by members of the fecal consortium. These @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ included N-acetylneuraminic acid, d-fucose, d-galactosamine, d-panose, d-galactose, GalNAc, and as a control, d-glucose.

To reveal the association of gut microbial balance with clinical biochemical parameters of @sm$ glucose @/sm$ metabolism, the selbal algorithm was applied to search for a microbial signature that could predict glucose intolerance. Alistipes onderdonkii and Bacteroides plebeius were the top-ranked species related to basal @sm$ glucose @/sm$ level during OGTT (Figure 4d, left). The analysis further demonstrated that Faecalibacterium prausnitzii was the most frequently observed species in the balance for blood @sm$ glucose @/sm$ levels at 1- and 2-hours during OGTT (Figure 4d, middle and right panels). The ratio with lower abundance of species such as Bacteroides cellulosilyticus in the denominator to higher abundance of species such as Alistipes onderdonkii in the numerator was associated with fasting @sm$ glucose @/sm$ levels (R2 = 0.285, Figure 4e, left). Consistently, the ratio of gut microbial species with lower abundance (such as Bacteroides coprophilus and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii) to gut microbial species with higher abundance (such as Megamonas unclassified and Ruminococcus gnavus) showed close association with 1-hour @sm$ glucose @/sm$ level (R2 = 0.406, Figure 4e, middle). Likewise, the ratio of microbial species with lower abundance (such as @gm$ Ruminococcus callidus @/gm$ and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii) to microbial species with high abundance (such as Megamonas unclassified and Bacteroides eggerthii) was associated with 2-hour @sm$ glucose @/sm$ level during OGTT (R2 = 0.375, Figure 4e, right). Hence, the balance of specific microbial species was associated with clinical parameters of @sm$ glucose @/sm$ tolerance during the second trimester of pregnancy.

To test the compatibility between the water treatment and filter-capture, the best performing treatment methods based on the pre-treatment results (zeolite, silica pellets 500 microm, @sm$ activated carbon @/sm$ with milk coating, and the Chelex-100 treatment) were used in a post-treatment setting (Figure 2, post-treatment tests); the results are shown in Table 5. Despite promising results during pre-treatment testing, the QEs from the post-treatment strategies were either low (<60% and lower for zeolite-TWC-ZL, @sm$ activated carbon @/sm$ with milk protein-TWC-AC/MP, and Chelex-TWC-CX treatments, Table 5) or highly variable (30-100%, silica pellets-TWC-Si5.2, Table 5). Considering the significant drop of the QE between the pre- and post-spike samples, it was speculated that the C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ cells may be retained by the highly porous @sm$ activated carbon @/sm$ and zeolite matrix or caught in the tightly packed Chelex and silica resins, preventing accurate enumeration.

To understand the mechanism underlying the observed behavioral improvement, we analyzed the effects of @gm$ B. breve @/gm$ CCFM1067 on neurotransmitters and their metabolites in PD mouse striata. HPLC experiments demonstrated that MPTP therapy drastically decreased the levels of DOPA (Figure 2H, T (8) = 12.07, p < 0.0001), DA (Figure 2I, T (8) = 15.54, p < 0.0001), DOPAC (Figure 2J, T (8) = 13.47, p < 0.0001), 5-HT (Figure 2K, T (8) = 3.836, p = 0.0050), 5-HIAA (Figure 2L, T (8) = 3.594, p = 0.0070), and @sm$ HVA @/sm$ (Figure 2M, T (8) = 5.336, p = 0.0007) in the striatum. Supplementation with @gm$ B. breve @/gm$ CCFM1067 enhanced striatal DOPA (F (2,12) = 27.45, p = 0.0067) and 5-HT (F (2,12) = 15.94, p = 0.0009) levels, and dramatically increased those of DA (F (2,12) = 36.39, p < 0.0001) and DOPAC (F (2,12) = 45.03, p < 0.0001) in mice with PD (Figure 2H-K). However, the decrease in 5-HIAA and @sm$ HVA @/sm$ (Figure 2L,M; p > 0.05) caused by MPTP was not affected by L-DOPA or @gm$ B. breve @/gm$ CCFM1067 treatment. Collectively, these results indicate that @gm$ B. breve @/gm$ CCFM1067 reduced the neuropathological changes and glial activation caused by MPTP and restored the normal levels of neurotransmitters in PD mice.

To validate the statistical correlations between @sm$ GABA @/sm$ and the discriminatory bacterial species, human isolates were grown in the presence of four different metabolites involved in the @sm$ GABA @/sm$ pathway (Fig. 4b). Specifically, B. breve, B. bifidum, B. longum subsp. infantis, @gm$ B. adolescentis @/gm$, B. scardovii, C. difficile, and C. bolteae were cultured under anaerobic conditions in cell culture medium supplemented with either @sm$ GABA @/sm$, glutamate, putrescine, or spermidine.

Together with the main regulator of the ECL cell, gastrin, CgA may be used in the diagnoses of autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, which is the main factor in gastric cancer whether induced by @gm$ H. pylori @/gm$ or autoimmunity. Moreover, CgA reflects 24-h gastrin better than fasting morning gastrin in patients treated with proton pump inhibitor once daily. The new group of inhibitors of gastric acid secretion, the @sm$ potassium @/sm$-competitive acid blockers represented by vonoprazan seem to be more efficient in inhibiting acid secretion, but as was to be expected, similarly induce more hypergastrinemia. Thus, vonoprazan should be reserved for only short-term treatment where profound acid inhibition is required, such as for @gm$ H. pylori @/gm$ eradication or acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Treatment with various antibiotics such as cephalexin, gentamicin, vancomycin, and @sm$ erythromycin @/sm$ altered the normal bacterial microbiota of infants increasing the percentage of potentially pathogenic Enterobacteriaceae and lowering the amount of bacteria like Bifidobacteriaceae, Bacilli, and @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ which are part of the healthy microbiota.

Treponema denticola, @gm$ Treponema vincentii @/gm$ and Treponema socranskii produce an enzyme that hydrolyses hyaluronic acid (HA) and chondroitin sulphate (CS). The secreted enzyme is specifically inhibited by gold sodium thiomalate and anti-bee-venom antibodies. The use of saturated substrate (HA or CS) transblots allowed the visualization of active enzyme directly from culture supernatants and is a useful tool in clarification of complex @sm$ polysaccharide @/sm$-degrading enzyme specificities.

Trimethoprim, @sm$ rifampicin @/sm$, chloramphenicol, minocycline, levofloxacin, tobramycin, ceftazidime, amikacin, and meropenem were examined as clinically relevant antibiotics (see Table 2 for the concentrations used). Twenty-six strains were positive for @sm$ HCN @/sm$ (Figure 3). The highest activity was observed with Bacillus paramycoides LMR1182, followed by five strains of Bacillus (Bacillus altitudinis LMR1175, Bacillus cereus LMR1176; LMR1177 and LMR1178, and Bacillus pumilus LMR1181), @gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ LMR1163, and 3 strains of Stenotrophomonas rhizophila (LMR1210; LMR1211; and LMR1212). Two @gm$ E. coli O104:H4 @/gm$ isolates close to TY2482 were sequenced and studied: 2009EL-2050 and 2009EL-2071. We used MICRA with a subset of the single Illumina reads and the same reference genomes as the sequences used for the TY2482 isolate (Additional file 1: part 3-3). MICRA identified a new plasmid close to the E. coli LF82 plasmid for the 2009EL-2050 strain, which is specific to this strain. An interesting result was a difference between the two predicted resistance profiles: 2009EL-2050 was predicted to be resistant to the @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ whereas the 2009EL-2071 strain was predicted to be sensitive, which was observed by experimentally measured antibiotics resistance profiles. The MICRA comparison module was then used to rapidly compare the TY2482, 2009-2050, and 2009-2071 strains. A Venn diagram (Fig. 3d) showed that the three strains share a large number of CDSs and that the two 2009EL strains share more CDSs. Among the CDSs shared between TY2482 and 2009EL-2050, the tetA gene implicated in the @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$ resistance was retrieved by MICRA.

Two @sm$ phenols @/sm$, pyrocatechol (82) and pyrogallol (84) a structural constituent of many polyphenols were screened against periodontopathic bacteria, and pyrogallol showed high antibacterial activity against A. actinomycetemcomitans and @gm$ Streptococcus mitis @/gm$.

Two different minimal medium formulations were used in the @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ growth arrays (Table S1a lists the formulation used for each isolate). The simpler of the two formulations (medium 1) was identical to the above MM, except that no @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ were included and the medium was prepared at a 2x concentration. The second minimal medium formulation (medium 2) was identical to medium 1 but included beef extract (0.5% [wt/vol] final concentration) as an additional supplement. We initially attempted to cultivate all of the species tested using only medium 1 but determined that beef extract was specifically required to allow the growth of some species, especially Parabacteroides spp., Barnesiella intestinihominis, @gm$ Odoribacter splanchnicus @/gm$, and the branch of Bacteroides that includes Bacteroides plebeius and B. massiliensis. Growth in the absence of an added @sm$ carbohydrate @/sm$ source was generally not observed or very low, except with Parabacteroides that were often able to grow to a low level on the added 0.5% beef extract. The corresponding negative-control wells for each strain assayed were averaged, and this value was subtracted from the total growth calculation of the corresponding to strain on other @sm$ carbohydrates @/sm$ tested (all raw growth curves are provided as source data).

Two fluorophores, a pH-sensitive and a pH-insensitive one are immobilised at the bottom of a @sm$ polystyrene @/sm$ 96-well microtitre plate. The pH-insensitive fluorophore serves as an internal reference and makes calibration unnecessary. The sensor measures pH accurately in optically well-defined media. Particles and fluorophores contained in the bulk medium disturbed the measurements. Despite these disturbances it was possible to clearly sense differences in inoculum type and in inoculum sizes of cultures of Lactococcus lactis and of @gm$ Streptococcus thermophilus @/gm$ at 30 and 37 degrees C.

Two homosexual men were colonized in the urethra with @gm$ Haemophilus parainfluenzae @/gm$ nonsusceptible to ampicillin (MIC, 8 mug/ml), @sm$ amoxicillin-clavulanate @/sm$ (MIC, 4 mug/ml), cefotaxime (MIC, 1.5 mug/ml), cefepime (MIC, 3 mug/ml), meropenem (MIC, 0.5 mug/ml), cefuroxime, azithromycin, ciprofloxacin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol (all MICs, >= 32 mug/ml). Repetitive extragenic palindromic PCR (rep-PCR) showed that the strains were indistinguishable. The isolates had amino acid substitutions in PBP3, L4, GyrA, and ParC and possessed Mef(A), Tet(M), and CatS resistance mechanisms. This is the first report of extensively drug-resistant (XDR) @gm$ H. parainfluenzae @/gm$.

Two important geniuses belong to this family: @gm$ Ruminococcus @/gm$, proposed by Hills et al. as a marker of intestinal dysbiosis. Ruminoccocus genus and its representative were decreased in intervention studies and during sports preparation . The second genus that belongs to the Ruminaceae family is Oscillospira, which is closely related to human health and lean individuals. The abundance of Oscillospira positively correlates with microbial diversity, high-density lipoproteins, and sleep-time duration, and is inversely correlated with blood pressure, fasting @sm$ glucose @/sm$ levels, triglycerides, and uric acid.

Two other GMMs for propionate production (II and IV) were found to be active in @gm$ C.catus @/gm$ and A.soehngenii, respectively. The propionate production module II occurs via the consumption of lactate and is active in @gm$ C. catus @/gm$, while propionate production IV proceeds via the 1,2-PD pathway, which is active in A.soehngenii. D-lactate is utilized by @gm$ C.catus @/gm$, whereas A.soehngenii can utilize both D- and L-lactate. In the Db-MM, we incorporated the potential for this cross-feeding by including multiple species (A.rectalis, B.ovatus and B.xylanisolvens) capable of producing lactate and multiple species capable of utilizing lactate and @sm$ acetate @/sm$ to produce either butyrate (by A.soehngenii) or propionate (@gm$ C.catus @/gm$).

Two thousand three hundred and seventy strains of @gm$ Shigella dysenteriae @/gm$, Sh flexneri, and Sh boydii isolated in England and Wales from 1974 to 1978 were tested for resistance to 12 antimicrobial drugs. Eighty per cent of strains were resistant to one or more drugs, with @sm$ sulphonamide @/sm$ resistance occurring most frequently. Resistance to streptomycin, tetracycline, ampicillin, and chloramphenicol increased during the period, as did the incidence of multiple resistance. Most infections due to @gm$ Sh dysenteriae @/gm$, Sh flexneri, and Sh boydii are acquired abroad, and the increasing incidence of drug resistance among these organisms contrasts with the decreasing incidence of resistance among the indigenous Sh sonnei.

Paratyphi @/gm$ to ampicillin and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole were inconsistent. Typhimurium and ETEC compared to @gm$ B. thermophilum @/gm$ in response to ANE1. Regarding the bifidogenic activity of ANE4, it has previously been reported that the bifidobacterial genome encodes for various glycoside hydrolase families including alpha-L-fucosidases, thus enabling Bifidobacterium spp. to utilise fucoidan as a substrate. Furthermore, low molecular weight fucoidans from Laminaria spp. and Sargassum spp. were associated with improved Bifidobacterium spp. counts in a batch fermentation with human faeces and in a pure culture growth assay. All the above support our assumption that it is the fucoidan in the ANE4 that is principally responsible for the increase in @gm$ B. thermophilum @/gm$ counts in the pure culture assay. The ability of some members of the Lactobacillus genus to partially utilise fucoidan from A. nodosum probably explains the minor increase in L. reuteri counts observed in this study. Based on the above, fucoidan was most likely the bioactive component in ANE1 and ANE4 associated with the antibacterial and prebiotic activities, with the variation between ANE1-4 attributed to structural alterations in this @sm$ polysaccharide @/sm$ due to the different extraction conditions of HAE methodology.

Typhimurium or @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$ as described in Section 2.2 and then submerged into a sterile container containing 1 L of ClO2 made with HCl, lactic acid or @sm$ malic acid @/sm$ at concentrations of 2.5, 5 and 10 ppm. The submerged papayas were mildly stirred at a rate of 150 rpm for 5 min. Subsequently, the washed fruits were dried under a biosafety hood for 15 min. After drying, the marked surface was sterilely cut and homogenized in 25 mL of PBS + T buffer at 250 rpm for 1 min. The homogenate was serially diluted and plated by the agar overlay method with XLD and MOX agar for the selection of S. Typhimurium and @gm$ L. monocytogenes @/gm$, respectively.

Typical tibico grains are known to consist of @sm$ polysaccharide @/sm$ matrix that embeds a variety of bacteria and yeasts. These grains are widely used in some rural regions to produce a beneficial sugary beverage that is slightly acidic and contains low level of alcohol. This work aimed to characterize the microbiota composition of Chinese Tianshan tibicos using the single molecule, real-time sequencing technology, which is advantageous in generating long reads. Our results revealed that the microbiota mainly comprised of the bacterial species of Lactobacillus hilgardii, @gm$ Lactococcus raffinolactis @/gm$, Leuconostoc mesenteroides, Zymomonas mobilis, together with a Guehomyces pullulans-dominating fungal community.

UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (UGPase) is an important pyrophosphatase that reversibly catalyzes the synthesis of @sm$ UDP-glucose @/sm$ during glucose metabolism. We previously found that the deletion of UGPase may affect structure, growth, the virulence of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$, and the activation of cellular NF-kappaB. However, the exact mechanism of activation of NF-kappaB regulated by @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ UGPase is still unclear. Here, we found for the first time that UGPase can regulate the expression of virB proteins (virB3, virB4, virB5, virB6, virB8, virB9, virB10, and virB11) of type IV secretion system (T4SS) as well as effectors (vceC, btpA, btpB, ricA, bspB, bspC, and bspF) of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ by promoting the expression of ribosomal S12 protein (rpsL), BMEI1825, and quinone of 2,4,5-trihydroxyphenylalanine (topA) proteins, and further inhibits the activation of cellular NF-kappaB and affects the virulence of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$. Our findings provide new insights into the mechanism used by @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ to escape the immune recognition, which is expected to be of great value in the designing of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ vaccines and the screening of drug targets.

We developed a mouse model to compare the virulence of @gm$ Campylobacter fetus @/gm$ strains with (S-plus) and without (S-minus) surface array protein (S-protein) capsules. In adult HA/ICR mice pretreated with @sm$ ferric chloride @/sm$, the LD50 for S-plus strain 84-32 was 43.3 times lower than its spontaneous S-minus mutant 84-54. Seven strains of inbred mice were no more susceptible than the outbred strain. In contrast to the findings with Salmonella typhimurium by others, 3 X 10(7) CFU of strain 84-32 caused 90% mortality in C3H/HeN (LPSn) mice and 40% mortality in C3H/HeJ (LPSd) mice. High-grade bacteremia in HA/ICR mice occurred after oral challenge with S-plus @gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ strains and continued for at least 2 d, but was not present in any mice challenged with S-minus strains.

We employed comparative structural modeling of the NEAT domain of @gm$ C. botulinum @/gm$ protein4 (Cb-p4) against the known structure of Ba-IsdX1. Figure 6A shows conservation of the NEAT immunoglobulin-like fold, comprised of the required eight beta-strands and the 310-helix. Phe-108, noted as a possible heme-iron coordinating residue, is located on the beta8-strand at the position comparable to the second @sm$ tyrosine @/sm$ in the conventional YXXXY heme-binding sequence (Figure 1). Using Coot modeling, superimposition of heme from Ba-IsdX1 into the Cb-p4 heme-binding pocket allowed a prediction of how heme could be coordinated within the heme-binding pocket, and also helped facilitate the identification of potential heme-coordinating residues. In Figure 6B (left panel), the distance between the farthest Phe-108 hydrogen and the heme-iron is predicted to be 4 A. While this is not optimal for Fe3+ coordination, the iron atom was not included in the heme molecule in our Cb-p4 model. Therefore, the distance between Phe-108 and the iron could be reduced when the iron atom is present, to a distance that would allow Phe-108 to be a heme-iron axial ligand. Also, as determined during an in silico analysis, phenylalanine (as well as cysteine, histidine, methionine and @sm$ tyrosine @/sm$) can act as heme-axial ligands. However, if Phe-108 is unable to coordinate heme-iron, there may be compensatory pi-stacking interactions between this residue and @sm$ Tyr @/sm$-29 on the opposite side of the heme, as well as further interactions between other Cb-p4 residues and heme, as discussed below.

We evaluated the genetic diversity of @gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ isolates of different serotypes by macrorestriction analysis and elucidated possible relationships between the genetic background, expression of potential virulence traits, and source of isolation. Virulence traits included expression of serotype-specific @sm$ polysaccharides @/sm$, muramidase-released protein (MRP), extracellular protein factor (EF), hemolysin activity, and adherence to epithelial cells. Macrorestriction analysis of streptococcal DNA digested with restriction enzymes SmaI and ApaI allowed differentiation of single isolates that could be assigned to four major clusters, named A1, A2, B1, and B2. Comparison of the genotypic and phenotypic features of the isolates with their source of isolation showed that (i) the @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ population examined, which originated mainly from German pigs, exhibited a genetic diversity and phenotypic patterns comparable to those found for isolates from other European countries; (ii) certain phenotypic features, such as the presence of capsular antigens of serotypes 2, 1, and 9, expression of MRP and EF, and hemolysin activity (and in particular, combinations of these features), were strongly associated with the clinical background of meningitis and septicemia; and (iii) isolates from pigs with meningitis and septicemia showed a significantly higher degree of genetic homogeneity compared to that for isolates from pigs with pneumonia and healthy pigs.

We examined antimicrobial susceptibility and efflux systems in laboratory-derived mutants of @gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ selected by culture on fluoroquinolone-containing plates. The mutants exhibited decreased susceptibilities to quinolones and several other antimicrobials. Mutations in the gyrA gene were not always found in the mutants. Accumulation assays revealed that intracellular enrofloxacin concentrations were significantly lower in the mutants compared with parent isolates. Increased expression of acrB mRNA can explain the decreased susceptibilities to several antimicrobials but not in the case of @sm$ carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone @/sm$ (@sm$ CCCP @/sm$). Decreased susceptibility to @sm$ CCCP @/sm$ may result from the increased expression of emrA mRNA.

We first aimed to determine the shortest incubation time for which reliable AST results can be obtained for @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$. Therefore, we performed disc-diffusion-based AST using a standard @gm$ Y. pestis @/gm$ inoculum (~1 x 108 CFU/mL originating from isolated colonies) and determined the inhibition zone diameters at different incubation times for a panel of potential therapeutic antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, @sm$ tetracycline @/sm$, gentamicin, chloramphenicol and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

We first determined by Triton X-114 phase-partitioning that native @gm$ TP @/gm$0326 possesses the amphiphilic character expected of a polypeptide containing an OM-spanning beta-barrel domain (Fig. 3A). As shown in Fig. 3B, 326P1-4+ and 326betaB partitioned exclusively into the aqueous and detergent-enriched phases, respectively. These results imply that the beta-barrel domain is solely responsible for the amphiphilicity of the native protein. To extend these findings, we compared the abilities of 326P1-4+ and 326betaB to incorporate into liposomes that simulate the phospholipid composition of the @gm$ T. pallidum @/gm$ OM; following incorporation, proteoliposomes and unincoporated proteins were separated on discontinuous sucrose gradients. Fig. 3C shows that 326betaB, as well as the OmpG and bacteriorhodopsin controls, representing both an OMP and an @sm$ IMP @/sm$, respectively, were recovered only from the top (liposome containing, TF) fractions, whereas 326P1-4+ was detected in the heavier bottom and middle fractions (BF and TF, respectively) containing unincorporated material.

We first investigated iron uptake of @gm$ B. thetaiotaomicron @/gm$ under laboratory conditions. One strategy used by bacterial pathogens to overcome iron limitation imposed by the host immune responses is to produce low molecular weight, high-affinity iron chelators termed siderophores. @gm$ B. thetaiotaomicron @/gm$ utilizes heme iron for growth in vitro, but does not produce any known siderophores. Consequently, @gm$ B. thetaiotaomicron @/gm$ grows poorly in TYG media supplemented with 200 muM of the metal chelating agent bathophenanthroline disulfonate (BPS) (Fig. 2A). BPS acts as a buffer to chelate free iron and addition of small amounts of iron salts (10 muM) does not restore growth (Fig. S1A). This growth defect is rescued by addition of 200 muM @sm$ ammonium iron citrate @/sm$, indicating that the inability to access iron, and not other trace metals, was responsible for diminished growth (Fig. S1B). In contrast, S. Tm produces two catecholate siderophores, enterobactin and salmochelin, and grows under iron-limiting, anaerobic conditions in vitro (Fig. 2A). Some bacterial species do not produce siderophores but instead utilize siderophores that are produced by other microbes, a phenomenon sometimes referred to as xenosiderophore utilization or siderophore piracy. We thus tested a small panel of enterobacterial siderophores for their ability to enhance growth of @gm$ B. thetaiotaomicron @/gm$ in BPS-supplemented media. Consistent with a previous report, growth in BPS-supplemented media was restored by the addition of purified, iron-laden enterobactin or salmochelin (Fig. 2B; Fig. S1C), suggesting that @gm$ B. thetaiotaomicron @/gm$ may acquire iron through xenosiderophore uptake.

We found Bifidobacterium longum, Eubacterium eligens and @gm$ Parabacteroides merdae @/gm$ to be more abundant in patients alive at 6 months after infusion when including all samples (Extended Data Fig. 7A), and Bifidobacterium longum after excluding high-risk antibiotic treated patients (Extended Data Fig. 7B). In contrast, peptidoglycan biosynthesis or @sm$ D-galactose @/sm$ biosynthesis pathways were more prevalent in the gut microbiome of patients that did not survive the first 6 months after infusion or experienced early disease progression (Extended Data Fig.

We found strong associations between specific taxa and key upregulated metabolites accompanying the onset of dental caries, especially @sm$ Lactate @/sm$ and DHAP. Specifically, strong associations were found between DHAP and Actinomyces and between Lactate, DHAP and @gm$ Veillonella parvula @/gm$, Streptococcus, Porphyromonas, and Granulicatella (Figure 8).

We found that Agathobacter and Escherichia_Shigella were significantly positively correlated with LDL and @sm$ UA @/sm$ in serum; @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$, Parasutterella, Ruminococcus, and Oscillospiraceae_UCG-003 were significantly negatively correlated with CREA in serum. The potential beneficial genus @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$, Parasutterella, Ruminococcus, and Subdoligranulum were increased after H.

We found that CBLEB administration alleviated the enrichment of Streptococcaceae and the depletion of Eggerthellaceae, Adlercreutzia, @gm$ Eubacterium @/gm$, Fournierella, and Romboutsia in the gut of immunocompromised SP-infection rats. Some of these microbes have been reported to have important physiological or pathological functions. For example, members of the genus @gm$ Eubacterium @/gm$ have been recognized as beneficial microbes since they produce butyrate and contribute to the homeostasis of bile acid and @sm$ cholesterol @/sm$, and alterations in Eubacterium spp. have been linked with various human diseases. Correspondingly, we found that the colon-expressed genes that positively correlated with @gm$ Eubacterium @/gm$ were significantly enriched in the NK cell-mediated cytotoxicity pathway, while the lung-expressed genes that negatively correlated with this bacterial taxon were enriched in the measles, inflammatory bowel disease, cell adhesion molecule and TNF signalling pathways.

We found that Prevotellaceae UCG-001 and @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ in the cecum were highly positively correlated with BFT and IMF. Prevotellaceae UCG-001, a strain of Prevotella with enzymes that can degrade cellulose and xylan, is also considered a beneficial bacterium. Prevotellaceae UCG-001 is significantly enriched after feeding inulin to mice, thus alleviating glucose and lipid metabolism disorders. In chickens, increased Prevotellaceae UCG-001 in the cecum was correlated with improved laying performance and egg quality in hens. @gm$ Alistipes finegoldii @/gm$ has been relatively comprehensively studied and is involved in @sm$ lipid @/sm$ metabolism via its bacterial type II fatty acid biosynthesis system for producing saturated fatty acids <= 16 carbons.

We found that a higher adherence to a healthy dietary pattern reduced the risk of type I CRC (dominated by @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$ and Lachnoclostridium) and type II CRC (dominated by @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$ and Faecalibacterium), but not type III CRC (characterized by Prevotella 9). This suggests that enterotypes modify the diet-CRC risk association. A possible explanation is that enterotypes metabolize dietary components differently into compounds that affect CRC development. For example, @gm$ Bacteroides @/gm$, Lachnoclostridium and Faecalibacterium produce SCFAs from fiber fermentation, which have anti-inflammatory and anti-tumorigenic effects in the colon. Prevotella 9 produces @sm$ trimethylamine @/sm$ (@sm$ TMA @/sm$) from choline and carnitine, which converts to trimethylamine N-oxide (TMAO) in the liver and promotes inflammation and oxidative stress in the colon.

We found that a reduction of a major member of Firmicutes, @gm$ Faecalibacterium prausnitzii @/gm$, is associated with a higher risk of postoperative recurrence of ileal CD. A lower proportion of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ on resected ileal Crohn mucosa also was associated with endoscopic recurrence at 6 months. To evaluate the immunomodulatory properties of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ we analyzed the anti-inflammatory effects of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ in both in vitro (cellular models) and in vivo [2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulphonic acid (@sm$ TNBS @/sm$)-induced] colitis in mice. In Caco-2 cells transfected with a reporter gene for NF-kappaB activity, @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ had no effect on IL-1beta-induced NF-kappaB activity, whereas the supernatant abolished it. In vitro peripheral blood mononuclear cell stimulation by @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ led to significantly lower IL-12 and IFN-gamma production levels and higher secretion of IL-10. Oral administration of either live @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ or its supernatant markedly reduced the severity of @sm$ TNBS @/sm$ colitis and tended to correct the dysbiosis associated with @sm$ TNBS @/sm$ colitis, as demonstrated by real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) analysis. @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ exhibits anti-inflammatory effects on cellular and @sm$ TNBS @/sm$ colitis models, partly due to secreted metabolites able to block NF-kappaB activation and IL-8 production. These results suggest that counterbalancing dysbiosis using @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ as a probiotic is a promising strategy in CD treatment.

We found that the samples from atherosclerotic patients in both cohorts were depleted in Bacteroides xylanisolvens, Odoribacter splanchnicus, Eubacterium eligens, @gm$ Roseburia inulinivorans @/gm$, and Roseburia intestinalis. At the functional level, healthy metagenomes were both enriched in pathways of starch degradation V, glycolysis III (from @sm$ glucose @/sm$), CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis, and folate transformations. @gm$ R inulinivorans @/gm$ and R intestinalis are major contributors to starch degradation V, while E eligens greatly contribute to the pathway CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis, and B xylanisolvens and B uniformis contribute to folate transformations II. The 11 marker species selected from the Chinese cohort distinguish patients from controls with an area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUC) of 0.86. Strain-level microbial analysis revealed a geographically associated adaptation of the strains from E eligens, B uniformis, and E coli. Two gut microbial metabolites, nicotinic acid and hydrocinnamic acid, had significantly higher predicted abundance in the control samples compared to the patients in the Chinese cohort, and interestinglynicotinic acid is already an effective lipid-lowering drug to reducing cardiovascular risk. Our results indicate intestinal bacteria such as B xylanisolvens, E eligens, and @gm$ R inulinivorans @/gm$ could be promising probiotics and potential therapeutic target for atherosclerosis.

We have also reported that monocolonization with a butyrate-producing Clostridial strain, @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$, mimicked the effects of the healthy microbiota and prevented an anaphylactic response to a food allergen. @gm$ A. caccae @/gm$ is non-motile and does not produce @sm$ indoles @/sm$ (major AhR ligands).

We have earlier showed that culture supernatant of @gm$ A. hydrophila @/gm$ increases the production of @sm$ ROS @/sm$ by PBL of Nile tilapia, Oreochromis niloticus (Subramani et al., 2016b). Vaccinating Mozambique tilapia, O. mossambicus with heat-killed @gm$ A. hydrophila @/gm$ resulted in a strain dependent modulation of @sm$ ROS @/sm$ production by PBL (Subramani et al., 2016a).

We have previously reported that Prevotella intermedia strain 17 isolated from a chronic periodontitis lesion produces a large amount of @sm$ mannose @/sm$-rich EPS and forms biofilm. The strain 17 induced highly noticeable abscess lesions in mice at 107 CFU, but non-EPS-producing @gm$ P. intermedia @/gm$ strains @gm$ ATCC 25611 @/gm$ or 17-2, a naturally occurring variant of the strain 17, required 100-fold more bacteria (109 CFU) in order to induce detectable abscess lesions.

We have recently employed mass spectrometry in @sm$ lipid @/sm$ profiling of Gram-positive bacteria @gm$ Bacillus subtilis @/gm$ and reported the discovery of novel @sm$ lipids @/sm$ such as N-succinyl-lysyl-PG from Staphylococcus haemolyticus. By searching for precursors of m/z 140 deprotonated phosphoethanolamine head group fragment in @sm$ lipids @/sm$ extracted from Gram-negative bacteria Acinetobacter radioresistens, we observed a @sm$ lipid @/sm$ species similar in size to lysocardiolipin (LCL), and tentatively assigned its chemical structure as 1-phosphatidyl-2-acyl-glycero-3-phophoethanolamine (PAGPE). Importantly, PAGPE was only observed in the stationary phase. Since the lipidome of this bacterium was also observed to transition from a PE and PG-dominated state in the exponential growth phase to a CL and LCL-dominated state in the stationary phase, we postulate that PAGPE with a compatible shape to LCL and CL may serve as a better charge modulator than the much smaller PE in the bacterial membrane during stationary phase. We also observed small amounts of two additional tri-acylated phospholipids: acyl-phosphatidylglycerol (APG) and N-acyl-phosphatidylethanolamine (NAPE). Importantly, production of NAPE was also triggered by the onset of stationary phase. The @sm$ lipid @/sm$ extracts also contained large amounts of triglycerides (TG) which likely serves as an fatty acid reserve.

We have shown previously that bacteria isolated from this environment possess IncP-9 family plasmids and can degrade phenol, @sm$ benzoate @/sm$, m-toluate, salicylate, naphthalene and toluene. Vedler et al. also showed that 3 out of 38 strains degrading phenol via the catechol meta pathway have two to three phylogenetically different C23O genes. One of these strains, Pseudomonas pseudoalcaligenes C70, is able to grow on naphthalene in addition to phenol, but not on @sm$ benzoate @/sm$ or toluate, and was selected for future investigation in this study. Whole genome sequencing revealed the occurrence of three genetically different sequences of the 16S rRNA gene, one most similar to P. pseudoalcaligenes and the other two to @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$.

We have studied proton movements associated with substrate transport via the galactose transport system in @gm$ Salmonella typhimurium @/gm$. The addition of galactose to lightly buffered suspensions of anaerobic, non-metabolizing cells of @gm$ Salmonella typhimurium @/gm$, specifically induced for the galactose transport system, causes an increase in extracellularpH as galactose and protons enter the cell together. Other substrates for this transport system, D-fucose, 2-deoxygalactose, glucose and @sm$ 2-deoxyglucose @/sm$ similarly cause an influx of protons when transported.

We hypothesized that the alginate-degrading bacteria may mediate the anti-colitis effect of alginate since these bacteria can utilize this @sm$ polysaccharide @/sm$ to promote their growth. To test this hypothesis, we isolated 296 strains of alginate-degrading bacteria from the human gut and found that @gm$ B. xylanisolvens @/gm$ AY11-1 has the best capability for the degradation of alginate. Interestingly, @gm$ B. xylanisolvens @/gm$ AY11-1 was also observed to have a potent anti-colitis effect in dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-fed mice. Our present study illustrates for the first time an anti-colitis effect of the alginate-degrading bacterium B. xylanisolvens AY11-1 and paves the way for the development of @gm$ B. xylanisolvens @/gm$ AY11-1 as a next-generation probiotic bacterium.

We identified 40 taxa significantly associated with inflammation, including those reported previously (Prevotella, Sneathia, Aerococcus, Fusobacterium, and Gemella) as well as several novel taxa (including increased frequencies of bacterial vaginosis-associated bacterium 1 [BVAB1], BVAB2, BVAB3, Prevotella amnii, Prevotella pallens, @gm$ Parvimonas micra @/gm$, Megasphaera, Gardnerella vaginalis, and Atopobium vaginae and decreased frequencies of Lactobacillus reuteri, Lactobacillus crispatus, Lactobacillus jensenii, and Lactobacillus iners). Women with inflammation-associated microbiomes had significantly higher body mass indices and lower levels of endogenous estradiol and @sm$ luteinizing hormone @/sm$.

We know that @gm$ Streptococcus @/gm$ and K. pneumoniae are present in the oral cavity and intestinal tract of many humans, suggesting most could be producing endogenous @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ after ingesting sugar. Another study reported that up to 3.5 mg/dL @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ was detected in 1,557 healthy @sm$ alcohol @/sm$-free individuals, due to fungal parasitization of the gastrointestinal tract, presumably due to fermentation. 7  In another study where an alcohol-degrading enzyme inhibitor was orally administered, blood @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ levels were increased when apple juice was ingested without @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ in healthy subjects. 8  These reports support the notion that endogenous @sm$ alcohol @/sm$ production occurs in healthy humans.
